  note = {Weiter Gottheiten Erwähnt weiter Gottheiten (Apollon, Merkur und Venus) an die Terrkotta Figuren gestiftet worden sin  277},
  LCCN = {Z 565},
  note = {Grabunggeschichte: Position der frühen Grabungen unklar La posizione del luogo e desinata dall'Argolo assai vagamente e non se ne potrebbe neanche dedurre con certezza che gli savi fossero stati eseguiti veramente nell'area dove ormai non puo cadere alcun dubbio che fosse il tempio di Diana, se questo non fosse provato da una nota di Holstenius. [...] L'Argolo non dice in che anno questi scavi furono eseguiti, ma dal modo in cui ne parla si puo dedurre che non fossero di molto anteriori al tempo in cui egli scriveva la sua lettera, che porta la data dell'anno 1637.  Ma questi scavi furono per piu di due secoli ignorati, e le notizie relative ad essi fraintese, ed anche quando il Rosa riconobbe, grazie ad uno studio accurato e paziente fatto sul luogo, i resti delle sostruzioni dell'area, egli credette che gli oggetti trovati dai Frangipani provenissero dalla rivao opposta del lago, presso il confine della villa Cesarini, vicino ai ruderi che egli ritiene appartenenti ad una villa.  299 f},
  note = {Identifizierung durch Rosa L'Identificazione fatta dal Rosa delle rovine esisteni nel ''Giardino'' con gli avanzi del tempio di Diana Nemorense, fu confermata prima dall scoperta avvenuta ivi per caso, di un frammento di fregio marmoreo rappresentante la strage dei figli di Niobe, e dei monumenti epigrafici riportati nel CIL 2215-2221, e poi dagli scavi, che vi ebbero luogo in piu riprese; negli anni 1885-1889 prima per conto di sir Savile Lumley, ambasciatore inglese a Roma, e poi dal signor Luigi Boccanera, e nell'anno 1895 dal prinicpe Orsini e dal signor Eliseo Borghi.  302 f},
  note = {Problem der Pläne ... e l'aiuto unico, benche non soddisfacente, per stabilire la topografia dell'area sacra, e fornito da due piante: quella del tempio pubblicata in Archaeologia, vol. L (1887), I, PL. VII, e quella dell'area disegnata dal sig. A. Langenhau di Breslau e inserita da Rossbach nel suo lavoro: Das Dianaheiligum in Nemi, piante in molti particolari, e non nei particolaro soltanto, tra loro discordanti (riprodotte nelle figg. 1 e 2).  305 f},
  note = {Maße des Heiligtums qui, scavando la terra dalla parte piu alta e trasportandola nella piu bassa, si formo artificialmente una vasta platea di forma rettangolare, della superficie di 45000 metri quadrati, distante dalla riva del lago un centinaio di metri.  309},
  note = {Archtiektur beschreibung Altri muraglioni, decorati di nicchie semicircolari, sostruivano il talgio delle terre nella meta scavata, cioe lungo tutto delle terre nella meta scavata cioe lungo tutto il lato di greco e parte dei lati di scirocco e di maestro, fin dove l'area e piu bassa del terreno circostante, per dar luogo ai muraglioni che sostruiscono l'area e piu bassa del terreno circostante, per dar luogo a muraglioni che sostruiscono l'area dove il terreno circostante incomincia ad essere piu basso. Parallelamente ai muraglioni correva un colonnato, che in origine doveva formare un portico, il quale fu diviso piu tradi, con muri di tramezzo, in tante celle votive o alae. Le alea, di larghezza che varia da uno a tre intercolumni, sono piu alte del piano dell'area sacra, a cui si scendeva pre tre gradini. Quelle scoperte sono tutte rettangolari, ad eccezione di una semicircolare.  309 f},
  note = {Positionierung des Tempel Il tempio era non nel centro dell'area, ma un po'verso l'angolo settentrionale. Credo che questo possa ritenersi un indizio che l'area si stata spianata dopo che il tempio esisteva. In tal caso, pero, perche non costruirla diversamente? Forse perche la configurazione del terren o impediva che si costruisse diversamente, e in modo che l'area guardasse col prospetto principale il lago, pur conservano questo lato parallelo a quello del tempio ove era l'ingresso, o perche restasse incluso nell'area sacra qualche altro edificio importante.  310},
  note = {Aufbau und Maße des Tempels Il tempio, sollevato su un podio, ha la forma di un rettagolo, lungo m. 30, largo m 15,90. E diviso nelle tre solite sezionie; cella, pronao, opistodomo. Le pareti sono in tufo e peperino, con bella cornice di basamento. Si trovarono anche dei capitelli dorici, e dei tamburi di colonne in peperino rivestito di stucco, di m. 0,94 di diametro: il raffronto di questa misura con quella dei lati fece pensare al prof. Lanciani che il tempio dovesse essere prostilo esastilo: ma potrebbe esser stato anche in antis, poiche le fondamente della cella, la sola parte conservat dell'edificio, non danno modo di giudicare della posizione delle colonne: per la stessa ragione, se in antis il tempio dovette essere tetrastilo.  310},
  note = {Vitruv und der Aufbau Quello che segue, che tali tempi hanno la cella di lunghezza doppia della larghezza, e vero per il tempio di Diana Nemorense, quando per altro si prenda il nome di cella nel senso piu largo, come comprendente cioe anche il pronano e l'opistodomo: quello che riguarda la disposizione delle colonne ''ad umeros pronai'', e che sarebbe interessante comprendere, poiche dall'espressione di Vitruvio appare che era speciale del tempio di Diana, e rimasto oscuro, come lo era prima, poiche nessuna colonna si e trovata in situ, ne si ha notizi che sia stata trovata traccia di un fondamento che sostenesse un colonnato disposto in modo da piedare l'oscura espressione di Vitruvio.  311},
  note = {Thermen Anlage Cosi, nella parte di libeccio dell'area alcune stanze da bagno e traccie di una piscina; un'altra piscina a scirocco. La presenza dei bagni suggeri al Lanciani l'idea che presso il tempio di Diana fosse uno stabilimento idroterapico. E la giustezza di questa ipotesi e provata dalla menzione di un balneum vetus, che si trova in un'iscrizione, e dall esistenza presso il lago di una sorgente di acquea magnesiaca. In questo si avrebbe un punto di contatto tra il tempio di Diana Aricina e quello di Diana Tifatina, presso il quale erano acque minerali e terme.  311 f},
  note = {Aufbau des Heiligtums A libeccio del tempio, alla distanza di circa quindici metri dall'ingresso, sono avanzi di una costruzione in opus quadratum posteriore al tempio, e a scirocco di questo un colonnato. Nell'angolo meridionale dell'area sacra, presso la sostruzione dalla parte del lago, si trovarono parecchi muri laterizi, paralleli tra loro e perpendicolari alla sostruzione, restauro di una costruzione che era in origine di opera reticolata, formati degli ambienti rettangolari. Questi sono evidentemente gli ambienti designati con be nello schizzo della Barberini, e ritenuti dal disegnatore appartenenti al tempio. [...] Qua e la si trovarono altro avanzi di costruzioni, di cui non si congetturo neanche quale fosse la forma e l'uso, e di cui alcuni sono recenti.  312},
  note = {Weitere Gottheiten probabilmente molte altre divinita ebbero sull'area del tempio di Diana dei sacelli d'importanza secondaria, e Diana stesso vi ebbe, oltre il tempio, edicole votive.  313},
  note = {Weitere Gebäude Si riconobbe solo questo d'importante, che verso l'asse dell'area sacra, lungo le sostruzioni di greco ove il portico correva non tramezzato da muri per formare le alae, come doveva essere tutto in origine, era una apertura che metteva in comunicazione l'area sacra con le fabbriche dipendenti dal tempi, ora sepolte al di fuori dell'area  313 f},
  note = {Kritisch gegenüber einer weiteren Terasse Il Rosa, Annali dell'inst. 1856, p. 7, immagino perfino che il tempio fosse costruito non sulla grande area, ma su un ripiano piu elevato, a cui si avrebbe dovuto accedere per mezzo d'una scalinata posta nel centro del prospetto. Del tempio credette anche di aver veduto qualche traccia della base (Annali 1856, p. 8 e tavola). Ma di che genere fossero queste traccie egli non dice, e nessuno dopo di lui le ha vedute. Credo percio di non dovere tenere conto della sua affermazione.  314 Anm. 1},
  note = {Terrakotten eventuell von kleineren Heiligtümern E impossibilie congetturare a quali edifizi ognuna delle specie di queste antefisse abbia appartenuto; e probabile che appartenessero ad edifizi di secondaria importanza, forse a sacelli che sorgevano nell'area, e la loro variete e un nuovo indizio del grande numero di edifizi che dovevano coprire l'area.  318},
  note = {Datierung goldenes Dach in 1. Hälfte 1. Jh. v. Chr. Un frammento di bronzo dorato, anche del Museo Nazionale doveva appartenere al finale traforato che coronava il fastigio.   note = {Funde aus Bronze und Terrakotta und ihre Datierung La tecnica di questi oggetti, di quelli almeno che presentano qualche cosa di caratteristico, induce a riportarli agli ultimi tre secoli della repubblica e all'eta imperiale.  328},
  note = {Inschriften kaum auswertbar ..che o non presentano grande interesse perche consistono nei soli nomi dei dedicanti apposti ai doni votivi, o sono giunte a noi in istato cosi frammentario, da non potersene stabilire neanche approssimativamente l'eta e il valore.  336 f},
  note = {Funde primär zerstört ... e lo attesta, ancor piu che la grande variete e ricchezza di quel poco che si e trovato, e specie degli ornamenti architettonici, il fatto che oggetti appartenenti al tempio si trovarono sparsi qua la sopra una vasta estensione fuori dell'area sacra, e che degli oggetti prevenuti a noi la maggior parte e stat barbaramente ridotta in minutissimi pezzi. Una fornace per calce, che si trovo presso il confine dell'area nel 1895 mostra chiaramente a qual uso siano stati destinati molti dei marmi, ed e ovvio pensare che, se i marmi si utilizzarono trasformandoli in calce, tanto meno all'ingordigia di uomini privi di ogni sentimento dell'arte poterono sfuggire i bronzi e gli altri metalli preziosi che rappresentavano un valore ben maggiore.  337 f},
  note = {Blütezeit L'ultimo secolo della repubblica e i due primi dell'impero dovettero sengare per l'Artemiso Nemorense l'epoca del massimo splendore. I doni piu ricchi e piu numerosi appartengono a questo periodo: a queste periodo appartiene l'abbellimento del santuario, che si connect col ricchissimo fergio in bronzo dorato.  338 f},
  note = {Gründungs Mythos Ad ogni modo, sia il fondatore un personaggio storico o leggendario, il lucus di Diana appare consacrato come centro religiose di una lega di citta latine.  343},

  note = {Kein zwingernder Zusammenhang zwischen Diana und Vesta Qualche rapporto deve evidentemente esistere, ma di che natura, per la scarsita di notizie che abbiamo del culto di Diana Nemorense, e impossibile determinare con precisione e con certezza, e mi sembrerebbe ardito dal solo fatoo, che in un'iscrizione Diana ha l'epiteto di Vesta, dedurre, come fa il Frazer, che nel tempio di Diana nel nemus, come in quelli di Vesta fosse mantenuto un fuoco perpetuo.  348},
  note = {Kultische Handlungen für Diana secondo la breve descrizione di Satzio nella festa di Diana che si celebrava sul far del mattino agli idi d'agosto, il lago risplende ''face multa'', parole che fanno pensare a qualche cerimonia in cui si tenessero all'aperto delle faci accese, che il lago rifletteva. E se questo si puo spiegare per Diana come dea della luce, non si capisce egualmente perche l'Italia tutta celebri la festa di Diana ''pudicis focis'', i quali mi pare debbano in qualche modo simboleggiare il focolare domestico e riferirsi a qualche cerimonia connessa con Vesta e coi Lari.  349},
  note = {Schiffe als Teil des Kultes L'idea del Lanciani che le navi scoperte nel lago di Nemi dipendessero dal tempio, e servissero per trasportare da una riva all'altra i visitatori e per processioni potrebbe trovare forse una conferma nelle parole di Stazio: ''face multa conscius Hippolyti splendet lacus'', parole che possono riferirsi a processioni, o a qualche cosa di simile, in cui le navi avessero parte, fatte di notte, o sul far del mattino al lume delle fiaccole.  349 Anm. 3},
  note = {Diana ist grausam Secondo gli scrittori, essa e una divinita crudele, e non le si trova riscontro se non nella Artemide Taurica, o Scitica, a cui s'offrivano sacrifici umani; percio il suo culto si credeva importato dalla Tauride da Oreste, dopo ucciso il re Toante. Secondo una tradizione, Oreste stesso avrebbe importato il culto e il simulacro della dea ad Aricia, e che questa tradizione fu diffusa e profondamente radicata, mostra l'opinione che le ceneri di Oreste fossero sate un tempo precisamente ad Aricia, opinione provata dalle parole di Igino e di Servio, secondo i quali da Aricia le ceneri sarebbero state trasportate a Roma.  351},
  note = {Keine weiteren Menschenopfer Nessun altro sacrificio umano era offerto a Diana Aricina : questo appare cosi dall'espression di Strabone [...], come dal verso di Valerio Flacco. [...] Ora è ben naturale che agli antichi il rex Nemorensis aggirantesi per il bosco ove la divinita di gran lunga piu importante era Diana, apparisse il sacerdote della dea.  352 f},
  note = {Kult der Diana so einzigartig in Italien Ma nulla di simile si riscontra altrove nella Diana italica, il che e provat, ancor piu che dalle notizie, veramente assai scarse, che abbiamo intorno a Diana, dal fatto che gli antichi facevano derivare il culto do Diana Aricina da quello di Artemide Taurica, evidentemente perche in Italia non trovavano alcun'altra traccia di un culto simile.  353},
  note = {rex keine weiteren Hinweise in den Inschriften gefunden Il nome, di rex Nemorensis, mostra la sa conessione non con Diana, ma col nemus: negli scavi nulla s'e trovato, che manifesti qualche sua funzione: anche ove sono ricordati, in iscrizioni, i magistrati arcini, di lui non e fatta parola.  E non è da meravigliarsene: esaminando la tradizione, non si trova nulla che induca ad aspettarsi qualche cosa di diverso.  [...] anche Stazio, dove parla della festa di Diana nemorense, al rex che se fosse il sacerdote, dovrebbe avere in quel giorno una speciale importanza, dedica poche parole, che non si riferiscono ad alcuna sua funzione, ma alla sua continua fuga:  353},
  note = {Rex nicht mehr als ein besserer Gladiator E a questa prova della sua malignita e della sua invidia, segue un altro esempio, d'invidia per un uomo di condizione molto umile, per un gladiatore. E c'è di piu: non solo abbiamo indizi tali, da esser indotti a disgiungere il rex nemorensis da Diana, ma gli antich stessi devono averlo connesso con la dea solo in tempi tardi.  354},
  note = {rex unabhängig von Diana Queste ragioni mi sembrano sufficienti per ritenere il rex Nemorensis indipendente da Diana. Del rex parlero in seguito: per Diana, mi pare di poter concludere che questa, venerata nel Nemus dalla lega latina, non è diversa dalla Diana venerata in tanti altri luoghi dalla stirpe italica: il suo culto fu localizzato in questo bosco dove si osservava lo strano rito che doveva farla credere, piu tradi, importata da paesi barbari.  354},
  note = {Weiter Gottheiten: Egeria Egeria è secondo i poeti, la stessa ninfa che era venerata a Roma presso la porta Capena, la consigliera e la sposa di Numa che, dopo la morte di lui, addolorata, si rifugia nel nemus d'Aricia, e ivi si scioglie in lacrime, finche Diana, impietosita dal suo dolore, la trasforma in una fonte, quella designata da Strabone come il principale immissario del lago.  355},
  note = {Virbus Secondo la tradizione giunta a noi, Virbio e la stessa persona che Ippolito, Morto mentre cercava di sfuggire al padre sul cocchio tirato da cavalli, Ippolito e richiamato in vita da Asclepio,e da Dina e nascosto nel suo bosco sacro presso Aricia, ove egli condue la sua vita immortale., ignoto a tutti. [...] Da questa di discosta alquanto la versione seguita da Pausania: Ippolito, andato in Italia, avrebbe istituito presso Aricia il culto di Artemide.  [S. 358] Di Virbio, sappiamo ben poco: non abbiamo alcuna immagine che certamente lo rappresenti: quelle che da alcuni furono credute sue immagini, da altro sono interpretate diversamente: non possiamo neanche essere certi che egli nel nemus fosse oggetto di un culto speciale, con suoi propri sacerdoti.  357},
  note = {Keine Belege für die Gleichsetzung von Virbus und dem rex Ora, di fare questa identificazione d Virbio col rex Nemorensis non c'è alcun' altra ragione che l'affermazione del solo Pausania, il quale dive semplicemente che Ippolito fu re di Aricia, e che fondo il tempio d'Artemide, mentre nessun altro dice ne l'una ne l'altra cosa: Diana anzi avrebbe nascosto Virbio nel bosco che gia era sacro a lei.  359 f},
  note = {rex nemorenis kein alter König bzw. Priester in primo luogo perche, se i predecessori del rex Nemorensis fossero stati di re nel senso ordinario della parola, avrebbero dovuto risiedere in citta, ossia, in questo caso, ad Aricia, e non nel bosco, ove stava certamente il rex Nemorensis: secondariamente perche il suo nome allude ad un potere non sugli uomini, ma sulla natura, e piu propriamente sul bosco.  362},
  note = {Tot des rex als Kultteil Con la vita del rex Nemorensis e legata la vita della vegetazione: se egli si ammala, o indebolisce per vecchiaia, la vita della vegetazione si affievolisce; percio e necessario che egli la trasmetta nel suo successore, mentre e ancora in pieno vigore: di qui il costume del duello, che e forse raddolcimento di un altro uso piu crudele, per cui il rex Nemorensis era messo a morte dopo un tempo determinato. [...] Per uccidere il sacerdote e necessario rompere il visco, in cui sta la vita della quercia, e quindi lo spirito che la anima.  363},
  note = {Rex mit altem Baumkult in Verbindung stehend Chi desiderava di succedere nell'ufficio al rex Nemorensis, prima di venire a combattere con lui, doveva staccare un ramoscello da un albero del bosco che a nessun altro era lecito toccare.   note = {Bedeutung als Ausdruck lokaler Politik udn Geschichte The development form worshiping the open woods to one of the most important temples of late republican Italy is not easy to explain. One factor must have been the fact taht Dians's grove was for some time a focal point of worship of at least eight towns and peoples of a Latin League, which perhaps did not yet include Rome. Diana seems to have been the patron goddess of the ancient Latin town of Aricia, three miles south west of Nemi itselft which was probably from some time the leader of the league. The importance of Diana's cult in a political sense was demonstrated when Rome herself set up a temple to Diana on the Aventine Hill  [....] The belief thtat Diana conferred political and imperial power is implied by a Roman aetiological myth taht whoever sacrificed a certain wonderful heifer to the goddes, his state would achieve empire.  => Livius I, 45, 3-7  15},

Fundilia was clearly the most important, for her herm is the only one to be carved with drapery, and one of the statues is also of her.  41},
  note = {Funde aus der Republik Nearly one half of the items in the Nemi collection at Nottingham (apart from the coins) are votive terracottas: objects made to be offered by worshippers at the Sanctuary of Diana. They fall into two main categories: anatomical, i. e. representations of various parts of the human body; and statuettes of men, women, deities and a few animals. Initially, they were placed in the temple and its surrounding cult rooms; but periodically, when tehy became full of accumulated offerings, the rooms were cleared, and the terracottas wer buried within the temple precinct. [...] This range of votive offerings is characteristic of religious sanctuaries in central Italy west of the Appennines, comprising Eruria from the territories of Vulci and Volsinii southwards, Latium, and Campania as far south as Capua. [...] A.-M. Comella's recent study of these vortive complexes has shown that the central Italian type of religious practice began its main development in the 4th century BC; the earliest of the Nemi offerings belong to that century,  46},
  note = {Ende der Terrakotta Votiv Kultur The practice continued until the beginning of the 1st century BC. It is not clear why the custom died out, but it many be connected with the spread of Greek medical knowledge to Rome during the previous century, and an increased reliance in human rather than divine cure.  46},
  note = {Funde teilweise verloren It must be remembered, however, that the Notthingham collection, though sizable, is by no means complete nor is it necessarily representative.   note = {Existente römischer Mythos und kreierter those very few Roman and Italian myths whose evidently great antiquity, predating both regular contact with Greek literature and the spread of literacy in its application [...] is indicated both by their form and by copious Indo-European (and indeed non-Indo-European) parallels (Romulus, Cacus, Caeculus), and which ahve survived all the vicissitudes of accretion and transmission; and (ii) those, which I shall call 'secondary myth', that are the products of antiquarian industry, literary activity, a desire for impressive antecedents, a good nose for suggestive analogies and for what might pass as a credibly antique story, a talent for creating a seductive but illusory patina of hoarily ancient authenticity, and lastly, wide reading.  001},
  note = {Mythos und Legende Cf. the neat but fallacious distinctions between myth ('thoroughgoing fiction'), legend ('stories based, however remotely, on historical fact') and 'folktale' ('a species of myth')  001 Anm. 2},
  note = {Unbekannte Italische Mythen The absence of identifiable mythological scenes in Roman or Pompeian art containing figures of identifiably Italian origin is clearly itself significant, though the numerous unidentified mythological or legendary figures in Etruscan or Praenestine art may of course often constitute unrecognisable evidence for lost non-Roman myth or for variant themes of known stories.  003},
  note = {Mythenlosigkeit ..while native myths, which, I would argue, had never been very numerous, held by contrast little or no popular appeal. The Mythenlosigkeit of Roman religion was already noted by Dionysius of Halicarnassus (2. 18. 3)  004},
  note = {Nur Gründer Mythen Undeniably, the stories of Romulus at Rome, and, probably, that of Caeculus at Praeneste, were of immemorial antiquity, but such narratives are exceptionally rare. Likewise, the story of Servius Tullius is clearly in part of primitive character and has widespread mythological analogues, yet he himself remains in some sense an historical figure.  005},
  note = {Herorische Mythen ''erfunden'' Nor is the enthusiasm of antiquarian writers the only stimulus to creation: local pride in the prosperous and well-educated Italian towns (cf. Cic. Arch. 5) will have cried out for heroic origins. Likewise, at a later stage, it is easy to image that the new-found dignity and expectations of the successful and often cultured apparitores might have encouraged and even financed the development of secondary myth. Where heroic origins did not exist, clearly they had to be invented.  006},
  note = {Konstruiereter Gründungs Mythos bei Vergil At all events, both Messapus and Halaesus, Oebalus, probably, and likewise the leaders of the Tiburtines Tiburtus, Catillus and Coras (but see 6f above), all belong to that single category of Greek immigrants laboriously linked to Italian toponyms in Varro, Timaeus and earlier. Their character as figures of 'scholarly' secondary myth is itself suggestive, for their towns and peoples cannot go leaderless whether in epic or in geographical and antiquarian wirting, and their very existence therefore seems to point to the fact that the area they represent lacked recorded indigenous mythological origins of their own.  008 f},
  note = {Mythos oft bei Heiligtümern, selten, wenig verwurzelt At Praeneste, there was also, probably (cf. 61f), availabe in Vrigil's time a 'mass-produced' Hellenised ktisis-story: the town was, according to this, founded by a grandsons of Odysseus, much as Telegonus had for some while been held to be the founder of Tusuculum. Thus, exactly as in the caste of Rome, it appears that indigenous and Hellenised version coexisted. [...] Caeculus is an ancient figure, who had long attracted mythographers. It is perhaps significant that our (relative) wealth of surviving testimony derives from a town which contained so majestic a sanctuary. Similar coincidences of rich mythological associations with a notable temple or temples occur of course also at, for instance, Lavinia, Alba, nemi, Ardea, and Falerii. Hardly an accident: the physical structures, surviving into the late republic, provide walls to record an priests to embroider the scholars' source material. But it is quite clear that what Virgil records tersely in Aen. 7. 678ff is a local story of great antiquity. [...] Yet no impression emerges that Vergil himself thought this odd or striking or was even particularly aware of the highly distinctive character of Praeneste. And it would appear that the text of Virgil confirms the suspicion expressed above that by Virgil's time very few fragments of central Italian myth properly speaking, did survive; and it is therefore, further, likely that such stories had not been firmly rooted and possible too that their numerb had never been very large.  009},
  note = {Sprache für Mythos wichtig The decay of the Italian dialects - and Etruscan - in the face of Latin's advance may also have contributed to the disappearance of some local stories. But the stories of Roumuls or, more interestingly, Caeculus, to look no further, demonstrate the possibility that narrative can  - at least in Latin - survive, whether in priestly formulae, in cised texts, in song or in folk-memory.  010},

  ISBN = {},

  LCCN = {TA Arch 3 Hanso},
  note = {ZuLesen  S. 36 => Fortuna Heiligtum},
  note = {Aufbau von Gabii Some distance from the Acropolis of Gabii, near the Via Praenestina where the forum fo the later city lay, are the remains of a sanctuary of teh early second century B.C. [S. 30 f...] In all likelihood these remains belong to some sort of stage building and the septs are a theatrical cavea from which spectators could watch spectacula devloped below. Wether these were ordinary spectacula of the Roman theater or special ceremonies connected with the cult of the divinity worshipe in the temple is impossible to determine. In any case, the two elements were planned and built at single stroke and theri connection is indisputable. Architecturally, the temple stands above and behind the theater, dominating it on its central axis.  029-031},
  note = {Gottheit in Gabii unklar We do not know what divinity was worshiped here, but there are indications that thee cella was divided at the rear into three small chambers by wooden partitions, which would lead one to suggest either the Capitoline traid or the triad of Cere, Liber, and Libera. The older attribution to Juno seems now to be false.  031},
  note = {Theater von Tibur If this inscription does refer to the sanctuary of Hercules Victor - and there are no other known buildings in the vicinity to which the terms in the text can be attributed - one must reconstruc a stae building of some sort. Scaena will allow no other meaning here. Its logical position is in front of the theatron stairway, as in the strucutre at Gabii. A recent restudy of the remains by Fasolo led him to the conclusion that the vaulting at this point must in fact support something in nature of a stage since there was no visible means of bridging the difference between ground level and teh level of the platform in front of the semicircular stairs in order to render them usable as an entrance into the sanctuary.  031 f},
  note = {Parallele von Cagliari - axialität und co On such an assumption, the ''Italic'' qualities of the sanctuary - its axiality and frontality, the dominance of the temple to which the eye is led by the two sets of stairs, in short, its striking parallels with the Tivoli and Gabii monuments described above - are natural, and, although one is surprised to see them manifested monumentally as far from Latium as Cagliari, the embarrassment to the architectural historian is far less than would be the positing of a heretofore unparalleled pre-Roman Punic form.  033},
  note = {Grober Aufbau von Praeneste ..series of terraces whose function, reduced to simplest terms, is to connect  a lower cult place to an upper cult place, The whole is unified on an axis through ramps and staircases whose visual effect is to point toward and accentuate the top if the complex, the portion pertinent to this study. The shrine at the summit, hidden today inside a baronial palace, is a small circular ''tholos'' cut partly into the native rock of the hillside, perhaps a regularization of an earlier ''cave'' shrine like the one on the bottome level of the sanctuary. Its facade is hidden however, since the ''tholos'' is joined by a narrow entrance to teh center of a large curved double colonnade, not quite a full semicircle, form which descends a cavea like staircase of seventeen septs ending in a relatively small ''orchestra'', 10,5 meters wide at the front. There is an immediate drop, however, of 6,6 meters to the next level of the sanctuary complex, an immense rectangular piazza surrounded on three sides by a double colonade.  034},
  note = {Mögliche Verwendungen des Theaters in Praeneste The semicircular ''cavea'' is therefore quite pointless as a purely functional staircase to approach the temple. On the other hand, it seems equally useless as a theater in the ordinary sense of the word, since here is no possibility of completing it with either stage building or platform, and the ''orchestra'' is too small for the development of any elaborate spectacle. Keeping in view the limitations in space and visibility imposed by the changes in level, one may conceive three different ways in which the steps could still function as a sort of theatron. A simple ceremony or sacrifice or speech could be performed in the top ''orchestra'' and witnessed by a fairly extensive number of spectatores standing on the steps and in the portico above. Such a ceremony could be seen even from the front of teh round shrine. A more extensive ceremony or pageant or play could be performed on the rectangular piazza below, and, as long as the action was restricted approximately to the front half of that piazza - an area about 100 meters long and 25 meters wide - the ceremony could be witnessed by spectators in the exedra above, with room for other spectators at the back of the piazza itself out of the line of vision from above. A third possibility is that teh ''spectaculum'' itself may have taken place on the semicircular stairs and colonnade, in the form of an array of important personages, priests and officials, who would thus be made eminently visible to person on the lower terraces of teh sanctuary. [...] Despite the impossibility of determining the exact use of this cavea at Palestrina, it is highly probably that the steps were employed for spectuacula of some nature. However, even if they are purely decorative it does not detract from their aptness as model for the later Roman combination of temple and theater, since this semicircular exedra suggests at least the appearance of a theater.  034 f},
  note = {Tempel dominiert nicht It is interesting to note further that at Palestrina the temple itself, though its central postion is clear from the ground plan, does not physically dominate the monument by means of its superstructure. It is rather hidden behind the whole facade of the colonnade surmounting the cavea.  035},
  note = {Tivoli und Praeneste Vorbilder für Pompeius Theater (?) Both this sanctuary [Anm. Praeneste] and teh temple of Hercules Victor at Tibur, constructed even nearer in date to Rome's first stone theater, must have been regarded as architectural landmarks, and were before the eyes of teh Romans as impressive building achievements in cities which they constantly visited.  036},
  note = {Definition des Begriffs ''Italisch'' bzw. ''Hellenistisch'' .to dislodge ''Hellenistic'' in favor of ''Italic'' [...] is not ''non-Hellenistic'', but rather the particular direction which the fluid experimentation of the Hellenistic world took in Italy, as partly determined by localized pre-Hellenistic forms and concepts, more strictly to be called ''Italic''. Among the later the commonplaces are axiality and frontality. A more difficult concept to manipulate is ''la sensibilita per uno spazio concreto'', sensibility toward a concrete - i.e., definde and limited - space. In the particular architectural problem with which this chapter deals it is of importance to emphasize the ''Italic'' derivation fo the form, since we can find no example of a theatron appended in like manner to a temple in he Hellenistic sphere outside Italy.  036},
  note = {Praeneste und Tabularium Vorläufer für Poempeius Baiuten The Tabularium at Rome and teh systematization of the great sanctuary a Palestrina are in this sense forerunners of Pompey's theater group. In this, as in his attemps to bring religious concepts into close association ith this political ambition, Pompeius Magnus far surpassed Sulla Felix and showed the way to the emperors.  047 f},
  key = {Hanson119}
}

  note = {Seiten 180 ff => Italische Heiligtümer},
  LCCN = {P 1287/120},
  note = {Theater in Italien They haven been found at Gabii, Tibur, and Praeneste - all important cities in Latium - at Castelsecco near Aretium in Etruria, at Teanum in Campania, at Piettrabbondante and Iuvanum near Chieti in Samnium, and, finally, at Calgiari in Sardinia. [...] While the theatre-temples of Latium, Cagliari, and Piettrabondate are very similar, all showing both a symmetrical layout including an axial unity between temple and theatre, and the porticoes surrounding the temple.. [...] In all instances, however, the caveae, or theatra, of the theatres were semicircular and placed in front of and below the temple (the only linear example bein the one at Sulmo). All these cultic theatres were built in a period of only 100 years, between the beginning of the 2nd and the early 1st century BC. [...] As already mentioned, there is evidence for the existence of ludi at Gabii, Praeneste, and Lanuvium among various other places,  and since the tradition seemingly originated in Etruria, such ceremonies were certainly still being celebrated in this period in that area too.  180},
  note = {Größe der Theater in den anderne Heiligtümern - Gabii The theatre proper is poorly preserved and consists of a large semicircular cavea (diam. 60 m) partly cut into the rock, with c. 10-12 rows of seats (depth 90/75 cm) giving room for c. 1,200 people surrounding an orchestra (diam. 32 m). There may have been a stage, or perhaps the orchestra was backed by a wall only. Ludi scaenici are mentioned in connection with this sanctuary (CIL XIV 2794)  183},
  note = {Theater in Praeneste The theatre, which was surrounded by a portico that hid the temple from below, had a semicircular cavea (diam. c. 60 m) with probably 13-15 rows of seats giving room for c. 1,100 spectators, and a rather small orchestra (diam. 10,5m); the latter could be reached by a monumental staircase from the main terrace below (115x52m), were more ambitious performances involving larger numbers of actors might have been presented, for there was no stage building to block the view from the cavea.  183},
  note = {Theater in Tivoli This Herculean sanctuary is very poorly preserved, but all the same, it can be confirmed that the cultic theatre had more or less the same relationship to the temple as at Gabii, and that it very nearly matched the Gabii theatre in size (cavea diam. c. 70 m), and capacity (c. 1,200). At Tibur, on the other hand, we have epigraphic evidence for the presence of a stage in the mention of ''porticus pone scaenam'' i.e. a portico behind a stage.  184},
  note = {Theater in Cagliari In plan, the sanctuary closely resembles that of Gabii, the only major difference being that at Cagliari the theatre was divided from the temple by a semicircular gangway, rather than by straight wall. The cavea (diam. 43 m) had at least eleven rows of seats and probably as many as thirteen rows in all (h. 40 cm, d. 70 cm), linked by staircases; there was room for c. 1,000 spectators. In addition, people could stand on the frontal staircase of the temple;  185},
  note = {Lage der Heiligtümer in der Nähe zur Stadt While all the sanctuaries treated above were urban ones, whether sited centrally or on the outskirts of town, the pan-Samnitic sanctuary of Piettrabbondate lay in the countryside. Besides its religious function this sanctuary unquestionably served a political one too, as a place of assembly for the tribes of the area - that is ,at any rate before teh Social War, for the sanctuary was abandoned shortly thereafter, in the middle of the 1st century BC.  187},
  note = {Funktion der Theater in Heiligtümern wichtig All the same, these theatres must have fulfilled an important function in the life of the sanctuaries, for otherwise their users would probably have been satisfied with temporary theatrical structures, or teh city theatres, if there were any nearby. Their close connection to the temple does, in fact, make it probable that these theatres were used for the presentation of the ritual dramas, cultic hymns, and so on that were features of the great religious, often seasonal, festivals. And if these festivals included literary ludi scaenici the theatres could probably also have been used for Greek- and Roman-style tragiedies and comedies too, but it seems unlikely that they were built exclusively for such ''secular'' performances in honour of the god. That this was indeed not their primary function is also strongly implied by the general lack of permanent stages and stage buildings; instead, the major emphasis was on the orchestra, indicating thath music and choruses had an important role in what went on there...  189-191},
  note = {Etruskisch und latinische Vorstellungen kombiniert A combination of these Etruscan complexes with the Roman and Latin predilection for symmetry and axiality, undoubtedly an inspiration from the Hellenistic east, might well have resulted in precisely the kind of complexes which appeared in Rome, Latium, and teh surrounding areas in the 2nd century BC.  195},
  note = {Händler fördern Isis Fortuna verbindung In fact, inscriptions of the late 2nd century BC from Sarapeion C on Delos - that is, more or less contemporary with the construction of the new sanctuary of Praeneste - confirm that isis could be identified with Tyche Protegpnei, an interpretatio graeca of Fortuna Primigenia. It is well known that the many Italic negotiatores (merchants) who travelled in the East, for instance to Delos and the Ptolemaic possessions, helped to build the great sanctuaries of Latium in the 2nd and 1st centuries BC, and this cosmopolitan milieu might well have fostered such a syncretism between Isis and Fortuna too.  233 f.},
  note = {Nemi Isis Her great sanctuary at Nemi was completely rebuilt and enlarged in the late 2nd century BC. The works involved a new terrace for the temple and a partition of the large terrace below it, the later being embellished with a triple portico decorated with a series of unique antefixed depicting Diana and teh goddess with whom she was probably identified in this period, namely Isis.  234},
  note = {Praeneste - Fortuna Isis Verbindung The earliest indication that Isis was worshipped here is the famous Nile mosaic, which decorated an apsidal building (14 x 22 m) near the forum, undoubtedly an Iseum. It dates from 125-120 BC: that is, from slightly before the construction of the main sanctuary. Two obelisks of the Claudian period were found in front of the apsidal building (and quite evidently associated with it), and a statue of Isityche is mentioned in an inscription of the 2nd century AD, as is a Serapeum in one of AD 157. It is thus a possibility that the famous sanctuary of Fortuna Primigenia in Praeneste might at the same time have belonged to Isis in one of her many facets. If such was indeed the case, the cultic theatre that constitutes an important element in this sanctuary might also have been used in connection with her cult.  234},
  note = {Beschreibung des Theaters It was reached directly from the sacred way (the latter may perhaps be deignated as a dromos), and was trapezoi in shape (25,50 x 42/47 m). This temenos dates back originally to the late Republican period and was this perhaps contemporary with teh enlargement of the sanctuary of Diana, though it was totall rebuilt in its present form in the early 2nd century AD  234-236},
  note = {Wandmalerei im Theater ..and party because of the finds of interesting painting in the changing-room behind the sage. Here, weapons and bough, perhaps ''the golden bough'', are seen.   note = {Schauspieler als Teil  It is possible that the actors known from the Fundiliius exedra in the main sanctuary also performed in ritual dramas in this sanctuary (among others), since such actors could apparently participate in both secular and ritual dramas; comparison may be made with the members of the Greek Dionysian koina/thiasoi, and teh presence of a bust of the actor Norbanus Sorex in the sanctuary of Isis at Pompeii.  236},
  note = {Theater für Isis erbaut But since Isis had a known attachment to Diana, and since Morpurgo suggests that the Nemian triad of Diana, Egeria (a spring goddess), and Hippolytos/Virbius, was eventually identified with the Egyptian one of Isis, Bubastis, and Osiris, it would also seem reasonable to suppose that the theatre was actually used in connection with the mysteries of Osiris, or generally for the performance of ritual dramas related to teh cult of Isis.  236},
  note = {Bade Anlage als Teil des Isis Kults (?)   note = {Syncretismus As was the case in the Orentalizing period many of the Oriental cults which were introduced into the West in the Hellenistic and Roman periods were probably identified with local gods through an interpretatio, and their rites, including ritual dramas, were accordingly transferred too. This has already been suggested in connection with isis and Fortuna Primigenia at Praeneste and Diana at Nemi, but in these cases Isis was also worshipped in her own name.  258},
  note = {Entstehung der Heiligtümer In Italy, the great boom in theatre-temples coincided with teh increasing activity of the negotiatores (merchants) in the East, including Delos, and these sanctuaries were, as suggested by Coraelli (1987a and 1983b), financed among others by these same negotiatores, who had become rich through their flourishing trage with the East.  258 f},
  note = {Alte Fruchtbarkeitsgötter Whether Oriental or Greek and Italian, the gods to whom ritual dramas were related were basically all of teh same type, namely old agrarian gods, the protectors of vegetation. One may well question what these gods with their old agrarian rites had to offer to the cosmopolitian society of the Hellenistic and Roman periods. It might perhaps be expected that performances like the ritual dramas would have become old-fashioned, and have nothing to say to the city dweller. But on the one hande, most people were still employed on the land, even if they lived in the cities, and on the other, religion is notoriously conservative, and so it was that, any of the cultic theatres in the Greek and Roman sanctuaries were actually built in these days.  267 f},
  note = {Orientalische Kult als ''Lebensspender'' This is especially evident in Italy, and perhaps the revival of the old sanctuaries of these gods, especially in Latium and the addition of cultic theatres to them, should be seen as a result of the injection of new blood through the cults of the East, which of course brought with them a developed ritual-drama tradition. [...] The model was also token over in other sanctuaries where we have evidence for the infiltration of the Oriental gods, and this especially the case with Isis, both in the sanctuary of the old fertility goddess Fortuna Primigenia at Praeneste, and in that of Diana at Nemi. These sanctuaries thus illustrate a syncretism between East and West, and an architecturally very successful acculturation between the Oriental ritual drama and a local setting, namely the cultic theatre, which gave rise to an entirely new building type.  => Gilt m. E. so nicht für Nemi  281},

  note = {rex alter Kult This priest is unique to the cult of Arician Diana in the historical period. (Among the Latins there may have been other similar priesthoods that had fade away by the time notice was taken of such figures.) [...] It is a truth of the wild that one being must die so that another may live, and the ritual of the man who kills his predecessor and then himself becomes priest-king doubtless had its origins among the hunter ancestors of the Latin communities. Its survival at Arcia may be due in part to the continued excellent hunting in the Alban Hills; but it must also reflect the interpretive adaptability of the priesthood as managed by teh Arician elders in control of the sanctuary. [..] The rex exhibits the characteristics of the central protagonist of hunter-gatherer mythology, who regularly becomes problematical when societies become politically organized and troubled by the ethical and legal implications of his behavior.  011},
  note = {Goldenes Tempeldach It was a monumental structure, crowned with gilt-bronze revetment plaques, frieze and roof-tiles, and elegant sculptures.   note = {Tempel Ausbau neues Vertrauen in Diana Instead of retreating under the shadow of Roman domination, the Latin cities were now affirming the reality of their religious power to a wider and more varied audience.   note = {Kultische offenheit und Gladiatoren Kampf Terentius or his grandfather may have had a particular connection that determined the dedication in the sanctuary at Aricia, of course, but the ritual of the rex had a meaning that enriched and illuminated the tradition of gladiatorial combat as a funeral rite. In turn, the performance of the funeral gladiatorial combat at Rome and elsewhere highlighted the significance of the ritual. The openness to religious conversation with other rituals, other cults, other meanings of ritual acts seems to have been characteristic of the sanctuary in all eras.  => Plinius Überlieferung des Gladiatoren Bildes  022},
  note = {Relief mit Aegisthos - Fundort unwichtig nor does it matter whether it [Anm. Aegisthos Relief] originally came from the sanctuary or merely reflected the sanctuary's proximity. Dedications, whether works of art or ancient bondieuserie, were set up in the sanctuary and given a more specific meaning by the rituals there. The dedicators, as well as subsequent visitors who observed their offerings, learned about the rituals, saw the ways in which the rituals could be understood, and took taht knowledge away with them to the world outside the sanctuary.  023},
  note = {Kultivierte Wildniss Regardless of wheather Servius is to believed on linguistic grounds, the nemus of Diana was compelled to become that very paradox he described, a cultivated wildness. Along with the grove of trees, we should also remember the mazelike hedgerows mentioned by Ovid. High green hedges along the paths can still be found near the site of the sanctuary, and to walk among them is a salutary reminder of just how effective such symbolic natural features are at creating that separation from the ordinary and the sense of being lost in nature.  025},
  note = {Wildniss als ''Barbarei'' smybolisiert As we shall see, beyond the artful tending of the grove, the sanctuary had begun to symbolize wildness with an increasing empahsis on wildness as barbarism.   note = {Bürger und Stiftungen im Heiligtum The Voconii were Arician noblemen and this Voconius commanded Lucullus' fleet that had nearly been destroyed in a terrible storm; Licinius was another of Lucullus' legates.  Quellen: 	Cic. Phil. 3, 6, 16 	Plut. Lucullus 13, 2-3  026},
  note = {Attier reiche Familie The Atii were a wealthy family, and some of their wealth derived from the manufactury that supplied the tiles for all his new building in the sanctuary.  027},
  note = {rex als Grund für Caesars Villa Aufgabe The explanation for this ruthless and complete destruction is not far to seek. Diana's precinct , for all that is was thick with buildings and crowded with people, preserved and celebrated wildness in one way that presented enormous difficulties for the new dictator-for-life, the victor over Pompey. The ritual of the rex nemorensis, the king who killed his predecessor in mortal combat  - and who would in turn be killed by his successor - was still there, the central symbol of teh power of wildness, and the wildness of power, in the now otherwise very civilized sanctuary. [...] Yet the ritual somehow had made him so emphatically a part of the meaning of the cult that Caesar, the fugitive and challenger who had fought Pompey, the ruling (if not reigning) Roman, to the death, could not have a villa overlooking the sanctuary and hope taht his enemies would fail to use the symbolism of this other rex against him. So the villa was destroyed, and on the Ides of March the victorious challenger was indeed himself challenged - to the death.  => Sehr spekulativ   027 f},
  note = {Münze und Kultbild The coin cannot tell us for certain what the cult image looked like, nor can it confirm or refute teh existence of an archaic statue. In this uncertainty, we should not, however, overlook what the coin does tell us. The archaic bust on the obverse claimed antiquity, whether it was a legitimate survivor from the archaic period or not. The triple Diana shows how the old characteristics of natural wildness were being recast in a more threatening image of social wildness, of barbarism.  031},
  note = {Wildniss Mythos und Taurische Verbindung konstruiert The elders of the sanctuary - perhaps beginning in the third century, when the gold-roofed temple was built - actively cultivated visual and mythological connections with barbarism, with the Scythians, so much so that - as Strabo indicates - she was familary known as ''Scythian Diana'', and that this epithet referred to her nature particularly in her sanctuary at Aricia. [...] The more we suppose that the triple Diana was an archaizing creation of the late Republic, the more we must acknowledge that the association with barbarism was an intentional construct of the sanctuary leaders. In the high noon of late Republican religious organization, with its complex of buildings and pilgrims and profitable finance, the aspects of Diana's cult made known to the world of a Roman denarius are those stressing the archaic tradition, the wildness, and the barbarism of the goddess.  031},
  note = {''Göttliche Barbarei'' strategische Wahl der ''Heiligtumsleitung'' Nevertheless, despite Cicero's rather already guaranteed that the rituals of the sanctuary, and particularly those of Diana's rex nemorensis, would now be irrevocably elevated to the level of an ambiguous and dangerous religious commentary on autocratic power. [...] The priest and his ritual were well known, and the sanctuary's ''wildness'' and ''barbarism'' were clearly part of that received image. The stronger our belief that the triple statue group was a later imaginative substitution for a nonexistent archaic statue, the more we must acknowledge the degree to which the image of barbarism was a strategic choise made by the sanctuary elders. Ciceros, Caesar, and Accoleius certainly all grasped the rudiments of this theology of divine barbarism, worked out through an understood religious symbolism (no longer the reality) of the forest, the priest-king, and the cosmology of the hunting goddees. Such a reading and reinterpretation of the goddess and her rituals cannot have been a recent development.  => Sehr spektulativ  032},

  note = {Diana Namnes bedeutung ..have all accepted the conclusion that the name has its roots in di with a meaning of ''light'' or ''shining''. This root di is found in dius (''daylit'', ''shining'', ''godlike''), divus (''a god'') related to deus (''a god''), and possibly to dies (''day'')  072 f},
  note = {Moderne Liguistische Diana Deutung Thus the modern linguistic analysis telling us that Diana's name has its origins in ''shining,''  ''divine,'' and ''the open sky'' strengthens our sense that the ancient evidence identifying her as a goddess of the moon was correct. It also strongly suggests that such an identification goes back into the misty origins of the Italic peoples who worshipped her. This accords well with the nature of her Arician sanctuary because the crater particularly emphasizes the circle of earth and sky, with the sky and the moon reflected in the lake. As teh speculum Dianae, the ''mirror of Diana'', this lake accurately reflects one face of Diana, as goddess of the moon.  075},
  note = {Wald immer heilig However, the nature of the sanctuary itself, as well as later evidence form the cult, make it clear that wildness was always a fundametal element, and that the forest was invariably sacred space.  076},

  note = {Kultänderung im 4./3. Jh.  The adoption of teh Euripidean myth of Iphigenia and Orestes would have been a fairly radical change, and so certainly had to have been accomplished long before the first century. It might best be assigned to the same changes that brought about the late-fourth-century tempel with its Hellenistic influences. A radically new version of a cult myth and the transformation of the sanctuary are propably connected. The Orestes myth at Aricia and the otherwise strange an atypical cult statue worked together.  078},
  note = {Votive als Ausdruck religiösen Befindens Diana as huntress - and the other representations of her - are part of the ongoing communication of the Aricians (and all their visitors) about their religious beliefs. It is extremely important to attend to the religious expression of those who came to the cult.  081},
  note = {Griechisch und barbarisch als ''Selbstdefinition'' That is, the visual language of self-identification, ''Greek,'' had been appropriated to describe ''us,'' and ''barbarian'' to describe ''them.'' As we have seen, and will see in more detail, the Aricians clearly required both qualities, the Greek and the barbarian, the Us and Them, to express Diana's nature fully. They were also exceptionally sophisticated in deploying these qualities in both visual and literary expression. [...] While the Greek sculptores provided a new, and very Greek, way of ''seeing'' the gods, nevertheless the gods were Latin.  082 f},
  note = {Griechischer Einfluss festig italische Religion ..religion is, a living process where human beings interact with each other and the divine.. [...] Religion was not a fixed cultural construct, certainly not in pre-Christian antiquity. [...] Whatever the Artemis figure represents, it must be the result of choices made by the Latin people, a negotiation between their inherited understanding of their own gods and rituals, and the models for representation presented by teh Greeks. It was through Greek images that Latin religion began to forge, consciously and deliberately, its own religious expression in terms of material culture.  084},
  note = {Griechische Mythen nur partiell adaptiert ..demonstrates just how independently the Greek material could be used. Myth and iconography were adopted only insofar as they gave greater expression to existing cultic (and perhaps civic) constructs; what was irrelevant for those purposes was left out.  085},
  note = {Diana ist vielschichtig Use determines the nature of the cult. It was Artemis' hunting nature that was important at Aricia, and it served to emphasize the religion of hunting in the Arician cult. [..] Diana was a huntress, but that was not all she was. The evidence for her name as a moon goddess, the possible cult statues (whether they were really ult statues or not) and the triple Diana (whether that was an original statue group, a copy of an original, or late archaizing invention), all make it clear that Diana was much more complicated. The images of the girl huntress wer, and are, only a beginning.  086},
  note = {Aeneis Zentrales Element Vergil must have intended his Roman audience to read the Arician cult behind the text of book 6, and from Servius' commentary we know that it was so understood. The Aeneid and Servius' commentary therefore have to be, as booth Wissowa and Frazer saw, central to the discussion of the rex nemorensis. Vergil clearly used the ritual with a sensitive awareness of its religious meaning, even when he chose, rightly, to adapt it to serve his poetic ends.  151},
  note = {Aeneis und Servius Kommentar entscheidenend This has not been adequately done hitherto, even though both the Aeneid itself and Servius' commentary (ad Aen. 6, 136 in particular) provide crucial and authoritative evidence for the ritual. In the case of Vergil, indeed, this testimony must have been approved both by the princeps and by the sanctuary authorities. Now it remains to read it as such.  153},
  note = {Kampf wegen Sünde Although required, the taking of the bough was a violation of the goddess' protection of her sanctuary and required an expiatory death, which was achieved through the mortal combat between the challenger and the rex. The rex was armed at all times.  178},
  note = {rex pythagoreisch zu interpretieren The ritual of teh rex nemorensis, in Servius' Pythagorean interpretation, is presented as a paradigm of the young man's death to his childhood followed by initiation into a life of conscious moral choice between good and evil. The branch teh rex takes represents life itself, the life of young men who must be brought to the discrimen, the point of decision that Grattius celebrated in his poem.  181},
  note = {Politischer Katalysator Thus, in central Italy the connections between King Servis of Rome and the rex nemorensis would have made teh Arician ritual a catalyst in the heady mix of traditional culture and teh radical political ideas of the Greek world.  183},
  key = {Green124}
}

As the only temple of which traces have been found in the Sanctuary of Diana is the so-called temple KKK the terracotta pediment has been regarded as belonging to this temple.  361},
  note = {Isis und Diana We know that Diana was assimilated with the Egyptian goddess Isis who became popular in the 2nd century BC. They shared many aspects; Isis was a moon goddess, protector of children and animals and of childbearing. An inscription found in the excavations of the theatre at Nemi mentions the two Egyptian goddesses Isis and Bubastis who each haf a chapel in the sanctuary.  363},
  note = {Statuen Entwicklung It is possible to follow the increasing Hellenisation of the sanctuary, first the terracotta pediments from the 2nd-3rd quater of the 2nd century BC, and then in the marble cults tatues of the late second - first half of the 1st century BC. Finally we find an echo of them in the archaising trinity representend on coins minted in the second half of the 1st century BC.  364 f},

@InCollection{Guldager126,
  author = {Guldager Bilde, Pia},
  title = {{Diana's Mirror - Introduction}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Diana Funde Gelesen Heiligtum Nemi},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {I Dianas hellige lund. Fund fra en helligdom i Nemi. Ausstellungskatalog Kopenhagen},

  address = {Kopenhagen},
  publisher = {Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {1997},

  pages = {166-167},
  url = {},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {87-7452-226-4},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {V 282/22},
  note = {Entstehungsgrund für das Heiligtum Natural phenomena such as earthquakes, violent storms with thunder and lightning, as well as thick fogs are more frequently encountered here than below on the plains or in Rome itself. All this meant that the people of ancient times strongly felt the divine presence, and this veneration led, in time, to the establishment of the Sanctuary of Diana on the shore of Lake Nemi.  166},
  note = {Frühzeit It is uncertain how far back it is possible to trace the cult, since archaeological finds form before 4th-3rd centuries B.C. are few and far between. But as far back as roughly 500 B.C. the Sanctuary was for a period the League Sanctuary of the Latin towns, which at that point had united against Rome.  166},
  note = {Entwicklung The Sanctuary was first given its monumental properties around 300 B. C. when the first temple was built, and it is from that time and in the succeeding centuries that the majority of votives in bronze and terracotta originate. The cult was not merely of local significance, as we know from inscriptions already discovered that men of power and consequence from other cities, particularly Rome travelled to the Sacred Grove of Diana at Lake Nemi to present her rich gifts.  166},
  note = {Hellenismus The Sanctuary of Diana's experience of this trend was to undergo a comprehensive rebuilding. A large artificial terrace of 50,000 square metres was built of concrete with powerful supporting wals down towards the lake. [...] At the same time the temple underwent refurbishment, gaining a new podium, doubtless new columns and new terracotta ornamentation. Even though this particular temple was renovated, the main axis of teh sanctuary was shifted to the east. A large triple portico which diveded the more secular buildings in the west, among them the baths, from the temple area proper, was built in front of yet one more strong supporting wall. This supporting wall with its characteristic niches is today one of the notable architectural elements. Its purpose was to prevent earth from an upper terrace sliding down onto the middle one. This upper terrace was presumably inteded for a new impressive temple, which had such a curious layout that the Augustan architect Vitruvius discusses in in his extensive volume on architecture.  => Unklar welcher Protikus gemeint ist  167},
  note = {Finanzierung unklar As a contrast to, for instance, the sanctuaries at Palestrina and Tivoli which were financed by, among others, wealthy merchants who were cruising the new lucrative markets in the East, we have no details of the money which was the basis for the upkeep of the Sanctuary of Diana. Building activities show however that the Sanctuary was well provide for.  167},
  note = {Republik - Kaiserzeit (Übergang) During the first century B.C. after the major phase of building mentioned above, a small theatre surrounded by a portico was added to the attractions of the Sanctuary. As far was we can understand the Sancutary was well-nigh complete by the final years of the Late Republican Period. During the Imperial Period it was mainly renovation and repairs which were undertaken. The most thoroughgoing of theses projects was the restoration of teh triple portico during the reign of Emperor Hadrian. But new tomes demanded constant renovation - not least so that the buildings would be suitable for new functions. Therefore construction-work never totally ceased, rooms were increasingly added to the central portico, which was intended for the exhibition of portrais, both of private persons and the Imperial family.  167},
  note = {Reiches Heiligtum in Antoninischer Zeit We cannot say for certain when this occurred, but the latest finds date from the Antonine Period in the 2nd century A.D. This dating is supported by the literary sources which say that the Sanctuary was still functioning at this time. Appian, who was writing during the regin of Antoninus Pius informs us that the Sanctuary still had treasure chambers which were overflowing, while the Greek travel-writer Pausanias asserts that the duel between the rex nemorensis and his challenger was still taking place during the reign fo the following emperor, Marcus Aurelius.  167},
  note = {Untergang durch Landrutsch (?) A natural catastrophe, probably a destructive landslide, put an end to the use of the Sancturay.  167},
  key = {Guldager Bilde126}
}

An example of this is that their tile-works which produced the tiles were used not merely for the buildings of the Sanctuary but also for the villa at the southern end of the lake in S. Maria area.  168},

  note = {Villen um das Heiligtum Ruins of at least four large villas from teh Late Republican and Early Imperial Periods have been discovered. [..] Another villa is to be found between the Ship Museum and teh Sanctuary in teh La Valle area. On a broad plateau above the Lake Nemi were a further two villas. They were both oriented toward teh south-east and had a superb view over the lake.  168},

  note = {Stifter lokal The statues in the Sacntuary served various purposes: many were portraits of men and women of consequence in the local community, while others wee likenesses of members of the Imperial family. An important group of figures served to ornament the Sanctuary terrace and the little theatre, examples being the statues of Baccus, the God of Wine and of the theatre. [..] It was customary in Italic sanctuaries to offer figures of terracotta or bronze toe the gods. This was indeed done at Nemi were thousands of votive gifts have been discovered, the majority of the dating from the period from the 4th-2nd centuries B. C.  207},
  note = {Bacchus Aspekt That figures of Dionysos and his entourage seem to be so prominent in the sanctuary is due, first and foremost, to the fact that this complex belongs to the open-countryside type of the sanctuary, where the landscape was also considered to be a domain of Bacchus; in fact the landscape is inconceivable without him.  208},
  note = {Auffstellungsort It is unfortunate that we have little or no idea of how the figures should be set up in the Sanctuary. But from marks of wear and tear in their surface we can see that many of the must have stood out in the open air. Some figures were set up in an architectural context; these include the statues which formed part of the decoration of the stage-building of the little theatre. Others may ahve formed the ornamentation on fountains or similar features. We may also imagine that the statues have thronged the steps of the temple and the porticoes.  208},
  note = {Kaiserfamilien That the emperors were well-disposed towards the Sanctuary of Diana is evident form the arrangement of the statues ind teh semicircular exedra G in the central portico- AS was the case in fron of the Fundilia Room, were once two columns in fron, and there is still a dado along the back wall. Three niches which were above the dado originally held three statues: Emperor Tiberius and his two crown-orinces, Drusus and Germanicus. There was probably a similar arragenement for teh Flavian emperors, Vespasian and his sons and successors Titus and Domitian. Evidence of this comes form a partly-preserved inscription from A. D. 71 discovered by Savile. Possibly a stuatue of Domitian, which was a subsequently reworked to portray the Emperor Nerva, was part of this monument.  208},
  note = {Hadrianisches Bauprogramm The Emperor Hadrian was also to leave his mark on the Sanctuary. In 122 or 123 he restored a building in the complex which had ''fallen down through age'', and it was possibly by way of thanks for this that the town council of Aricia set up a statue of him the same year. It was also under Hadrian that the great triple portico was restored, which we know from stamp-marks on both the brick pillars and the rooftiles.  208},
  key = {Guldager Bilde128}

  note = {Orientierung des Theaters In questo caso speciale è da notare che con tale orientamento la scena è a monte e la cavea verso il lago: orientandolo in modo opposto chi lo costrui avrebbe potuto trar vantaggio dal pendio naturale per la costruzione della cavea, e anche la acustica ne avrebbe guadagnato. [..] I sedili di orchestra, destinati alle autorità, dovevano essere assai pochi, se occupavano il solo gradino con rivestimento marmoreo che circonda la orchestra. Comunemente, a parte la maggior estension del teatro, e quindi del semicerchio interno della cavea, anche il numero delle file dei seggi privilegiati è assai maggiore;  294},
  note = {Wasserspiel Dekoration Da notare la osservazion fatta dal Gatti della esistenza nel terreno antistante alle nicchie di frammenti di pomice, che fanno pensare a una decorazione in finte stalattiti, che presuppongono delle cascate di acqua. È un genere di decorazione assai appropriato in una regione cosi ricca di acqua come questa è, e assai piu era prima che una grande paret ne fosse incanalata a fornire di ottima acqua potabile parecchi dei Castelli Romani.  295},
  note = {Kanal Nutzung im Theater unklar Meno chiaro è il uso della altro canal piu ampio che si apriva tra il canale del sipario e la fronte della scena. [..] Si puo pensare a qualche meccanismo in uso nelle rappresentazioni drammatiche, che di li sorgesse al momento opportuno, e si puo pensare che si prestasse anche alla opportunita di far sparire sollecitamente i corpi dei vinti e dei caduti in spettacoli cruenti, quali erano, in genere, i combattimenti gladiatori, e qui in particolare in uno specialissimo genere di duello, di cui diro in seguito.  296},
  note = {Reperatur des Theaters La iscrizione che ricorda il restauro, o meglio la ricostruzione del teatro er la munificenza di Volusia (n. 235 della elenco) fu ritrovata, spezzata dalla caduta, anche essa come la antico teatro ''vetustate corrupta'', dinanzi alla fronte della scena, in cui evidentemente era murata. Nella sua forma banale è un documento per noi importantissimo in quanto prova, che un teatro più o meno stabile esisteva in questo luogo molto pima della età di Volusia, in quanto al suo tempo era già ''vetustale corruptum''. Ma di questo diro in seguito.  297},
  note = {Wandmalereien in kleinen Kammern Percio se non conviene a queste pitture il termine di ''stile architettoncio'', [..], sono concepite nello stesso stil illusionistico, che fiori dal primo secolo avanti Cristo in poi.  297},
  note = {Therme (?) Le suspensurae riconosciute in O' fanno pensare che qui, nelle immediate vicinanze del teatro, fosso un edificio termale. E lo stesso ufficio di lasciar circolare la aria calda, dovete avere la camera di aria tra i due muri della nicchia M della pianata.  297},
  note = {Theater mit Wasserkult (Nymphe) verbunden ... avessero sopratutto una ragione di carattere sacrale, che si connette col caratere sacrale del teatro. Per esempio il rito delle immersione in molti culti pagani e attestao dai monumenti, e , per attenermi al caso di cui tratto, è assai probabile che il teatro in origine fosse connesso col culto delle acque, qui personificate nella ninfa Egeria, di cui le fonto letterarie ci danno ampie notizie.  298},
  note = {Geschlecht der Volusii La gens dei Volusii è frequentemente ricordate nei monumenti epigrafici latini dei due primi secoli dopo Cristo. Questa Volusia in particolare sembra vissuta tra a fine del I e il principio del II secolo, se è in rapporto di parentela con la Cornelia maritata a un Volusio Saturnio a cui ho accennato.  => CIL XV, 7441  299},
  note = {Bau des Theaters A questa età appunto riportano i caratteri della iscrizione, e , sopratutto, la struttura architettonica del teatro. Infatti la mescolanza in una stessa struttura della opus reticulatum con il opus testaceum appare in età traianea, ed è usata specialmente al tempio di Adriano. [...] La construzione del teatro come oggi appare nel suo complesso, dunque, sia per la struttura, sia per la indicazione cronologica fornita dai bolli mattone, sia per la iscrizione che ricorda il suo restauro, appare dalla prima metà del II secolo di Cristo. [...] più recenti furono probabilmente parecchie dell costruzioni prossime al teatro, di cui la età non `e facilmente determinabile:  299},
  note = {Nutzungsphasen der Anlagen am Nemi See Esse, da quelle che la Repubblica emise fin dal tempo della guerra di Annibale a quelle che in età imperiale tramandano il ricordo di essere state coniate ancora per deliberazione del Senato, o il nome dei triumviri monetali, attraverso i nomi imperiali di Cesare Augusto, Tiberio, Claudio, Ottone, Nerone, Nerva, e poi dei tardi imperatori Claudio II il Gotico, Aureliano, Probo, Constanio, Graziano, Valentiniano II, sembrano indicare come età del più intenso svolgersi della vita sulle rive del lago di Nemi gli ultimi tempi repubblicani e i primi imperiali, a cui sia seguìto un periodo di sosta, e poi un risveglio nel III e IV secolo di Cristo. E is gusti e le tendenze più varie hanno qui i loro rappresentanti la ispirazione attinta alle opere primitive e il più raffinat ellenismo come la libera esplicazione delle doti del genio romano.  300},
  note = {Ausmaße des Theaters Non solo i teatri pubblici rimasti sono, che io sappia, tutti più vasti, ma anche il teatro privato della villa tiburtina di Adriano supera di molto il nemorense, avendo un diametro pressa poco triplo del suo.  300},
  note = {Bestizer und Funktion des Theaters Una altra spiegazione della sua piccolezza si potrebbe dare ammettendo che fosse di proprietà privata, e sorgesse in una villa. Questa ipotesti è già stata enunciata. Ma ci sono due argomenti in contrario: la età in cui esisteva un teatro in questo luogo, e la sua posizione.  Il rifacimento di Volusia del teatro ''vetustate corruptum'' ci fa sapere che un teatro preesisteva a quel rifacimento dal lungo tempo: da un tempo cioè in cui non erano ancora penetrate nel mondo romano le abitudini di lusso per cui anche ricchi privati potevano concedersi edifici riservati unicamente agli spettacoli.  300 f},
  note = {Gesamter Wald der Diana heilig Esso sorge nel bosco a Diana, in una area recinta immediatamente adiacente a quella su cui si innalzava il tempio della dea, alla quale non quella area soltanto era consacrata, ma tutto il bosco aricino, che occupava per lo meno tutte le pendici attorno al lago.  301},
  note = {Votive im Gebiet des Waldes Basterebbero a provarlo le favissae di oggetti votiv trovati distanti dalla area del tempio, e fin sotto Genzano, la iscrizione votiva di un colatoio di bronzo trovato nella area, dedicato Diana af louco, e sopratutto il ricordo del Nemus e della sua estensione e della sua connessione con Diana di cui è piena la tradizione letteraria.  301},
  note = {Religiöser Kontext des Theaters Non si può pensare a mancanza di spazi per la costruzione del teatro, chè anche tutto il terreno  intorno di avrebbe potuto occupare; non a ragioni di economia, che la ricchezza delle strutture e dell decorazioni escludono affato. Bisogna quindi ammettere che questo teatro non servisse a spettacoli a cui potessero assister tutti i fedeli accorsi alle feste di Diana, ma avesse una sua speciale destinazione, per cui doveva esser cosi piccolo. Destinazione certamente sacrale: la sua presenza nel bosco di Diana ne è una prova inconfutabile.  301},
  note = {Theater im sakralen Kontext Infatti è generale il suo di costruire i teatri entro recinti, che possono essere o il recinto stesso del tempio a cui il teatro è annesso, o, come nel caso nostro, un recinto a sè, ma il cui carattere sacrale è in ogni caso evidente.  301 f},
  note = {Darstellungen in den Kammern für die Schauspieler als Interpretation Un nuovo fondamento a questa ipotesi porta lo studio delle pitture ritrovate nella stanza che ho detta spogliatoio degli attori, senza specificare a qual genere di attori alludessi. [..] Invece abbiamo drappi, che sono probabilmente vesti, calzar ed armi, armi soprattutto, offensive e difensive. Notevole il ramoscello perchè fa pensare al ramo che doveva cogliere dalla albero sacro ogni aspirante al regnum per essere ammesso al duello col re Nemorense in carica.  302},
  note = {Text in dem Buch der Wandmalerei Sul prolettico aperto e sul libro semis volto ci aspetteremmo di trovare, se il teatro fosse stato desinato a rappresentazioni drammatiche, il titolo di qualche dramma o qualche brano saliente. Sul prolettico ormai non si legge piu nulla: sul libro sono ripetute piu volte delle parole, che sembrano apparenere a una formula rituale: il nome di Manius vi e scritto tre volte, e dopo sembrano invocati i Manes. Ed e cosa assai notevole, giacche il nome Manius e tramandato da Persio come quello di persone in intimo rapporto col bosco aricino.   302},
  note = {Theater als Austragungs Ort des Duelles Intanto senza escludere che il teatro nemorense sia stato usato anche per spettacoli scenici o comuni spettacoli gladiatori, mi pare si debba ritenere assai probabile, che il duello mortale per la succession al regnum nemorense fosse stato lo spettacolo a cui essenzialmente in origine era destinato: spettacolo a cui doveano asistere, come giudici, magistrati veri di Roma o di Aricia, o personaggi che avevano gli stessi nomi dei magistrati cittadini, ma funzioni riguardanti solo la vita scarale del Nemus aricinum, e forse pochi altri privilegiati.  303},
  note = {Weiterführung des Diana Kults aufgrund von ''überschreibung'' als exotische Gottheit Ho gia rilevato che i ritrovamento nella area del teatro e nelle sue adiacenze si accordano con quelli nella area del tempio a indicare che la vita vi pulsò più gagliarda negli ultimi tempi repubblicani e nei primi imperiali, ma continuò per lo meno per tutto il III e IV secolo av. Cr. Questo persistere della uso del teatro, che si identifica col culto, fa pensare che il culto di Diana si sia rafforzato colla identificarsi della dea italica con una delle divinità esotiche che in età imperiale sovrapposero la loro personalià a quella della antiche di Italia.  => Das Heiligtum wurde hingegen wahrscheinlich gegen Ende des 2. Jh. aufgegeben => Verlagerung? Wiederspruch?  303},
  note = {Assimilation von Diana durch Isis Iside poteva bene essere assimilata a Diana, e la vita travagliata del suo sposo Osiride trovava pieno riscontro in quella di Ippolito-Virbio. Che se il culto degli dei egizi, penetrato in Italia fin dalla età dei Tolomei, sempre più vi si rafforzo, fino a raggiungere la apogeo ai tempi degli Antonini e dei Severi [...]  303},
  key = {Morpurgo131}
}
