  note = {Tiberius Nemi Kaiserkult Schließlich ist mit dem Heiligtum der Diana in Nemi ein konkrete sakraler Bezirk genannt, in dem eine Kaiserkultstätte eingerichtet wurde: Herrschstatuen des Tiberius und des Caligula (?) sind bezeugt. Die Statue des Tiberius ist an einem Altar in situ gefunden und bezugt die kultische Verehrung vor Hüftmantelstatuen der Kaiser als 'Götterbilder' in Heiligtümern  352},
  key = {Post387}
}

@Book{Niemeyer388,
  author = {Niemeyer, Hans Georg},
  title = {{Studien zur statuarischen Darstellung der römischen Kaiser}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Diana Gelesen Heiligtum Kaiser Kaiserzeit Kult Nemi Skulptur},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {Berlin},
  publisher = {},
  volume = {7},
  number = {},
  series = {Monumenta artis Ronamae},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {1968},
  month = {},
  pages = {},
  url = {},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {TB 425/100},
  note = {Aufgabe von Kaiserstatue Ihre [= Kaiserliche Porträtstatue] Verbreitung im römischen Imperium ist staatlich organisiert, allenthalben wird sie in der Öffentlichkeit aufgestellt und dami den Bewohnern des Reiches, Bürgern wie Nicht-Bürgern, ''sichtbar'' gemacht, sie steht ''quam oculatissimo loco''. Diese Statuen haben neben der Aufgabe der reinen Abbildung der einmaligen Person des Kaisers und seines Charakters auch die der Darstellung seiner besonderen überindividuellen Qualität im Verhältnis zu den übrigen Menschen.  14},
  note = {Primär Statuen die öffentliche, auf die Öffentlichkeit wirkende und für sie bestimmte Repräsentation des Menschen und besonders des Herrsches bedient sich immer in erster Linie des statuarischen Bildnisses, wie schriftliche und monumentale Überlieferung erweisen.  15},
  note = {Monarchische Züge des Prinzipats Die Fiktionen auf den tatsächlichen Charakter des römischen Kaisertums zu projiziere, ist jedoch nicht erlaubt, denn an den Tataschen ändert sich hierdurch nichts. Schon die antike Historiographie hat den monarchischen, um nicht zu sagen ''absolutistischen'' Charakter des Prinzipats erkannt und diese Tatasche dazu benutzt den Ablauf der römischen Geschichte zu periodisieren: die Monarchie, die in der antiken Literatur mit Caesar oder, häufiger mit Augustus beginnt, wird stets deutlich von der Zeit der freien Republik abgesetzt und auch in der späteren Zeit ohne Unterscheidung zwischen Früh- und Spätformen behandelt.  16},
  note = {Grundlagen der Herrschaft im Titel des Kaisers So dürfen wir in der Namensformel ebenso wie in der vollen Titulatur des römischen Kaisers ein besonders wichtiges Mittel erkenne, durch das die Institution des Prinzeps in ihrem Gehalt verdeutlicht und zugleich durch die ständige, von der einzelnen Person unabhängigen Wiederholung der ''Propaganda'' jedem selbstverständlich gemacht werden sollte. Mit den drei Grundelemente der Kaisertitulatur 'Imperator', 'Caesar' und 'Augustus' werden die drei wesentlichen Aspekte des Prinzipats von Anfang an deutlich bezeichnet. a) ''Caesar''. Durch die Übernahme des Cognomen Caesar in die Kaisertitulatur macht Augustus den Namen seines Adpotiv-Vates zum Titel, zur Bezeichnugn eines besonderen Ranges. [...] Die durch diesen Akt in die übermenschliche Sphäre hinaufgehobene Abkunft des Kaisers verstärkt den religiösen Gehalt des Prinziats, der sonst vornehmlich mit dem Ephitheton ''Augustus'' bezeichnet wird. b) ''Imperator'' [...] Die ausschließliche Beschränkung des Nemens auf den Kaiser allein macht ihn damit auch zum alleinige Träger des höchsten militärischen Auftrages und, ideologisch gesehen, zum ''Sieger schlechthin''. [...] c) ''Augustus''. Der religiöse Rang des Princeps ist immer wieder stark umstritten und am schwersten zu dfinieren. [...] Die kultische Verehrung des Kaisers zu seinen Lebzeiten und damit die Möglichkeit zu seiner Identifizierung mit einem göttlichen Wesen setzt bereits unter Augustus ein und war von ihm gewiß beabsichtigt und gelenkt, obgleich er und besonders sein erster Nachfolger, Tiberius, sich wenigstens offiziell eine gewisse Zurückhaltung auferlegt haben. [....] Für dieses [= einfache Volk] glich auch Augustus schon zu Lebzeiten einem Gott. [...] Bei der statuarischen Darstellung der Kaiser lehrt die Betrachtung des Darstellungsinhaltes und ebenso des unmittelbaren antiken Wirkungsfeldes, das von der Aufstellung der Statuen in ihrem Zusammenhang bedingt ist, einzelne Züge dieser kultischen Verehrung kennen. [...] dass ''der lebende Kaiser, obwohl nicht offiziell ein Gott, auf verschiedenste Weise in einen übermenschlichen Status erhoben war.''  16},
  note = {Funktion von kaiserlichen Statuen Wir ersehen aus ihm, zu welchem Zweck die Statue aufgestellt wurde und wie sich die Menschen zu ihr verhielten oder verhalten mußten. Die Fülle der verschiedenen Funktionen läßt sich in zwei große Bereiche zusammenfassen, den staatsrechtlichen und den kultischen. Beide Bereiche überschneiden sich häufig und sind in manchen Fällen nicht voneinander zu trennen.  17 f},
  note = {Aufstellungsrecht von Statuen Aus den Schriftquellen gewinnen wir jedoch den Eindruck, daß im 1. Jh. n. Chr. (und auch wohl schon vorher) Mißbräuche eingrissen waren, denen zufolge mancher sich selbstherrlich und weit über Gebühr ehren ließ. So verbot Tiberius, Statuen oder Bildnisse (''Statuas atque imagines'') ohne seine Erlaubnis aufzustellen. Wenig später hören wir noch zweimal von einem gleichlautenden Erlaß, wobei einmal wiederum der Kaiser als Instanz genannt wird, einmal der Senat. Im 2. Jh. n. Chr. wird die Ehrung durch einen auf öffentlichen Plätzen oder in öffentlichen Gebäuden aufgestellte Statue anscheinend ausschließlich entweder vom Kaiser selbst beantragt oder auf privaten Antrag vom Kaiser genehmigt. Der Antrag des Kaisers vor dem Senat scheint, wie die Alterantive lehrt, nur eine Formsache gewesen zu sein. Das kaiserliche Bildnisrecht war von solchen Bedingungen nicht abhängig  18},
  note = {Aufstellungsrecht von Statuen in der Provinz bzw. nicht Stadt Rom In den Provinzen und wohl auch in Italien war das Recht zur Genehmigung einer öffentlich aufzustellenden Statue an die örtlichen Behörden delegiert, wie ein Blick auf die Basisinschriften solcher Statuen lehrt. [...] Das Recht der ''Gemeinden'' auf Bildnisehrung nicht-kaiserlicher Persönlichkeiten wird auch bei Cassius Dio [= Cas. Dio. 76, 15, 6 f.] erwähnt. [...] Nach einer Nachricht bei Tacitus gab es im Bildnisrecht für Personen nicht-kaiserlichen Ranges bestimmte Vorschriften hinsichtlich der Größe und der Aufstellung, wenn solche Staue in Gemeinschaft mit Statuen des oder der Kaiser aufgestellt wurden, vielleicht aber sogar überhaupt  18},
  note = {Göttlichkeit von Augustus nach dem Tod Die Göttlichkeit des Augustus wurde damit unmittelbar nach seinem Tode für alle gleichermaßen deutlich definiert; während seiner Lebenszeit war sie jedenfalls in Rom nach dem Willen des Augustus selbst nur verschleiert angedeutet worden.  20},
  note = {Rechtlicher Status Die rechtliche Bedeutung der kaiserlichen Bildnisstatue gründet sich auf ihre Stellvertreter-Funktion.  20},
  note = {Kaiserliche Statue als Kultstatue Das loyale Verhältnis römischer Untertanen zu diesen Bildnisstatuen nun bestand in kultischer Verehrung, ebenso, wie es Plinius mit seinem berühmten Brief an den Kaiser Traian ein knappes Jahrhundert später von den Christen berichtet, die in Bithynien dem Kaiser mit Weihrauch und Trankspende ihre Verehrung bezeugten.  21},
  note = {Kaiserkult für verstorben Kaiser ..ist die respektvolle Pflege und Verehrung der Statuen des Vorgängers, wie sie verschiedentlich überliefert wird. Dokumentationen des Kaiserkultes und der dynastischen Legitimierung des einzelnen Kaisers zugleich, werden die hierfür einschlägigen Schriftquellen bei der Behandlugn des Statuenkultes sinnvoller Platz finden.  22},
  note = {Göttlichkeit des Bildes darf nicht angerührt werden Auch der individuelle Bildnischarakter der Kaiserstatue sollte erhalten bleiben vor allem aber verbot die Göttlichkeit der Dragestellten die Auslöschung seines Bildes. Es entspricht einem verwandeten Gedanken, wenn in spätrömischer Zeit die Falschmünzerei als sacrilegium am Kaiserbild und nicht etwas als Wirtschaftsverbrechen geahndet wird.  22},
  note = {Kultstatuen im Theater Wir wissen bereits aus anderen Zeugnissen, daß Statuen im Theater bzw. in der Bühnenfront eines Theaters Gegenstand des Kultes sein konnten.  23},
  note = {Göttlichkeit des Kultbildes Durch die Funktion eines göttlichen Kultbildes erhielten die kaiserlichen Blidnisstatuen auch in Rom die üblichen Funktionen des Götterbildes, wie etwa die Gewährung des Asylrechtes.  23},
  note = {Kaiserstatuen - Zusammenfassung Diese Statuen sind unter dem politischen, juristischen und kultischen Aspekt Stellvertreter des Kaisers mit allen Konsequenzen, die sich aus dieser Stellung ergeben: In Rang und Funktion könnne sie teilweise mit der Person des Kaisers identisch werden. [...] Sie wird dadurch zu einem wichtigen, wenn auch nicht dem einzigen Vermittler kaiserlicher Propaganda und zum volllgültigen Träger der Kasierlichen Herrschaftsidee. Die enge ideologische Verknüpfung mit Herrschaftsidee und Kaiserkult bedingt in Wechselwirkung die aufklärende Bedeutung, die den Statuen für jene Fragen beigemessen werden muß.  26},
  note = {Bedeutung und wichtigste Typen Neben der Gruppe der Toga- und Panzerstatuen sind eine Reihe weiterer Bildtype des statuarischen Proträts der römischen Kaiser in der Wirklichkeitswelt beheimatet, stellen also den Kaiser in einer Bildform dar, die dem Bewohnter des römischen Imperiums von Augenschein her vertraut sein konnte. Dem offiziellen Range nach stehen hier die Reiterstatue an erster Stelle.  39},
  key = {Niemeyer388}
}

@Book{Muth415,
  author = {Muth, Robert},
  title = {{Einführung in die griechische und römische Religion}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Einführung Entwicklung Gelesen Geschichte Griechisch Kaiser Kult Religion Römisch},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {Darmstadt},
  publisher = {Wissenschaftl. Buchges},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {1988},
  month = {},
  pages = {X, 347 S ;},
  url = {http://www.gbv.de/dms/hebis-darmstadt/toc/7126050.pdf},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {3-534-03839-8},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {P 300/20},
  note = {Besonderheit des Kaiserkults Dies ist deshalb von besonderer Bedeutung, weil dieser Kult den Versuch darstellte, die römische Religion um des Zusammenhaltes des Reiches willen zu vereinheitlichen und aus politischem Interesse dem Polytheismus - trotz aller kultischen Toleranz - Grenze zu setzen.  211},
  note = {Genius als Träger des Kaiserkults Vor allem war zum Verständnis des Kaiserkultes der Glaube an den genius maßgeblich, an jene göttliche Kraft, welche die Zeugungskraft des Mannes verbürgte und ihn als Beschützer durch sein Leben begleitete. [...] Die Verehrung des Genius des pater familias war in den Familien vorrangig; so konnte auch dem Genius des Kaisers, des pater patriae, besonders an seinem Geburtstag, vom ganzen Volk göttlicher Kult zuteil werden, um so mehr, als in Rom der schon lange durch ein Ritual verehrte genius populi Romani mit dem Genius des Kaisers in Verbindung gebracht wurde.  212},
  note = {Götterbilder Soweit Götterbilder verehrt wurden, liegt etruskischer, griechischer oder orientalischer Einfluß vor. Daher kann der Verehrung von Götterbildern im römischen Kult nie so große Bedeutung zu wie im griechischen. Viele Götter wurden überhaupt nie bildlich dargestellt.  214},
  note = {Keine Mythen bei den Römern Überdies lagen schon in früher Zeit Nachdichtungen und römische Ausgestaltugnen griechischer Heldensagen vor. Dabei handelt es sich jedoch um Schöpfungen der Dichtung und nicht der Volksreligion. [...] Soweit jedoch Sagen welcher Art immer existierten, fielen sie bei der Ausformung der alten römisch-italischen Relgion zum Staatskult Roms einer Entmythisierung zum Opfer, weil sie nicht zur genuin römischen Gottesvorstellung paßten.  216},
  note = {Kult wichtiger als Religion Der Begriff religio wird häufig als cultus deorum verstanden und umschrieben. In einer Religion, in der die Gottheit in der Geschichte, genauer : im konkreten historischen Akt, präsent und manifest wird, hängt alles davon ab, daß diese Vergegenwärtigung der Gottheit im rechten Moment eintritt.  218},
  note = {religio Zeichen des politische Geschehens Für diese [= röm. religio anderen ''überlegen'' da Weltherrschaft] politisch-religiöse Weltansicht liegen Zeugnisse schon seit Begeinn des 2. Jh. v. Chr. vor, sie trat gegen Ende der Republik in das Bewußtsein weiterer Kreise und wurde in augusteischer Zeit regelrecht zu einer Reichsidee ausgeabut. Deshalb ging es Augustus bei seiner inneren Reform vor allem auch um eine Erneuerung des Kultes, Nur so schien die pax Augusta gesichert.  221 f.},
  key = {Muth415}

@Book{Romano429,
  author = {Romano, Irene Bald},
  title = {{Classical Sculpture - Catalogue of the Cypriot, Greek, and Roman Stone Sculpture in the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Funde Gelesen Geschichte Heiligtum Nemi Priorität Skulptur},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {Philadelphia},
  publisher = {Univ. of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {2006},
  month = {},
  pages = {XII, 331},
  url = {http://www.gbv.de/dms/bsz/toc/bsz252349881inh.pdf},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {9781931707848},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {V 143/9},
  note = {Enstehung The early history of this sanctuary is murky, but from historical evidence and archaeological finds it its possible to trace the beginnings of worship of Diana on that spot to at least teh Archaic period (ca. 500 BC) when it was the site of the federal sanctuary of teh Latin towns. The earliest finds indicating temple building activity at the sanctuary are the architectural terracottas of ca. 300 BC and the votive temple models of teh same approximate date. Architectural terracottas also confirm subsequent building phases of around teh mid-2nd c. BC and ca. 100 BC, and small finds and inscriptions also indicate a high level of activity in the sanctuary during the 3rd and 2nd c. BC. The plan of the sanctuary with its vas artifical terraces and retaining walls seems to have been completed in the late 2nd c. BC, though it continued to be an important site in the Early Imperial period with donations of large scale votive sculptures, e.g., the portraits of Tiberius, Germanicus, and Dursus, now in the Glyptotek in Copenhagen, and with major architectural modifications in the Hadrianic period. After the reign of Marcus Aurelius, there is no evidence of buiding activity at the sanctuary, and that combined with the lack of finds indicates that the life of the sanctuary had come to an end towards the later 2nd c. AD, perhaps by some natural disaster.  73},
  note = {Diana ''Persönlichkeit'' As we can attest from the sculptural representation from Nemi of Diana wearing her short costume and hunting boots, she was worshipped there as goddes of the hunt in the verdant woods surrounding the lake, but like many Greek divinities in the Roman sphere, Diana`s identiy was complex, She was associated with Hekate, the goddes of the underworld, and like Hekate was worshipped as Trivia (''at the crossroad''), as a triple-bodied figure, and with torches lighting the way to the darker realm. [...] inform us that Diana Nemorenis was also a healing dvinity. [...] Hipolytos lived his resurrected life as the divin Virbius, a servant to Diana in ther sanctuary at Nemi. [...] She was also associated with Isis, the Egyptian goddes of childbirth and healing whose cult throughout the Hellenistic and Roman worlds attracted many female worshippers. From treasury lists of the Late Republican period we know that a temple dedicated to Isis existed at Nemi. The UPM`s pygmy and crocodile relief may be a remnant of that shrine to Isis.  75},
  note = {Fundverteilung Savil Lumley`s stubstantial division of teh finds from his explorations, including several large sculptures, many architectural and votive terracottas, and coins was given by him to the Castle Museum in Nottingham, England, while those retained by Count Orsini were put up for sale and dispersed, some now in the Villa Giulia Museum in Rome and others in teh Museum fo Fine Arts in Boston and elsewhere.  76},
  note = {Räume als ''Schatzkammern'' It is unclear excatly why the sculptures were in this small room aloong, the northern portico. The jumble of fragmentary and whole pieces of mixed chronology (Late Republican and Early Imperial periods) and with different functions (votives as well as cult images) suggest that the sculptures were cleared from other places in the sanctuary and that they were not in their primary use context. That this small vaulted room was a storage/treasury room for sanctuary material seems the most likely hypothesis.  77},
  note = {Interpretation Fundilia Statuen Moltesen and others have suggested that these sculptures were an elaborate show of gratitude from Fundilius to his former patroness, while at the same time a thank offering to Diana. Although the room was not built to house these sculptures, its later use was clearly as a sort of sculpture gallery of local dignitaries.  77},
  note = {Wann die Statuen eingelagert wurden An analysis fo the construction of the rooms indicates that they were probably built in the second half of the 1st c. BC. It is, of course, not certain that the deposition of the material occurred in a single moment, but the terminus post quem for the depostion is given by the date of the latest sculptures taht certainly came from room 9, the marble griffin cauldron vessels of the late 1st c. BC or early 1st c. AD.  77},
  note = {Interpretation jungendliche Figuren The dancing youthful males could be satyrs on the basis of their soft physiques and of the parallels for the poses of some of them, though none have tails, teh obvious satyr characteristic. [...] Guldager Bilde and Moltesen have offered the intriguing and attractive interpretation that these effeminate, young nude male statuettes may be images of Hippolytos/Virbius, the young god who served the cult of Diana at Nemi in his reincarnated state. [...] According to the version of the myth told in Ovid, teh Greek Hippolytos aged when he was transformed to the Latin god Virbius and there is a possibility that Hippolytos was also depicted in the Roman period as bearded. [...] Elizabeth Bartman shows, however, that the phenomenon of ''sexy boys'', as she calls these androgynous youths, especially in leaning poses, is very widespread in Roman art... [...] These androgynous youth may simply have been pleasing ideal greek images which found suitable places as votives in a public sanctuary in Italy in Late Republican times  79},
  note = {Aufstellung zumeist draußen The statuettes seem mostly to have been used in outdoor settings to judge from the signs of weathering on many.  79},
  note = {Marmor teurer als Herstellung This suggestes taht the imported marble material was perhaps more expensive than the labor to create the piece of sculpture.  80},
  note = {Blütezeit In the late 2nd and 1st c. BC, a period when the sanctuary at Nemi is at its peak and from which most if the UPM`s Nemi sculptures date, Rome is bringing into its sphere of dominion the Greek kingdoms and exerting its considerable influence on artistic trends, thus creating new markets on the Italian mainland for certain types of Greek sculptural production. [...] The sculputres from sanctuary sites in Latium like those at Nemi and Praeneste, whose Sanctuary of Fortuna Primigenia undergoes a major a major reorganization in the last decades of the 2nd c. BC, and from the homes of wealthy Romans at Praeneste and at teh villa at Fianello Sabino in northern Latium share common elements pointing to links with the Aegean islands of Rhodes and Delos and wiht Attica. [....] The preferred marble for the later 2nd and 1st c. BC statuettes at Nemi is Parian, just as it is on Delos, Rhodos, and for the Praenestean production. Then,  in the Nemi sculptures of the later 1st c. BC and teh early 1st c. AD the emergence of a new impetus in sculptural styles coincides with the first exploitation of the local Italian marble quarries at Carrara  81},
  note = {Neo-Attische Werke und Ägyptischer Einfluss The decorative relief plaque of Pan and Dionysos (73) and the Dionysos herm (72), both of Penetelic marble, stand out in the Nemi corpus as eclectic works whose classicizing tendencies invite parallels with ''Neo-Attic'' works of the Late Hellenistic and Early Imperial period. The Nilotic relief with pygmies and crocodiles of Pentelic marble (74), on the other hand, seems to bear no relationship to ''Neo-Attic'' works and is thematically part of a general interest in ''Egyptianizing'' art in Italy following the annexation of Egypt after 30 BC, with Delos possibly playing some intermediary role in trade between Alexandrian Egypt and Italy.  83},
  key = {Romano429}
}

@PhDThesis{Bentz430,
  author = {Bentz, Martin},
  title = {{Etruskische Votivbronzen des Hellenismus}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Etrurien Funde Gelesen Heiligtum Nemi Republik Skulptur Vergleich Votive},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {Florenz},
  publisher = {Olschki},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {1992},
  month = {1989},
  pages = {257},
  url = {},
  school = {Universität Göttingen},
  ISBN = {88-222-3957-1 },
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {TA 260/158},
  note = {Kult Ziel Wenn überhaupt weitergehende Aussagen getroffen werden können, weisen sie in den dionysisch-aphrodischen Bereich. Im 3. Jh. sind dies zunächst nur wenige Figuren mit dionysisch interpretierbaren Haarmotiven, im 2. Jh. ist es dann fast die gesamte Produktion, die den Blätterkranz dionyischen Ursprungs trgt, ohne jedoch auf Dionysos Kulte beschränkt zu sein. Ein grundsätzlicher Wandel gegenüber dem 5. und 4. Jh. liegt in der Opferhaltung der Weihenden. Während bis weit in das 4. Jh. hinein der ehrfurchtsvolle Adorationsgestus mit den gegen die Gottheit erhobenen Händen vorherrscht, ist für die gesamte später Zeit, bis auf einige Ausnahmen, der aktive Opfergestus mit Patera verbindlich; im 2. Jh. kommt dann noch die Acerra oder Pyxis hinzu.  183},
  note = {Teilweise Kulttradition Die Auswirkungen der etruskishcen Darstellungen und Kulte auf die späteren römische Vorstellungen können hier ebenfalls nicht ausführlich behandelt werden. Für einige Kultplätze, so Bolsena, Colle Arsiccio  und Fiesole, ist eine Kontinuität bis in die Kaiserzeit hinein zu beobachten.  223 f},
  note = {Soziale Entwicklung in Etrurien Seit dem ausgehenden 4. Jh., verstärkt im 2. Jh. findet eine soziale Umschichtung statt, bei der sich ehemalige Sklaven und Angehörige der Unterschicht zu einer neuen Mittelklaase formieren. Durch einige Inschriften mit nennung der Stifer konnte dieser Prozeß bestätigt werden.  239},
  key = {Bentz430}
}

  ISBN = {},
  edition = {},
  note = {Gruppen The sculptures fall into roughly four groups: the Late-Hellenistic cult statues (in Copenhagen, Philadelphia and Nottingham), the small-scale votive sculptures dated from the very last years of the second and the first half of the 1st centuries B.C. (in Philadelphia), a group of marble vases of the 1st century B.C. - 1st centruy A.D. (in Copenhagen and Philadelphia), and lastly a series of Roman portraist dated in the reigns fo Tiberius and Claudius, i.e. the first half of the 1st century A.D. (in Copenhagen).  101},
  note = {2. Umbauten In the 2nd century B. C. many new temples were built all over the Mediterranean and large new cult statues were made for them in marble. These were often in a style reminscent of the Classical style of the 5th - 4th century B. C. In Italy the use of marble was introduced as something new, but the marble and also the sculptors had to be imported as the local Carraca quarries wer only fully exploited from the late 1st century B.C.  102},
  note = {Kleine Statuen There are 28 pieces of small-scale sculptures ranging in size from about 50 to 125 cm. They are free-standing figures and constitute an interesting variety of late-hellenistic types: Diana, Aphrodite, a saytr, and serveral effminate and elongated young boys. Such small-scale marbble sculptures are found in other sanctuaries in the Mediterranean. They are common in Knidos and on Rhodes and Kos, but also occur in Magna Graecia.  102},
  note = {Chio Vasen Pia Guldager Bilde has publisehd this unique group of vases and considers the four amphorae works of a Neo-Attica workshop of the 1st century B.C. whereas the manufacture of the griffin cauldrons and the donation of all the vases by Chio is dated to the reign of Augustus in the first years of the 1st cenury A.D.  103},
  note = {Fundilia Our analyes show that Fundilia`s body is in Carrara marble while Fundilius and perhaps Fundilia`s head are in Dokeimion marble. In the same room as these two portraits were found a series of inscribed herms in bluish marble carrying portrait heads in white marble, all but one of which is in Parian lychnites marble.  104},
  note = {Porträts These portraits are of local citizens, all belonging to the middle class of former slaves and their descendants. Stylistically they are so close to one another that we must surmise that they came from the same workshop, although Licinia Chrysarion is in Carrara marble.	  104},
  note = {Tiberius, Drusus und Germanicus The statues would thus represent the emperor Tiberius and his two designated heirs, his son Drusus and his nephew Germanicus, and can be dated to around the year 20 A. D. The style of the workmanship and details were made in the same workshop as Fundilius and Fundilia. It is also significant that white marbles form different provenances, in this case Paros, Dokeimion and Carrara were used side by side for portrait sculpture. It is additionally noticeable that the finer, more precious Parian lychintes was not necessarily preferred for the more prestigious Imperial portraits, but was used in this case for the herm portraits. This seems to corrolate well with the fact that Paroan lychnites was hard to quarry in large blocks whereas Paros II, Carrara and Dokeimion could be acquired in larger quantities.ô  104},
  note = {Werkstätten We believe that there was one or more local workshops, perhaps of immigrated Greel sculptors, working for this new large Hellenistic sanctuary and later for the Roman nouveaux riches who had theirs summer villas on the shore of the lake and on the slopes of the nearby Alban Hills. The portraits of the first half of the 1st cenurty A.D. are of such good quality that we can surmise the continuation of these workshops which still favourd marble from Paros and Dokeimion, but also used the local Carrara marble for full size portrait statues.  104 f},
  key = {Moltesen432}
}

  note = {Praeneste - Bildbeschreibung The upper part offers a picture of Aethiopia, i.e. that part of Africa that lies below the first cataract at Assuan, present-day Nubia and the Sudan. The accurately represented landscape depicts a large number of Sudanses animals, often with their names inscribed. The lower part is usually considered to be either a picture of the Nile valley form Assuan to the delta or simply a genre scene. [...] There is a temple for Osiris, presumably the one at Canopus, where the revival ritual of the corn-Osiris had taken place. There is the procession with the sarcophagus of Osiris, which is on its way to the funerary chapel in a sacred wood, th abaton. There is also a banquet of Ptolemaic soldiers which is about to begin.  052},
  note = {Nil Mosaik von Palestrina The Nile mosaic of Palestrina was neither part of the Fortuna sanctuary nor of a temple of Isis, as is often assumed. the so-called lower complex formed the town centre of ancient Praeneste. [...] The floor of the nymphaeum was decorated with a Nilotic scene, and water seeping through the porous stone of the mountain flowed over this mosaic.  054},
  note = {Ägyptische Heiligtümer in Latium Latium probably had the largest and most important temple of the Egyptian gods in Italy: the Iseum Campense on the Campus Martius in Rome. [...] Furthermore, the existence of sanctuaries is supposed in Osita, Portus, Nemi and Praeneste.  => 2x Hafen und 2x altes Heiligtum  309},
  note = {Funde in Praeneste A number of Egyptian and egyptianising objects have also been found in Praeneste. Most notable are an inscription for Sarapis from the second century AD, a statuette of Isis-Type from the third century AD, some fragments of two obelisks and the Nile mosaic (cat. no 006). The context of the Nile mosaic of Palestrain is sometimes interpreted as a sanctuary for Egyptian gods. There are however no indications for this; it probably concerns the basilica and curia of ancient Palestrina.  310},

  url = {},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {},
  edition = {},
  note = {Tempel der Monumentalisierung Diana's temple at Nemi, at the time when Vitruvius was writing c. 25 B.C., woul thus seem to have had a cella transverse to the pronaos, as Rosa's 1856 plan indeed appears to show. The type has been seen as a development from Hellenistic precedents within Latium in the 2nd and 1st centuries B.C., the period of large-scale replanning of Latin sanctuaries, including Nemi, where the terraced precinct is datable to the late 2nd century B.C.  88},
  note = {Ein einziges Model mit querliegender cella Even if the temple was rebuilt at the same time, which cannot be assumed, it may be asked whether the preceding structure might also have had a transverse cella. A factor in favour of that is the siting, which appears to have been significant in the choice of this form of arrangement for other temples of the type. [..] In the case of Nemi, the limitation os that of the ascending hillside behind the suggested site of the temple.  The possibility should therefore be considered whether both groups of model fragments, A and B as defined by Melis and Serra Ridgway, formed parts of a single more complex model of a temple with transverse cella, in which some of the B group constituted a taller and consequently broader central pronaos, with four facade columns and also columns between them and the cella, ad umeros pronai, and the pediments of the A group came from the two ends of teh cella, without columns.  88},
  key = {Blagg442}
}

We chose this spot partly because it had never been excavated before, and partly because it had not been used for the cultivation of flowers, like the rest of the area inside the Sanctuary.  179},
  note = {Rekonstruktion The pillar with the channel in front of it together with the discovery of the remains of a collapsed tiled roof between wall Q and row of pillars Z, suggests that between it and wall B there was an open corridor faced by the portico, and that it was covered by a layer of crushed tile laid in mortar (cocciopeso) which rested directly upon the bed-rock  180},
  note = {Repartur unter Hadrian The upper building had a tiled roof with cover tiles shich were found where they had fallen between the row of pillars R and the wall QQ'. The stamps on the tiles, which are not numerous, have confirmed that the roof and the restoration of the portico can be dated to the reign of Harian; the tiles have the stamps of the workshops Caniniae, Mercurio Felix, Sulpicianae, Tetellus Donatus, Sabina, T. Satilius Maximus and Severus Darianus.  180},
  note = {Aufbau des Portikus Three steps lead from the terrace to the colonnade, whose level corresponds to the bottom of the semicircular niches in BB'. 1.5m from the steps it has been possible with the aid of cleaning to expose a series of cuttings of nearly rectangular shape into the rock.... [..] it is conceivable that they have been used to accommodate machines to remove the rest of the portico's architecture... [..] A more attractive theory ist, however, that the holes are connected with activities in the Sanctuary in ancient times.  181},
  note = {Keramik The amount of pottery found in this area of the excavation is not particularly large and is very fragemented; a study of the material is still in process. A current examination shows that it belongs to the period from the 2nd century B.C. to the 2nd century A.D. ith the emphasis of the 1st century A.D.  181},
  note = {Untergang Stratigraphy has shown that after the area was abandoned, two incidences of destruction in quick succession were cause by the fall of the basalt and peperino blocks from the hillside above.  181},

@PhDThesis{Stek460,
  author = {Stek, Tesse D},
  title = {{Cult Places and Cultural Change in Republican Italy - A Contextual Approach to Religious Aspects of Rural Society After the Roman Conquest}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Entwicklung Gelesen Italisch NochMalLesen Priorität Religion Republik},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {Amsterdam},
  publisher = {Amsterdam Univ. Press},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {2009},
  month = {2008},
  pages = {X, 263},
  url = {},
  school = {Amsterdam},
  ISBN = {978-90-8964-177-9},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {P 372},
  note = {Methodik The main focus of this study is on the spatial and functional relation of cult places to other elements in the settlement organisation. This, information, I will argue, is essential for under standing their function in society at large.  005},
  note = {Untergang von Heiligtümern Whether or not Rome violently or legally suppressed Italic sanctuaries, there is general consensus that rural sanctuaries declined after the Social War. This is most often seen as a result of the urbanisation that was a feature for Roman municipalisation. Attention was focused on the new urban centres and it is there that most monumental buildings arise. The survival of Italic cult places would have depended on the extent of their integration in the new municipals structures. [..] The general idea, however, is that chances for survival of rural Italic sanctuaries into Roman times were small and this is an important undercurrent in modern cinceptions of the changing role of non-urban cult places in Italy during the last centuries BC.  Yet, in at least some cases Rome betrayed a special interest in ancient Italic sanctuaries, as can be seen in the legal statuses that were assigned to them after the Roman conquest. As has recently pointed out by Scheid, at least in the latter half of the first century BC and in the early empire, and not surprisingly in particular under Augustus, a strategy of incorporation of cult places can be discerned.  032},
  note = {Längere Restauration von Kulten According to Scheid, this policy was not exclusive to the Augustan period, with its well-known program of religious restoration. Augustus would rather have continued an earlier tradition in the treatment of symbolically important sanctuaries. [...] But it is certainly appealing to discern, with Scheid, a Roman habit of consciously appropriating some famous Italic cult places, by which these cult places, full of symbolic power, acquired an autonomous and by consequence Roman status.  033},
  note = {Anatomische Votive As to teh specific case of the anatomical votives, it has been shown by Gentili and Glinster that the idea that this type of votives would map teh level of religious romanisation of different parts of Italy is highly problematic. They can certainly not simply be used as an ''indicator'' of Roman or ''romanised'' people.  034},
  note = {Positionierung von Heiligtümern The transposition of the model to the less or non-urbanised Italic world is problematic, especially because the supposed Italic ethnic groups, and in particular their territorial manifestations, evade us. In any case, it is interesting that the few sanctuaries for which we have evidence pointing at a border position seem to have had an integrative rather than an exclusive function. A function as a central meeting place, also for commercial ends, seems therefore reasonable.  077},
  note = {Aufgabe der Heiligtümer nach den Bundesgenossen Krieg ''Romanistaion'' is seen as antithetic to this settlement pattern; municipalisation would have entailed the suppression of this Italic mode of living, although it sometimes shows a remarkable persistence. In this view, municipalisation would therefore also explain the abandonment of Italic sanctuaries after teh Social War. Exceptions to this rule are teh sanctuaries that fitted well into the new municipal organisation.  077},
  note = {Monumentalisierung eines kleineren Heiligtums More specifically, the sanctuary of S. Giovanni in Glado represents one of the best dated examples of cult places that were monumentalised at the end of teh second century or beginning of the first century BC. Coins under the pavement of the shrine date its construction to after 104 BC. It reflects the ground plan found in Temple B of Pietrabbondate... [...] As the small counterpart of the sanctuary complex at Pietrabbondaten and with its relatively well preserved remains, this sanctuary has almost come to constitute a canonical site when speaking of Italic or Samnite sanctuaries.  080 f},
  note = {Heiligtümern zur Kaiserzeit Once Italy was conquered, Roman attention shifted to other areas and we hear little or nothing about what happened subsequently to Italic sanctuaries and religion. The literary information we do have, from the early imperial period onwards, relates to a by then ''pacified'' peninsula. In particular in the Augustan period, Italian countryside religion is represented as rustic, pure and timeless. But what happend in the period between teh conquest and nostalgic romanticism?  213},
  note = {Votive kein Merkmal von Romanisierung For instance, the spread in Italy of anatomical votives has been seen as a direct result of teh pre-eminence of Roman culture and a similar case has been made for the Capitolium-style temples. However, evidence for this spread of Roman religious models as a consequence of their ''Superiority'' if problematic. Recent studies have questioned teh ''Roman'' character of anatomical votives, and Capitolia are actually less well attested for the early phases of colonies that is often assumed.  214},
  note = {Untergang durch Urbanisierung According to conventional understanding, the real Roman impact would have consisted of an emphasis on urban development, rather than on countryside cult places. This shift of attention would have led to the gradual abandonment of the latter.  214},
  note = {2. Jh. v. Chr. Selbstdarstellung In the second century BC evidence for religious expressions of communal pride abounds, for example in Samnium, and in Roman contexts Capitolia become prominent from the second century BC onwards. [..] Nonetheless, it appears that the expression of communal identities through religious aspects is especially important in this period and it is tempting to relate this to a general climate of change, competition and search for new self-definitions.  221},
  note = {Funktion von Heiligtümern I distinguish and critically examine three models, one which links cult places to transhumance routes, one which sees them as frontier markers, and one which sees them as an integral part of a specific, Italic, settlement organisation, the so-called pagus-vicus system. An important problem in the evaluation of these ideas is that htey are mostly based on an incomplete picture of the ancient ITalic landscapes.  6},
  key = {Stek460}
}

  note = {Erhalt von Religion Von einer wirklich individuellen religiösen Praxis in der Antike haben wir keine Zeugnisse, schon gar keine archäologischen, sondern eben nur von Kulten, die jeweils in einem wie auch immer gearteten sozialen Rahmen (Familie/Hausgemeinschaft, Vereine/Verbände, städtische/staatliche Institutionen) stattfinden. Was zuweilen als Dokument persönlicher Religionsübung angeführt wird, entspricht zumindest formal öffentlich oder kollektiv-überindividuellen Modellen. Man denke nur an Votivgaben, die mitunter zwar auf sehr persönliche Anliegen verweisen, aber gemäß einem standardisierten Formenrepertoire gestaltet wurden.  15},
  note = {Funktion von Kult An dieser Argumentation wird exemplarisch deutlich, daß der gemeinschaftliche Kult einen verbindlichen Zeichnsatz, gleichsam eine Sprache liefert, deren Gebrauch Zugehörigkeit zu der den Kult tragenden Gemeinschaft signalisiert. Partizipation ist gefordert - aber gerade nicht Konsens hinsichtlich einer expliziten Deutung der Riten.  15},

@Book{Weber465,
  author = {Weber, Max},
  title = {{Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft - Grundriß der verstehenden Soziologie}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Einführung Entwicklung Gelesen Religion Römisch},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {Tübingen},
  publisher = {Mohr},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {1976},
  month = {},
  pages = {XXXIII, 942 S ;},
  url = {http://www.gbv.de/dms/hebis-mainz/toc/004685008.pdf},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {3-16-533631-8 },
  edition = {5},
  LCCN = {ULB 4' 48/245 +5 #1},
  note = {Religion Eine Definition dessen, was Religion ''ist'', kann unmöglich an der Spitze, sonder könnte allenfalls am Schluss einer Erörterung wie der nachfolgenden stehen. Allein wir haben es überhaupt nicht mit dem ''Wesen'' der Religion, sondern mit den Bedingungen und Wirkungen einer bestimmten Art von Gemeinschaftshandel zu tun, dessen Verständnis auch hier nur von den subjektiven Erlebnissen, Vorsellungen, Zwecken der Einzelnen - vom ''Sinn'' - aus gewonnen werden kann, da der äußere Ablauf ein höchst vielgestaltiger ist. Religiös oder magisch motiviertes Handeln ist, in seinem urwüchsigen Bestande, diesseitig ausgerichtet. [...] Das religiöse oder ''magische'' Handeln oder Denken ist also gar nicht aus dem Kreise des alltäglichen Zweckhandelns auszusondern, zumal auch seine Zwecke selbst überwiegend ökonomisch sind.  245},
  note = {Beziehung Götter Menschen Wenn der Tote nur durch symbolische Handlung zugänglich ist und nur in Symbolen der Gott sich äußert, so kann er auch mit Symbolen statt mit Realitäten zufriedengestellt werden. Schaubrote, puppenbildliche Darstellungen der Weiber und der Dienerschaft treten an die Stell der wirklichen Opferung: das älteste Papipergeld diente nicht der Bezahlung von Lebenden, sondern von Toten.  248},
  note = {Religiöse Symbolik in der Kunst Die religiöse Stereotypierung der Produkte der bildenden Kunst als älteste Form der Stilbildung ist bedingt sowohl direkt durch magische Vorstellungen, als indirekt durch die im Gefolge der magischen Bedeutsamkeit des Produkts eintretende berufsmäßige Herstellung, welche schon an sich das Schaffen nach Vorlagen an die Stell des Schaffens nach dem Naturobjekt setzt.  249},
  note = {Kult Wirklich sicher aber wird diese abstrakte Vorstellung erst durch ein kontinuierlich einem und demselben Gott gewidtmetes Tun, den ''Kultues'', und durch sein Verbindung mit einem kontinuierichen Verband von Menschen, eine Dauergemeinschaft, für die er als Dauernedes solche Bedeutung hat.  250},
  note = {Römische Religion Die Kompetenzen der römischen numina sind ungleich fester und eindeutiger abgegrenzt als die der hellenischen Göttergestalten; dagegen ist die Vermenschlichung und plastische Veranschaulichung der letzteren als eigentlicher ''Persönlichkeiten'' ungleich weitergegangen als in der genuinen römischen Religion. Der wesentlichste soziologische Grund liegt in diesem Fall darin, daß die genuine römische Vorstellung vom Übersinnlichen in ihrer allgemeien Struktur weit stärker die einer nationalen Bauern- und Patrimonialherrenreligion geblieben war, die hellenische dagegen der Entwicklung zu einer interlokallen Ritterkultur wie der des homerischen Zeitalters mit ihren Heldengöttern ausgesetzt wurde.  250},
  note = {Definition römischer Religion durch das Wort Die römische Religion blieb ''religio'', d.h., einerlei ob dieses Wort etymologisch von religare oder von relegere abzuleiten ist: Gebundenheit an die erprobte kultische Formel und ''Rücksichtnahme'' auf die überall im Spiel befindlichen numina aller Art.  250},
  note = {Genius des Kaisers Im zweiten Fall ist die Konsequenz, daß die Ahnen, numina, genii oder persönliche Götter jenes mächtigsten Haushalts neben die Hausgötter der Untertanenhaushalte treten und die Stellung des Herrschers sakral legitimieren. [..] Die sakrale Rolle des ''genius'' des römischen Princeps sollte, mit der dadurch bedingten universellen Aufnahme der kaiserlichen Person in den Laraienkult, Ähnliches leisten.  253},
  note = {Spezial Götter für Verbände Im Gegenteil hat in aller Regel jeder politische Dauerverband seinen Spezialgott, der den Erfolg des politischen Verbandshandelns verbürgt. Er ist bei voller Entwicklung durchaus exkulsiv nach außen.  253},
  note = {Götter in Verbänden Ideengeschichtlich ist diese Auffassung des Verbandes als lokalen Kultträgers ein Zwischenglied zwischen der rein patrimonialen Betrachtung des politischen Gemeinschaftshandelns und dem rein sachlichen Zweckverbands- und Anstaltsgedanken etwa der modernene ''Gebietskörperschafts''-Idee.  254},
  note = {Bedeutung von Opfern Noch wichtiger und warhscheinlich auch älter ist aber das andere Motiv: das Opfer, speziell das Tieropfer, soll eine ''communio'', eine als Verbrüderung wirkende Tischgemeinschaft zwischen den Opfernden und dem Gott herstellen: eine Bedeutungswanldung der noch älteren Vorstellung, daß das Zerreißen und Essen eines starken, später eines heiligen, Tieres dessen Kraft den Essenden mitteile..  258},
  note = {Zweck von Religion und religiösem Handeln Abwendung ''diesseitigen'' äußerlichen Übels und Zuwendung ''diesseitiger'' äußerlicher Vorteile ist der Inhalt aller normalen ''Gebete'', auch der aller jenseitigsten Religionen.  259},
  note = {Definitionen Man kann diejenigen Formen der Beziehungen zu den übersinnlichen Gewalten, die sich als Bitte, Opfer, Verrehung äußern, als ''Religion'' und ''Kultus'' von der ''Zauberei'' als dem magischen Zwange scheiden und dementsprechend als ''Götter'' diejenigen Wesen bezeichnen, welche religiös verehrt und gebeten, als ''Dämonen'' diejenigen, welche magisch, gezwungen und gebannt werden. Die Scheidung ist fast nirgends restlos durchführbar, denn auch das Ritual des in diesem Sinn ''religiösen'' Kultus enthält fast überall massenhafte magische Bestandteile.  259},
  key = {Weber465}
}

  author = {Scullard, Howard Hayes},
  title = {{Römische Feste - Kalender und Kult}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Einführung Entwicklung Gelesen Geschichte Religion Römisch},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},

  volume = {25},

  LCCN = {},

  url = {},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {3-8053-0555-9},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {P 1567/40a},
  note = {votum Eine andere Möglichkeit, die Aufmerksamheit der Götter auf sich zu ziehen, war das mehr formelhafte Gelübde (votum). Wenn Gelübde auch häufig in einem legalistischen Text abgefaßt sind, bedeutet das nicht, daß sie beide Parteien verpflichten, sondern es handelt sich um Gebete, die im Falle einer Erhörung Opfer versprechen.  35},
  note = {Auspicien in der späten Republik Obwohl die Auspicien oft zur reinen Formalität oder zu einer Waffe im politische Ränkespiel geworden waren, glaubten um die Zeit der späten Republik viele gebildetet Männer, einschließlich Augustus an sie...  38},
  note = {Definition von Glaube In der Tat war der Glaube sekundär, wichtiger war, was man tat, wenn auch nur im Sinne der Einhaltung von Riten. Ein besonderer ethischer Kodex war nicht damit verbunden, lediglich auf die pedantisch genaue Durchführung bestimmter ritueller Hanldungen durch den Einzelnen oder durch den Staat kam es an. Die Mehrheit der Beteiligten hatte vermutlich eine völlig undifferenzierte Einstellung bezüglich der Wirksamkeit eines solchen Gehabes. [...] ...so gelingt es uns doch nur mühsam, die Anschauungen des 'Mannes auf der Straße' zu erfassen. Wahrscheinlich akzeptierte er überkommenes Brauchtum, ohne viel darüber nachzudenken, während einzelne vielleicht Gedanken hegten, die von vernichtender und verächtlicher Kritik bis zu leichtgläubigem Aberglauben reichen mochten.  47},
  note = {Religion in Stadt und Land So klaffent in den späteren Jahrhunderten der Republik Stadt und Land, wo nach wie vor ältere Traditionen blühten, weit auseinander, was nicht bedeutet, daß alle nostalgischen Sehsüchte der römischen Dichter nach den einfachen ländlichen Sitten einer entschwundenen Vergangenheit angehörten; denn vieles von der alten Überlieferung schleppte sich noch hin, und die Landbevölkerung hätte sich bestimmt nicht träumen lassen, dass Jahrhunderte später das Christenum einen seiner härtesten Kämpfe auszufechten haben würde.  47 f},
  note = {Glauben um der Tradition willen Später (3.9) äußert Cotta, daß er bereit sei, die Lehre von der Existenz der Götter zu akzeptieren, einfach weil die Tradition es so wolle (ita nobis maiores nostros tradidisse), ein weiteres Argument erübrige sich.   52},
  note = {Glaube der einfachen Leute Leider dringt jedoch die Stimme des einfachen Römers selten bis zu uns vor, daher sind wir in religiöser Hinsicht besser über das unterrichtet, was er tat, als über das, was er dachte. Die meisten Römer hatten wahrscheinlich die unbestimmte Vorstelung, daß die Götter auf eine anständigen Lebenswandel Wert legten und daß bestimmte Vergehen, wie zum Beispiel Inzest, sie beleidigte, doch im Gegensatz zur jüdisch und christlichen Religion lehre die römische Religion keine pernsöliche Moral. Wenn ein römischer Adeliger einer vergöttlichten Tugend wie Fides oder Pietas einen Tempel baute, wird er vermutlich erklärt haben, daß dies eine vom ethischen Standpunkt erstrebenswerte Tat sei, doch die Vermutung, daß seine eigene persönliche Ehre und die seiner Famlie ein ebenso ausschlaggebendes Motiv waren, dürfte auch nicht allzu abwegig sein. Ganz allgemein gesprochen waren persönliche Moral und öffentliche Religion zwei getrennte Dinge.  56},
  key = {Scullard466}
}

  LCCN = {P 725/80},
  note = {Fortuna Primigenia hat widersprüchlichen Mythos At what stage did Rome lose its mythology? [...] In any case, it was certainly hastened and completed by the invasion of Greek mythology, which was much richer and much more prestigious. [...] Had the other Latin peoples also lost their mythology? Had their divinities become as meacoated , as abstract, as those of Rome? A few rare indications suggest that certain ones had been less radically so. The Fortuna Primigenia of Praeneste, in the enigmatical conflict which defines her, is portrayed as being at the same time primordial, primigenia, and, contradictorily the daughter of Jupiter, puer Jouis. As this conflict seems to be fundamental (it recalls a Vedic theologem on the same level), we are tempted to admit that the connection with Jupiter is an ancient one.   055},
  note = {Frühes Rom hat Mythen If it has been proved that Rome of the eighth century knew more mythology than the Rome of the third century, one must still realize that for lack of poets,  and in contrast with Greece, this mythology was not literary or exposed to the temptations of literature, but rather was restricted to useful functions and ''glued'' to ritual.  056},
  note = {Mythen selten komplett verloren This kind of almost completely demythologized religion, surviving only in rites whose mythological and even theological justifications haven been forgotten, is seldom found in other parts of the Indo-European world.  058},
  note = {Indo-Germanische Einflüsse The comparative study of the most ancient documents from India, Iran, Rome, Scandinavia, and Ireland has allowed us to give it a content and to recognize a great number of facts about civilization, and especially religion, which were common to these diverse societies or at least to several of them. Many of these agreement,such as the one which has just been summed up concerning Dawn, are so singular that they cannot be interpreted otherwise than as the heritage of Indo-European conceptions. Several also are interdependent, complementing and articulating one another in such a way that it is not a inorganic dusting of more or less considerable concordances which we find but entire structures of representations.  061},
  note = {Archäologische Befunde Moreover, the data which are used are almost exclusively archaeological, a fact which allows, as we know, the most generous interpretations.  062},
  note = {Gründung von Praeneste At Praeneste the legend of the founder Caeculus recalls in certain respects that of the founder Romulus, but the pair of brothers, either twins or equivalent to twins, is set in another generation: they are his uncles. [...] After spending this youth among the shepherds, he formed a band of boys of his own age and founded Praeneste.  Quelle: 	Servius, Ane, 7, 678 	Schol. Veron. in Verg. Aen. 7, 681 	Solin. 2,9  253},
  note = {Schäfer als Gründerkonzept in Latium geläufig Thus we may conceive that the primitive mythology of the Latin peoples was familar with a pair of shepherd brothers, probably twins and gods, but living among men, who the ''histories'' of the origins of the various cities have variously used - in other words, a type homologous to that of the Vedic Nasatya. If at Rome the idea of a ''demigod'' seems to show Greek influence, the less specific idea of diui, at Praeneste, may preserve a genuine Latin conception.  253},
  note = {Gründer von Praeneste ..celebrated accident of Caecilius Metellus in 241 bears a strong resemblance to what is told about Volcanus's son Caeculus, the legendary acestorof the gens Caecilia and the mythical founder of the Latin city of Praeneste. This hero had been concieved near the hearth, that is, in Vesta's domestic abode, and as a result of the smoke his eyes had remained smaller than is normal.  325},
  note = {Ursprung von Fortuna latinisch The origins of Fortuna are unknown. If it is admitted in general that she came to Rome from other points of Latium, this is because in fact ancient cults of the goddess, more prestigious than those of Rome, existed ar Praeneste and Antiu, of which at least the former influenced the Roman cults.  423},

  note = {Dina  Dort lag in Aricia ein Heiligtum der Göttin, das einmal Zentrum eines Bundes latinischer Städte gewesen war. Der Dictator Laevius Egerius hatte nach Cato (Orig. frg. 58 P.) dort die Bundesurkunde aufgestellt, die von den Mitgliedern Tusculum, Aricia, Lanuvium, Laurentum, Cora, Tibur, Pometia und Ardea gemeinsam geweiht war. Als der Bund in dem von Rom geleiteten aufging, hat man die Bundesgöttin nach Rom gezogen und ihr auf dem Aventin ein Heiligtum erbaut, das zunächst noch in einem Altar in einem Hain bestand.  169},

Ein rex sacorum, ursprünglich der Gemeinde Aricia gehörig, mag später, als er dort bedeutungslos wurde, zum Wächter des heiligen Haines degradiert und der Zweikampf erst nachträglich hinzugetreten sein, als man schließlich Sklaven dafür verwendete und damit das Priestertum eine Zuflucht für den Träger wurde.  172},

  LCCN = {ULB 2006/7265},
  note = {''Religion'' als System nicht vorhanden Even the concept of ''a religion'' does not seem to have been part of traditional Graeco-Roman culture, although it perhaps began to develop in the second century CE.  013},
  note = {religio Its primary connotation seems broadly to have been ''an obligation with respect to the divine'', often with the negative force of ''prohibition or scruple,'' but sometimes with the positive sense of ''prescribed ritual or customary practice'' [...] Writers of the second century CE and later come increasingly to use religio to mean the worship of a particular deity, stressing belief and commitment to way of life.  013 f},
  note = {Religion ''a religion'', that is, ''a distinct and broady coherent system of beliefs and practices''  014},
  note = {Beinamen Juno Lucina, the goddess of childbirth, was quite different form the martial Juno Sospita, with her goatskin cloak and her spear and shield. The purpose of the supplementary names ''Lucina'' and ''Sospita'' was to specify which version of Juno a worshipper had in mind. Supplementary names of this sort, usually called ''epithes'', are very common in dedications...  015},
  note = {Objekte als ''Götter'' Votive dedications to the Sun and teh Moon, to Heaven and Earth, and to Storms and Winds indicate that people actually invoked these deities in prayer and believed that they responded.  Quelle (Bsp) 	Horaz, Odes 3, 13 	ILS 3385 (Altar für göttliche Quelle => Nymphe?)  016},
  note = {Personifikationen verehrt The worship of such abstractions goes back to an early period in Greek history, and was by the imperial period very well established. In the second century CE, the travel writer Pausanias reported that the Athenias had public altars dedicated to Eleos (Mercy), Aidos (Respectfulness), Pheme (Rumor), and Horme (Impuse). Similary, in the city of Rome, there were public temples to Spes (Hope), Pietas (Piety), Concordia (Concord), Victoria (Victory) and Fides (Good Faith), among others. Although it might seem that cults like these were sheer propaganda, attempts to promote virtues conducive to the public good, all these deities and others like them were also the recipients of votive dedications.  017},
  note = {numen Definition The Latin word numen meant ''divine power'' or ''divine will''. Some writers used it almost as a synonym for deus, especially when referring to a deity whose existence was perceived but whose specific identity remained uncertain. In the imperial period, the word was also applied to the godlike aspect of the Roman emperor;  019},
  note = {genius Definition Genius originally designated teh divine later-ego or guardian spirit of an individual person (usually male: the genius of a woman was often distinguished as a iuno). Over time, people began to use  the word more widely, and attribute a genius to virtually any locality or institution. [...] But it is perhaps more helpful to think that concepts like that of the genius allowed people to feel that every aspect of their day-to-day lives was in some way represented on the divine plane.  019},
  note = {manes The Romans actually referred to the dead as gods, the di manes; the etymology of the name manes remains uncertain, although it may have been a euphemistic title derived from the archaic adjective manus, meaning ''good''.v  019},
  note = {divus und deus This is simply one indication that hile Roman emperors and other rulers were often regarded as gods, they were gods of a particular sort  020},
  note = {Kaiser braucht keine Votive But it would be better to conclude that emperors were simply not divinities of the sort invoked in vows.  021},
  note = {Mythen und Philosophie koexistieren Yet even so he [Anm. Varro] considers myth as suitable for literature and popular entertainment, upholds the traditional religious institutions of Rome, and says that the speculations of philosophers are better within the walls of schools than in public squares. In other words, Varro was evidently not worried about consistency: although myths and civic religious insitutions might be ''wrong'' from a philosophical point of view, they wer not to be rejected for that reason, but remained appropriate enough within their own spheres.  022},
  note = {Widersprüchliche ''Theologie'' kein Problem  023},
  note = {Gabenaustausch charakterisitsch First, since the formal exchange of beenfits was something that characterized a wide range of social relationships in the Graeco-Roman world. it is not suprising that it also helped structure relationships between mortals and immortals.  024},
  note = {Kult überall, aber nicht definiert In short, cult practices were a pervasive part of everyday life. Secondly, cult represented a conception of the divine world that was enacted in a set of practices, not codified in a set of beliefs. [...] Cult practices were not the expression of a formalized doctrinal system, but were instead a self-sufficient approach to the divine. At the same time, cult did not constitute the whole of religion as I defined it above, but was simply one of several approaches to the divine that coexisted in Graeco-Roman tradition.  027},
  note = {Mythos ist keine ''Instanz'' Myth was in origin a fluid oral tradition, and there was never any move to establish a particular set of myths as distinctively authoritative or true. Although poets at times claimed divine inspiration, people never regarded their works as ''the word of God'' in the way that Jews traditionally regard the Torah and Christians the Bible.  028},
  note = {Mythos und Kult getrennt the myth was not so much a part of the ritual as a gloss on it. In short, although cult practices might incorporate myths and myths might comment on cult practices, myth and cult remained in essence two separate things. [..] For all these reasons it is highly misleading to regard myth as the core of Graeco-Roman religion...  029},
  note = {Guten Mythen Kenntnis At least in urban areas, then, it seems likely that some knowledge of traditional Graeco-Roman myth was fairly widespread. Likewise, the fact that the educated classes criticized and satirized traditional myths does not mean that they regarded them as unimportant.  030},
  note = {Antike Auffassung von Mythen Some people used a historical key, arguing that the gods of myth were in origin early kings and heroes, whose deeds were exaggerated as tehy were retold over the centuries; this strategy is known as Euhemerism, after the fourth-century BCE writer Euhemerus, who first applied it systematically. Others suggested that myths were not stories about the true gods, whom they regarded as above human emotions and incapable of wickedness, but about daimones, who wer thought to have superhuman powers but human failings. But the most common strategy was to treat myths as allegories, in which the gods and their deeds were symbolic representations of philosophical truths; [...] Myth, then, was an old and well-establisehd way of thinking about the divine world, and remained an integral part of Graeco-Roman culture.  031},
  note = {Jedes Götterbild kann Kultbild sein First, any image of a deity was potentially, if not actually, an object of devotion. We know, for example, that statuettes of gods were sometimes cult objects and not simply objets d'art. [...] In view of such stories, we sould be very cautious in assuming a clear-cut- distinction between ''religious'' and ''decorative'' images of gods. Instead, the cultic potential of a divine image was always present and perceived as a kind of subtext.  035 f},
  note = {Bild wichtig für Ungebildetet In a society where illiteracy rates were by modern standard unimaginably high, images of the gods played a crucial part in shaping people's understanding of the divine world. We can make some guesses about the ideas that they propagated: taht the divine was in some sense understandable and approachable because it was so similar to the human, yet also involved a degree of perfection and power beyond that of ordinary mortals.  036},
  note = {Keine feste ''Religion'' mehrer ''Theologien'' Most people in the Graeco-Roman tradition, however, seem to have thought instead in terms of multiple ''theologies,'' in which cult, myth (togehter with art), and philisophy constituted separate modes of thinking about the divine, modes that interacted in various ways but remained essentially independent. [...] The Graeco-Roman religious tradition was instead constituted by this entire set of largely separate, sometimes contradictory, yet equally important approaches to the divine.  042},
  note = {Priester nicht nötig - keine ''Klasse'' oder ''Stand'' The first is that people were to a very large extent in charge of their own religious lives and had no need of religious specialists. [...] A priestly class of this sort [Anm. mittelalterliche Priester] did not exist in the Graeco-Roman tradition. The basic cult practices that I sketched above - prayer, sacrifice, and to some extent divination -were open to all, so that people generally had no need of any third party to mediate between them and the gods.  043},
  note = {Korrektheit der Durchführung der Ritual entscheidend Their [Anm. Priester und Magistrate] chief responsibilty was to ensure that the prescribed public rituals were performed as tehy were supposed to be performed, although in some cases they could also be consulted by individual citizens on points of ritual.  045},
  note = {Opfer, gezeigte Ritual wichtiger als ''Glaube''  049},
  note = {Athena und Amman gleichzeitig verehrt in an inscribed potsherd from Egypt ''Claudius Silvanus and his brothers to mistress Athena against Longinus Marcus. Since Longinus - again whom we have often appealed to you because he was after our lives while we did no wrong, poor as we are - while he wins nothing with this, he still continues to be malicious against us, we beg you to do justice. We have already asked Ammon for help as well''  Quelle: 	C. A.  Faraone, Magika Hiera. Ancient Greek magic and religion  	(New York 1991), 72  051},
  note = {Flexibles Glaubenssystem there was no one unified and coherent set of beliefs and principles, no sacred scriptures, no priestly class, and no associated moral code. Instead of ''a religion'', we can more usefuly think of it as a group of loosely related but largely distinct ways of thinking about and interacting with the divine world. This fluid and open organization allowed people to maintain simultaneous beliefs and practices that we might regard as inconsistent with one another and even mutually contradictory.  052},
  note = {Hauptgötter Role in der Stadt In their different was, both these rituals functioned to define and reinforce the civic and religious identity of the populace. The processions physicially and visually tied teh temple of teh chief deity to key public spaces in the city. In the Panathenaia, the participation of representative groups in the procession and the elaborate formula for the distribution of the sacrificial meat symbolically united the entire citizen body in the worship of its patron goddess while at the same time affirming the distinct social roles that the different parts of the population were supposed to play. [..] In addition to shaping civic identity, public cults also played a part in articulating social hierachies.   114},
  note = {Kaum Unterschied zwischen öffentlich und privat It would be misleading to see household cults and civic cults as an opposition of ''private'' and ''public'': although they existed in different spheres, there were significant links between them. At the same time, they did not fit together into a seamless and all-embracing system. Just as individuals could pursue their own religious interests with little or not interference from public authorities, so too could households worship whatever deities they liked.  121},
  note = {Kultteilnahme und sozialer Status To belong to a community in the Graeco-Roman world meant to worship the deities of that community and to participate in its rituals, especially sacrifice and the accompanying meal. [..] Similarly, freedmen, who were also excluded from politicla office, might become Augustales, a formal civic rank common especially in the western empire that seems to have been connected with the worship of the emperor. If public cult offered opportunities for women and freedmen to acquire and display social status, voluntary associations offered even more.  128},
  note = {Mitglied in meherern kultischen Gruppen In terms of group identity, the fact that worship of one deity did not preclude the worship of others meant that it was possible for people to belong simultaneously to a number of different groups. In some cases their group identities could be mutually reinforcing.  129},
  note = {Primär lokale Adoranten While travel for religious purposes must have been fairly common, the bulk of it was no doubt local or regional, simply because healing shrines and festivals existed throughout the empire, and there was no need to travel great distances in order to enjoy their benefits. But as we have seen, there was a certain amount of long-distance travel as well.  136},
  note = {Stellung des Kaisers ''Gottgleich'' the emperor was the concrete embodiment of what was otherwise an almost unimaginable abstraction. Although it would be accurate to say that the emperor symbolized the unity of the empire, he was in fact much more that a symbol. As the supreme commander of the imperial army and the center of the imperial bureaucracy, he directly controlled those aspects of imperial power that most people were likely to encounter. He was also at the peak of the social hierarchy, the culmination of the complex network of patronage mentioned in the previous chapter: the emperor was the only person in the empire who could bestow benefits on everyone without himself receiving benefits from anyone. In a very important sense, then, the emperor was the empire.  148 f},
  note = {Opfer für divi und genius der Kaiser The Feriale Duranum, for example, the festival calendar of the Roman army from the third century CE, marks the anniversaries for deified emperors with sacrifices to those emperors themselves, but marks those of the current emperor with sacrifices either to the emperor's genius or to traditional deities like the Capitoline Triad.  150},
  note = {''Kaiserkult'' frei von Regeln Public cults of the emperor also existed in cities throughout the empire, with shrines, public priests, and a regular schedule of ceremonies. [..] Although it was not necessary to obtain imperial permission for civic cults of the emperor, any more than it was for other public cults, an official endorsement brought prestige.  151},
  note = {Kaiser omni präsent Cult was not the only medium for expressing the religious role of the emperor. Images of the emperor, for example, like those of the gods, were omnipresent, ranging from larger-than-life statues in public spaces to small figures in private residences to images on coins, And like the images of the gods, their constant presence helped to shape people's sens of who they were.  152},
  note = {Spiel mit Kaiser-Gott Angleichung Yet even so the implications are ambiguous: one person might interpret the image to mean that Claudius was the actual embodiment of Jupiter, some else, that he was a representative of Jupiter; someone else, that he was merely like Jupiter. Adding to the ambiguity is the one key difference between the images of Claudius and Jupiter: where  Jupiter holds a lightning bolt, Claudius holds a dish of the sort used to offer libations.  153},
  note = {Kaiser - Gott und Mensch zugleich The emperor was in a sense both divine and human, so that one's perspective in specific circumstances determined which aspect came into focus.  153},
  note = {Kaiser hat realen Einfluss auf Menschen Leben It was the emperor who ensured the peace, security, and prosperity of the empire; in this respect he was like a god for the people of the empire, since the ability to bestow benefits was a defining characteristic of the gods. In acting as a unique intermediary between the divine and mortal spheres, therefore, the emperor to some extent participated in both.  155},
  note = {Trenner und Binder ist Religion religion was as much a force for integration within the Roman Empire as it was an expression of its diversity.  156},
  note = {Eingriff in Kulte ehr selten In some cases, as in Asia Minor, they apparently encouraged the transformation or incorporation of traditional temple states into more familiar Graeco-Roman civic cults; elsewhere, as in Egypt and, at least initially, in Judaea, Roman authorities upheld the traditional roles of the priests, while subjecting them to increasing regulation and control. In yet other cases, the took the more drastic step of eradicating traditional structures of religious authority altogether, as they did with the Druids. This last response was the least common; most of the time, Roman officials apparently preferred to exert more indirect pressures in order to reshape traditional societies in accordance with their expectations.  187},
  note = {Verbot von Wahrsagung Already in 12 BCE the emperor Augustus collected more than 2,000 prophetic texts in Greek and Latin and had them burned, Towards the end of this reign, ''seers were forbidden to make predictions in private or to make predictions about death even if others were present''. A few years later, early in the reign of Tiberius, a young Roman nobleman named Libo Drusus was accused of plotting to win imperial power for himself and of consulting various astrologers, magi, and dream-interpreters about his prospects; in the wake of his trial the Senate issued a decree condemning all freelance diviners of this sort.  Quellen: 	Sueton, Augustus, 31, 1 	Cassius Dio, Geschichte, 56, 25, 5 	Tacitus, Annalen, 2, 27-32 => Praeneste Orkale Verbot  189},
  note = {Richtig und falsches relgiöses Verhalten definiert The limited aims of Roman rule menat that Roman officials had no formal mandate to monitor and regulate the religious beliefs and activities of the people over whom they ruled. Yet we should not mistake this general laissez-faire attitude for an active policy of religious toleration and respect for diversity. On the contrary, the imperial elite shared a number of definite if not clearly articulated assumptions about what constituted proper and improper religious behavior.  200},
  note = {Kaiserkult hat keinen Einfluss auf andere Kulte at no point did worship of the emperor effectively replace the cults of traditional deities. As we have seen, the latter continued to flourish, and indeed provided the larger ritual framework within which the emperor was accommodated.  203},
  note = {Kein Rückgang alter Kulte It has sometimes been proposed that during the imperial period private cult associations of this sort gradually came to replace public cults as the focus of people's religious lives. Although there does seem to have been an increase in the number and variety of such associations, this was again more a change in degree, since cults groups of one sort or another seem always to have existed in the Graeco-Roman tradition. Moreover, it is difficult to demonstrate any real decline in the importance of public cults; if anything, we can perhaps in the third century trace a kind of streamlining, whereby greater attention was focused on fewer cults.  204},
  note = {Religion nicht konstant The concept of ''religion'' now current is not an immutable one, representing an unchanging element of human culture in all times and places. Like many of the other conceptual categories that shape our understanding of the world, it is instead the product of specific historical developments; as such, it has changed and evolved over time, and will no doubt continue to do so in the future.  209},
  key = {Rives480}
}

  note = {Nemi The first structures we can observe in the villa are were connected with the sanctuary and teh regulation of the lake, not with the villa itaself.  13},
  note = {Monumentalisierung In connection with the phase of monumentalzing the sanctuary with grand terraces in opus caementicium, which took place in the last quarter of the 2nd century BC, an embankment reinforcing the banks of the lake was constructed of huge wooden ''boxes'' filled with opus caementicium. This embankment provided the physical framework for the coming villa`s construction.  14},
  note = {Bauphasen der Villa The excavation have made it clear that the villa had four main phases:  Phase 1, Late Republican, mid-1st century BC Phase 2, Early Imperial, ca. AD 20-40 Phase 3, Late Neronian-Early Flavian, AD 60-80 Phase 4, Hadrianic, 120s AD The villa was presumably abandoned because of a natural catastrophe around AD 150, used a quarry for buildings materials, and finally completely abandoned roughly a quarter of a century later. [...] The villa seems to be a pure otium villa. No production unit has been located and it is almost certain that none such ever existed.  14},
  note = {Ceasar als Besitzer der Villa Elsewhere  I have argued the case that the first villa was C. Iulius Caesar`s villa in nemore or in nemorensi, that is in Diana`s Sacred Wood (Cicero, Att. 6.1.25; Suetonius, Iul, 46). I will not repeat eh arguments here. Notwithstanding its identification it is beyond doubt that the villa was very sumptuous and remained of high standard in its furnishings until it was abandoned in the mid 2nd century AD. It is important to note that there is a close correspondence between building activities in the villa and in the sanctuary, and it its likely that the patron of the villa was also involved in the activities in the sanctuary.  17},
  note = {Amphoren stempel auch im Schiff It should be noted, that in the First Nemi Ship, another variant of the Postumius stamp, not present in our material, was found in five examples, and Blich dated these to 40s of the 1st century AD.  449},

  shorttitle = {},
