  note = {Roms Mach im 6-7 Jh. begrenzt This evidence implies that the sphere of Roman influence was narrowly delimited within central Latium in the seventh and the earlier part of the sixth century;.. [...] Rome had still to make contact with the larger and remoter units of Latium; for it is not possible to believe that Tibur and Praeneste did not exists at this period as comparatively large states, although it is certain that the villages only passed gradually under the sway of the greater powers. At the very end of the period Gabii, as an independent community, was too strong for Rome to swallow up and merge completely in herself.   010},
  note = {Latinische Liga von Aricia Whether or not this league, at this particular moment of its development, represented a political group is less certain. [...] This considerations should dispose of the view that the league of Aricia was a separate organization from the Council of Ferentina, set up as a counter-body when Superbus gained control of the latter. Such a view, in any case, does not agree with the chronological indications of Cato.  013},
  note = {Viele verschiedene Bünde It is thus possible to maintain that by the middle of the sixth century the cult-centers, thought still primarily religious, were capable of acquiring political importance. At what date the league of Aricia first assumed such importance remains uncertain. All that can be said is that in the period which preceded teh Etruscan domination of Rome latium was composed of a number of crossing and interrelated groups, some small and local, other tending to become complex and politically self-conscious. The big city-states were undoubtedly emerging, but the period of sedentary tribe was perhaps not very remote. It is improbable that at this period there existed any single political group which embraced all the populi of Latium; [...] It was extremely important for the history of the Latin people that they retained down to a late period in their development as city-states the practice of these intercommunal festivities and councils, and that the memory of the pre-urban, tribal organization of Latium was thus kept alive.  014},
  note = {Etruskische Vorherrschaft When the Etruscan kings disappear the peoples of Latium, the Latin Name, seem to enjoy a greater degree of federal unity than in the earlier period, and Rome in particular emerges as the head of a considerable league of Latin states. [...] It remains to decide what precisely were the limits of the Etruscan hegemony in Latium  017},
  note = {Sonderstellung Gabiis in der Fürhzeit The detailed account of the relations between Rome and Gabii in the time of Superbus illustrates the process of direct absorption. Gabii was a small community situated to the west of the group of Prisci Latini with which Rome had hitherto been mainly occupied. Livy and Dionysius, after mentioning certain attempts of Superbus to secure the submission of Gabii by violence, agree in the noteworthy statement that it eventually entered the Roman state unforced. According to Dionysius this entry was mediated by a treaty, which gave to the Gabini the enjoyment of their own city and lands, together with 'isopolity'. [...] There is confirmatory evidence, in the special use of the cinctus Gabinus, the Gabine robe and in the peculiar condition of Gabine land, to show that Gabii at an early date possessed an extraordinary position in relation to the Roman state; for ager Gabinus was juridically distinct from both ager Romanus and ager peregrinus, and the cinctus Gabinus was worn by Roman officals as a sacred vestment for certain solemnities.  019},
  note = {Äußere Feinde als Anlass für Bündniss But in the fifth century a fesh danger appeared with the advance of teh Volsci into the hills to the south-east Latium, their seizure of certain strongholds such as Velitrae, and their influx into the coastal plains as fas as Antium. This threat was contributory motive in the formation of the alliances between Rome and the other latin peoples known as the Cassian treaty, even as a little later the advance of the Aequi was compelling cause in the extension of the Latin federation to the Hernci.  021},
  note = {Hegemonie keine Dominaz The difficulties that have been raised over the two treaties ascribed to Spurius Cassius are largely due to the habit of regarding them as the Roman historian wish us to regard them - as teh assertion of Roman suzerainty over recalcitrant allies, rather than as teh acceptance of the hegemony of the greatest state in Latin by the others, at a time whein their own existence was seriously threatened.  021},
  note = {Interesse Roms und der Latiner an Bündiss Nomentum, Pedum, Tibur, Praeneste, Tusculum above all, Aricai, Lanuvium, Ardea - these formed a wall of comparative security around Rome. [...] The interest of the Latins equally lay in gaining Roman aid, to save themselves from the raiders. On these presuppositions the Cassian treaty can be accepted as part of the genuine tradition, set at its traditional date, despite the dubious character of other stories that have attached themselves to the name of its alleged mediator. [...] The treaty establishes peace between the Latin cities and Rome, but not between the Latins themselves, and it provides for a defensive alliance on equal terms in case of attack from without Latium, and for the division of spoils of war.  022},
  note = {Schleichende Dominaz Roms It became a institutum for the Latin cities to send their soldiery each year to the city of their great ally. Now institutum is not a technical term of constitutional right, but a designation for a practice which could be, and on Livy's admission was, broken.  025},
  note = {Herniker schwächen latinische Position .. the alliance with the Hernici. The introduction of a non-Latin people meant that the conduct of communal affairs could no longer be entirely directed by the council at Lucus Ferentinae, which was essentially a Latin tribal gathering, whose function was to appoint the praetores Latini. [...] It marks Rome's first adventure beyond the narrow limits of Latium, and it fixes the moment when Rome became more definitely the military focus of Latium that united a double federation of Latini and Hernici.  026},
  note = {Sonderstatus von Aricia The addition to this lost of a foedus Aricinum, however, cannot be established by Cicero's reference to the municipium of Aricia in his day as iure foederatum. Some confirmation might perhaps be found in the fact that, in Livy's narrative, the Romans rushed to rescue Aricia from teh grip of the Aurunci in the period after the battle of lake Regillus and before the conclusion of the Cassian treaty. Rome was certainly especially interested in Aricia, not only in the regal, but also in the early republican period. If the suggestion of a foedus Aricinum can be accepted, the most that the three instances of special treaties, Ardea, Lavinium, and Aricia, would suggest is taht the Roman Republic was simply resuming the policy of the last of the Kings, who seem to have sought to combine a limited series of local alliances with a general confederation with the rest of Latium  027 f},
  note = {Sonderstellung Praeneste und Tibur  It is characteristic that the two peoples of whom most is heard in the fourth century, Tibur and Praeneste, are conspicuous by their absence from the records of the fifth. This means simply that the Cassian treaty satisfied the needs of these powers ,and that neither party desired ampler arrangements. [...] Dionysius refers to a federal war against the Aequi in teh territory of Praeneste that preceded the formation of the Hernican alliance, and Livy records that Praenste took no part in the Latin war that followed teh expulsion of the Kings.  028},
  note = {Latiner versuchen Roms dominanz abzuschütteln The traditional account of the breakdown of the Cassian system is thath the undue preponderance of the Romans, who won back, under teh shelter of the treaty, much of the power lost in the sixth century, stirred the Latins on two occasions, first between 385 and 358 B.C., when the Gallic invasion offered an opportunity, and again in 340 B.C., to break away from the threatening dominion of Rome.  029},
  note = {Nach der gallischen Invasion (?) ..after the Gallic invasion... [...] But with the two greatest states, Tibur and Praeneste, which had performed teh act of formal surrender individually to her, Rome settled separately. A little earlier a special settlement had also been made with Tusculum, which roused the indignation of the Latin federation.  => Quellen: 	Praeneste: 		Liv. 6, 29, 7 		Dion. 16. 45, 8 	Tibur: 		Liv. 7, 19, 1 		Oxyrhynchus Ol. 106, 1  030},
  note = {Viele Informationen verloren The fragment of Cincius, supported by casual references in Livy, shows how much has been lost of the history of Latium in this period. We probably possess less than the half stories of the border warfare.  031},
  note = {Tibur und Prenaest dehen sich auf kosten anderer aus This seems to represent a development of the period. Like Rome, these two states [Anm. Tibur und Praeneste] emerge from the period of the invasions with an increase of lands and power. But this increase, like that of Rome, must have been at the expense of the remaining Triginta Populi which contracted the foeudes Cassianum. IN 338 no more than thirteen independent populi were left.   033},
  note = {Handel und Eherecht im 4. Jh. The existence of commercium and conubium is no small exception to the exclusiveness of local politics in fourth-century Latium. The power of acquiring the citizenship of another statue by change of domicil - ius mutandae civitatis or ius migrationis - is debated ground. That in the second century the latin colonies shared it with Rome and one another, is not disputed.  034},
  note = {Umzugsrecht The liveliness and continuity of the notion are shown by the fact that Tibur and Praeneste retained the right, after the break-up of the Latin League, till the Social War. Thus subject illuminated by the incident, in 311 B.C., of the Roman tibicines who went on strike and retired to Tibur. They, in fact, exercised the ius exilii; that is why the Senate could not touch them.  034 f},
  note = {Sonderstellung Aricias (?) A difficulty occurs over Aricia, which Cicero desribes as 'municipium vetustate antiquissimum iure foederatum'. Livy tells of nothing beyond the fact that Arica received the citizenship along with the other Latin states. Kornemann suggests that the existence of the grove of Aricia secured her special terms. In view of Livy's silence it is hard to assign to this foedus any political value, such as the foedus Gabinum must have possessed. It sounds more like the special proviso tha accompanied the grant of citizenship to Lanuvium.  => Quelle: 	Liv. 8, 14, 3 	Cic. Phil. 3, 15  061},
  note = {Dictator als Oberster Magistrat in Aricia at Aricia, Lanuvium, and Nomentum there were, in imperial times, not tow aediles but a dictator assisted by either one or two aediles. Rudolph attempts to explain away the the presence of the dictator by maintaining that his functions were purely religious. But further complications appear when it is remembered that at Caere also in later days there existed the scheme of dictator and single aedilis.  063},
  note = {Nach 338 gebunden an Rom The clue to the understanding of the institution is that they are Rome's allies not on the ground of any treaty, but because they are recognized to possess a certain status. This recognition is a bilateral act between partners in fact unequal, one of whom is preponderant in the transaction. The members of the earlier nomen Latinum had severally performed the act of deditio to Rome, and the Romans in their turn, by a process that foreshadows the treatment of the Campanians in 210, declared teh various states to be 'free on certain terms'.  096},
  note = {Latinisches Recht für alle gleich ..the fact that no difference existed between the constitutional position rights, and privileges of the coloniae Latinae and those few surviving members of the forme triginta populi and those of teh Hernici. When Livy mentions in one passage offical letters sent circa nomen Latinum he means in particular Norba, Setia, Circei, and Praeneste. [...] The main duty of the Latin Name was to supply Rome with troops, the milites ex formula togatorum;  098},
  note = {Rom behandelt Bundesgenossen als ''ausführende Organe'' in Krisenzeiten Such phrases as these demonstrate how Roman control spread. Doubtless it was possible to avoid violating the forms of local independence. The litterae hospitum de senatus consulto showed the local authorities how to act, but when the magistrates of Ardea were sent a prisoner to guard and warned not to let him escape, they were in effect being treated not as independent bodies but as administrative machinery. [...] at the time of a slave riot in Latium the Roma praetor sent letters to the authorities of the Latin states asking for their assistance and co-operation. This was doubtless the normal custom, and abandoned only in times of crisis and excitement.  105},
  note = {Bürgerrecht für Magistrate It is as a result of this last factor that there emerges in the period immediately before the Social War another path to citizenship. This is the acquisition of it per magistratum. When the Transpadane peoples were given Latin rights this element of their privilege was noted as teh dominate feature.  111},
  note = {Latiner Status Mittelding Hitherto the Latins had formed an intermediate class between Romans and non-Romans but not a link. [..] For the imperial jurists just as for the Republican sources of Livy the world was divided into cives Romani and Latini over against the peregrini.  116},
  note = {Viele Kulte weiter geführt The league of Aricia kept the cult of Diana, the Alban federation that of Juppiter Latiarus, while the Lavinian group observed the archaic pater or Juppiter indiges and penates under the form of the Dioscuri. The Lavinian cult still operates in 339 B.C. when special provision is made for its formal continuance on behalf of the Latin Name. Hence it had always coexisted with the Latiar. So too teh council of the Latins at Lucus Ferentinae continued its activities down to the dissolution of all such groups in 338.  192},
  note = {Diskussion Alföldi Alföldi rejects the text of the 'Cassian' treaty in Dionysius as irreconcilable with the view (which he shares with this book) that  the renewal of the alliance after Regillus was on equal terms. [...] But Alföldi somewhat misunderstands the text of Dionysius. [...] the two parties are neither to fight one another directly nor to let thrid parties attack the other through their territory. This ties in with the recent intrigues of Aricia, Rome, and Prosenna which Alföldi elsewhere stresses. [S 195] Yet at some time Rome acquired more than a rotating share in the military leadership of Latium - the clash between teh two parties in the fourth century is otherwise inexplicable.  194 f},
  note = {Hegemonie Roms über Latinischer Bund später These facts suggest that at some later date, if not in 493, a bipartite agreement was made, exactly as in the 'Cassian' treaty, giving Rome more than a rotating share in the hegemony of Latium, but not exclusive control.  195},
  key = {Sherwin-White789}
}

@Article{MacDonald790,
  author = {MacDonald, A H},
  title = {{Rome and the Italian Confederation (200-186 BC)}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Diana Entwicklung Gelesen Geschichte Münzen Nemi Republik},
  journal = {JRS},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {},
  publisher = {},
  volume = {34},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {1944},
  month = {},
  pages = {11-33},
  url = {},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {Z 425},
  note = {Stellung der Latiner In principle the Latin cities under Rome had municipal autonomy in constituion, magistracies and coinage, and (almost certainly) some communal interrelations, for example, teh migration- They had to raise and pay their quota of troops ex formula togatorum, but did this by their own authority. They were closely associated with Rome in their rights co commercium and conubium, in the settlement of colonies (Romans regularly joining Latin colonie and Latins being accepted in Roman colonies), and in their access to full Roman citizenship. Latins when in Rome might vote in an allotted tribe or, if resident, gain citizenship by registering at the census, per migrationem et censum.  11},
  note = {Silbermünze der Diana In 296 (or 268) the first issue of Roman silver (the Romano-Campanian didrachms) showed Diana of Nemi, the patron goddess of the Latins. Thsi presumably reflects the confederate policy of Rome against Pyrrhus, and the new common currency would force out the local coinages.  11 f},
  note = {Roms Macht basiert auf Latinern Thus we may accept the view that Latin colonie sfounded after 265 had a restricted ius migrandi, by which a Latin migratin to Rome had to leave a son behind him. This was not discrimination against the latins: Roman power at this time depended upon Latin support.  12},
  note = {Kolonien unterschiedlich an Rom gebunden first, the Twelve Colonies with the ius Arimini (to whom Cicero later referred), retaining the full Latin rights from before 265; second, the twelve defaulting colonies of 209, which had been founded before 265 but now were in the special position of being dependent upon Rome for the administration of their levy; thirdly, the colonies founded after 265 with the modified ius migrandi.  12},
  note = {Frei, aber politisch Gebunden an Rom The Italians cities, for their part, had full municipal autonomy and considerable freedom in intercommunal matters, for example, in exchange of citizen rights and in migration. With Rome their relationship was strictly defined by treaty. The foedus aequum, a defensive alliance on equal terms had been superseded after 338 B.C. by the foedus iniquum, which bound the socii to maintain the maiestas populi Romani, following Roman foreign policy and providing troops. The Italians fulfilled their military obligations, but in return claimed respect for their municipal independence.  12},
  note = {Einfache Latiner wandern nach Rom aus The Latins came to Rome because Roman citizenship, which they could gain by residence there, was now more valuable. [...] The Latins who migrated would therefore belong mainy to the small artisan or landless class, who could make their living as craftsmen or labourers in the city. These were the Latins to whom Roman citizenship meant an improved livelihood, in its full social and economic sense, and they were the new citizens whom the city of Rome required as part of its fresh growth.  21},
  note = {Latiner auf Wunsche der Latiner aus Rom zurück In 187 representaives from the whole of Latium, that is, in particular from the older colonies with the unrestricted ius migrandi, raise teh question of the Latin migration to Rome in the Senate, and the Senate instructed the praetro Q. Terentius Culleo to repatriate all Latins who themselves or whose fathers had been enrolled in a Latin city in 204 or afterwards. => Problem der zu wenigen Soldaten  22},
  note = {Gegen den Bacchus Kult The Senate had political and religious reasons which it could put forward in taking action against the Bacchic cult. Politically teh movement could be represented in general as a form of popular degeneracy, threatening the social stability of Rome and the confederation and weakening Roman military power; in particular the secret celebration with its criminal accompaniments could be treated as ''conspiracy'' against the State.  27},
  note = {Soziale Spannungen wegen der Kriege We have noted the war-weariness, the dislike of overseas campaigning, and the insubordination in the armies, presumably affecting the allies as well as the Roman citizens, which boded ill for Italian society on their return to civil life. In the Latin communities in particular there were dangerous points of agitation where the craftsmen and labourers who had been expelled from Rome resigned themselves unwillingly to their loss of economic opportunity. [...] The Roman hegemony in Italy rested upon the alliance of the Roman senatorial nobility with the Latin and Italian aristocracy, in accordance with a set social structure and political organisation in the Italian confederation, and Roman and Italian nobility were of one mind in preserving the foundation of their power and authority. [...] The administrative and military success of the Italian confederation under Rome had begin the social unification of Italy; but the  social changes arising from unification were affecting the administration and military working of the confederation. This is the historical problem of Rome and the Italian confederation in 186 B. C.  33},
  key = {MacDonald790}
}

  note = {foedus Cassianum With the Etruscan domination removed, this claim was contested by the Latins, who in a large measure regained their full independence. But with the appeareance of invading hill-tribes in the fifth century, the need for coalition became plain: in some form, Roman hegemony was recognized in what is traditionally known as the treaty of Sp. Cassius. [...] the treaty of Casssius was renewed and, whatever it was before, it now became a treaty on equal terms between Rome and the rest of teh Latins.   note = {Latinier Krieg Rome had been unable to protect her allies in Latium and Campania against the Samnite danger, which moreove r(in the case of Latium) she had wantonly brought upon them; thus the reason for acknowledging the hegemony of Rome had disappeared, and with it the fear of her. The Latins and Campanias, in their elation, thought they could both attack their fallen leader and continue the war against the Samnites. [...] They were defeated by the combined forces of Rome and Samnium, and the settlement of 338 saw the end of the Latin League and of the independent political importance of the Latin states. [S. 23] The settlement of 338 marks the failure of Rome's first protectorate - the first of such failures that turned out to be the steps to her greatness. [...] The whole of Latium was annexed,except for the larger states of Tibur and Praeneste, Ardea (which must have remained faithful), and probably Lavinium. [...] And for the first time, as we have noticed, ager Romanus and civitas Romana were extended over large areas and important cities outside Latium.  022 f},

[...S 25] That the Latins were satisfied with their status is shown by their unwavering loyalty in all the major wars of Rome after 338.  024 f},

  LCCN = {ULB 65/2419},
  note = {Egeria unter Servius Tullius importiert Egeria was a spring-goddess of Aricia, whose name was evidently derived from the gens Egeria which supplied at least tow prominent figures in early Latium. Now the connexion between Rome and Aricia and in particular the importation of Aricine cults to Rome is certainly no earlier than the reign of Servius Tullus, and therefore, the association of Egeria with the Camenae must also belong to that period.  102},
  note = {Schlacht von Aricia Under the leadership of Aristodemus Cumae resisted that expansion while preserving friendly relations with the maritime states of Tarquinii and Caere. In 524 she defeated an assault by Etruscans, aided by Umbrians and Daunians. Her victory at Aricia (c. 506) was confirmed thirty years later by the decisive Battle of Cumae (474) [...] ..the first signs of Roman independence can be detected under Sp. Cassius. For ten years or so Rome collaborated with Porsenna and that fact is not likely to have endeared the Romans to Aristodemus.  169},
  note = {Übergang der Diana von Aricia auf den Aventin The most important of such sources was Aricia where the cult of Diana (Cato fr. 58 P.) was served by a religious league of nine Latin communities to which Rome, as an Etruscan dominated town, did not belong. The Arician cult was earlier than the Aventine and had a political as well as a religious aspect to it, since the Concilium Latinorum which met at the Lucus Ferentinae in the territory of Aricia was the same organization under a different name. Political and religious competition with Aricia is further indicated by the transplantation of the Virbius legend from Aricia to Rome at much the same date. [...] The cult of Diana on the Aventin marks his [Anm. Servius Tullius] attempt to oust Aricia from the political hegemony of Latium. [...] These wandering exiles would have furnished Servius with the privileged information about the Ephesian shrine that enabled him to promote the superior claims of Diana of the Aventine over Diana of Aricia. Above all, he devised an almost Callimachean Aetion around a sacred relic, a gigantic pair of horns, to convince the superstitious and to teach the moral that the sovereignty of Latium had passed to Rome. Despite some anachronisms, the story of the Sabine cow must be very ancient - as old as the cult of Diana on the Aventine. The exact date of the foundation is not disclosed but c. 540 suits both the traditional chronology of Servius' reign (577-33) and the second settlement of Massilia. [..S. 183] He [Anm. Alföldi] does, however, produce no evidence for the assertion that the image and the league belong to the period of Porsenna's activities rather than fifty years earlier nor, a fortiori, for the contention that the institution of Diana on the Aventine should be dated not to c. 540 but to the aftermath of Lake Regillus.  182 f},
  note = {Virbius At an early date contact with Aricia brought about a religious corss-fertilization between the tow towns. Now at Aricia the predominant cult, that of Diana Nemornesis, was associated with a native Latin god Virbius, regarded by Vibius Sequester as a river-god, but by an authority known to [Servis] as scholar, who under the influence of Greek mythology quickly came to be identified with Hippolytus and inherited many details of Hippolytus' biography. The street leading up to the temple of Diana Nemoreneis was called the clivus Virbis  193},
  note = {Arricia A colony of Alba Longa or, according to another, hellenizing, account, founded by a Sicilian Archilochus, its floruit was glorious but short-lived. Not a member of the old Laban League, it appears to have built up its own federal league which flourished for a while towards the end of the sixth century before the city passed into the orbit of Rome and into obscurity.  => Quellen	Solinus 2, 16 (Gründung) 	Cassius Hemina (?)  200 f},
  note = {Gabii freiwillige und starke Fusion the ancient tradition is unanimous that Gabii was absorbed by Rome not as a result of direct conquest but by negotiation, and D.H. adds taht teh details of teh treaty were preserved on a leather shield in the temple of Semo Sancus Dius Fidius. The tradition is corroborated by teh curious position enjoyed by Gabine institutions in the history of Rome which suggests taht in the fusion Gabii was negotiating from a position of greater strength than the Roman historians care to allow. Historically such a fusion could not be later than the end of the sixth century so taht the main facts of the tradition are beyond dispute.  Quelle: 	Horaz, Ep 2, 1, 24 	Festus 48 L 	Dion. Hal. 8,9,9; 10, 7, 3 	Cato. ap Servius, ad Aen, 5, 755 	Varro, Ling Lat. 5,33  209},
  note = {Latinische Liga von Aricia The moving spirits of the political league were Aricia and Tusculum and the fragment of Cato gives a list of the leage at a very early date: [...] That was before Rome under Tarquin had secured association with the community. At the other end of its existence, in 338 13 members survived. [..] At sone point between these tow dates the league totalled 30 and the number gave its name to the community, surviving long after the arithmetical reality had passed. [...] The menace of the Hernici and the Volsci and the leadership of Tarquinius Superbus were factors that would have tended to expand and unify the league. [..S. 281] Of the workings of the league we know little. It met annually at the Lucus Ferentinae and conducted joint campaigns in time of war, Rome apparently supplying the commander. The position in 501 would seem to have been that with the expulsion of the Tarquins Rome's domination and perhaps even membership of the league ceased and Tusculum regained her former hegemony. Under such circumstances it is in no way odd that the league should have decided to commence hostilities against Rome.   280},
  note = {Praeneste Ursprung The name [Anm. Praeneste] suggests an Illyrian foundation which may be mirrored in the tradition that made Telegonus, Odysseus' son, its founder, but any Illyrian traces were soon overlaid by a cosmopolitian mixture of Etruscan and Sabine influences. Her cults (e. g. Hercules) and her family-names (e.g. Saufeius) are strongly Sabine, while her architecture and writing are marked by Etruscan features. [..] The Terentili may have come to Rome from Praeneste.  285},
  note = {Tradition und Macht in den Städten langezeit gepflegt The memory of the Etruscan domination of Italy was well maintained. Its detailed accuracy indicates that it was kept alive by a succession of Etruscan writers.  => Quellen 	Varro, ap Censornus, de Die Nat 17, 6  703},
  key = {Ogilvie810}
}

  note = {Mythos und Geschichte gleich Myth an history had the same status; from the point of view of the addressees too, what was said had endured 'since the time of their ancestors', indeed the aspect of permanence was given further emphasis, in particular through the affirmation that the acceptance of teh Magnesian festival should hold 'for ever and ever'.  295},
  note = {Mythologie als intendierte Geschichte In this respect one can describe such a picture of the past as intentional, avoiding terms which imply value judgments, such as 'forgery', 'fictive history', or 'believed history'. Intentional history would then be history in a group's own understanding, especially in so far as it is significant for the make-up and identity of the group; or, alternatively, tradition has a 'social surface' in the sense of modern social anthropology, it relates itself to a group which holds it as real.  298},
  note = {Mythos und Geschichte eng verbunden The connection between myth and history was much closer in those authors who formed what we might call the mainstream tradition of Greek historiography. In the second century AD Lucian still attacks the widespread pursuit of exaggeration and poetic embellishment in this genre, as well as its subjectivity and partisanship.  299},
  note = {Bindung an Mythische Zeit Now perceptions of exactly this kind were fundamental for the imaginaire of a community, a polis, a league, and indeed the hellenic world as a whole. They also had prescriptive value, and this gave them particular importance. One was located in a temporal continuum at the beginning of which stood events tied to a primeval world of sacred myth and to which one was none the less connected 'from ancestral times', i. e. from the times of heroes and sons of deities.  300},
  note = {Zur Selbstidentivizierung wichtig A further purpose of this reference to the past was to categorize oneself as belonging to particular groups; this was relevant for people's collective identity and their relationship to others, their concept of the Other. In this there was a wide spectrum between affinity and heterogeneity.  304},
  note = {Geschichte als soziales Wissen History, or what a given society regards as its history, also belongs to this kind of social knowledge. One could also say that the social store of knowledge about the past is what i call intentional history.  308},
  note = {Kennedy Zitat The great enemy of truth is often not lie - thought-out, invented, and false - but myth - steady, convincing, and unrealistic.  Quelle: Die Zeit 51/37 (5. Spet. 1997), 1.  313},
  key = {Gehrke819}

  note = {Bundesgenossen Krieg Eine Reihe von italischen Völkerschaften erhob sich gegen Rom, und zwar die Marser, Samniten, Pikenter, Päligner, Vestiner, Marruciner, Frentaner und Hirpiner. Das Zentrum dieser Erhebung lag im mittleren Italien, bei den Marsern und den Samniten. Die betreffendne Völker schlossen sich zusammen und buldeten eine Konföderation mit den Zentrum Corfinium im Lande der Päligner; die Stadt erhielt den Namen ''Italia''. Etrurien und Umbrien, deren reiche Großgrundbesitzer die Römer fpr sich gewinnen konnten, der größte Teil der Latiner, Norditalien (Gallia Cisalpina), die Griechenstädte und die kampanischen Städte Nola und Nuceria hielten zu den Römern. Nicht zletzt boten den Römern die im Zuge der Unterwerfung Italiens gegründeten zahlreichen Kolonien einen militärischen Rückhalt.  137},
  LCCN = {S 770/30 +3},
  note = {Bürgerrechtsgesetzte Ende des Jahred 90 brachte der Konsul Iulius Caesar ein Gesetz durch (lex Iulia de civitate), wonach allen Latinern und bis dahin Rom treugebliebenen Bundesgenossen das römische Bürgerrecht gewährt wurde. Im Jahre 89 folgte das Gesetz der Volkstribunen M. Plautius Silvanus und des C. Papirius Carbo (lex Plautia Papiria), das dieses Zugenständnis auf alle Bundesgenossen südlich des Po ausdehnte, allerdings mit der Maßgabe, sich innerhalb von 60 Tagen in Rom zu melden, was selbstverständlich das Niederlegen der Waffen einschloß.  138},
  note = {Folgen des Bundesgenossenkrieges Im Ergebnis der Bundesgenossenkriege hatte nahezu die gesamte freie Bevölkerung Italiens das römische Bürgerrech erworben, doch darf diese Tatsache nicht überschätzt werden, denn die politische Mitwirkung eines jeden Bürgers war bei Stimmabgaben von seiner Anwesenheit in Rom selbst abhängig, und die Masse der Kleinproduzenten in den verschiedenen Teilen Italiens hatte kaum Gelegenheit, die so gewonnenen Gleichberechtigung auch tatsächlich zu nutzen. Davon profitierte in erster Line die städtischen itaischen Pberschichten, die allmählich ihren Einfluß auf das politische Geschehen in Rom verstärken konnten. [...] Immerhin war die Verleihung des Bürgerrechts an die Italiker insofern von Bedeutung, als hier der klassische stadtstaatliche Rahmen erstmalig gesprngt wurden und sich der Reichsgedanke abzeichnete. [...] So beginnt nacht dem Bundesgenossenkreig ein Aufblühen vieler itlaischer Städte...  139},

@Book{Cens832,
  author = {Cens},
  title = {{... - Censorinus, De Die Natali}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Etruskisch Gelesen Geschichte Quellen},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {},
  publisher = {},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {...},
  month = {},
  pages = {},
  url = {},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {},
  edition = {},
  note = {Etruskische Geschichtsschreibung wie Varro belegt Haec portenta Etrusci pro haruspicii disciplinaeque suae peritia diligenter observata in libros rettulerunt. Quare in Tuscis historiis, quae octavo eorum saeculo scriptae sunt, ut Varro testatur, et quot numero saecula ei genti data sint, et transactorum singula quanta fuerint quibusve ostentis eorum exitus designati sint, continetur. Itaque scriptum est quattuor prima saecula annorum fuisse centenum, quintum centum viginti trium, sextum undeviginti et centum, septimum totidem, octavum tum demum agi, nonum et decimum superesse, quibus transactis finem fore nominis Etrusci.  Les Étrusques, vu leur science et leur habileté dans l'art des aruspices, après avoir observé ces prodiges avec attention, les ont consignés dans leurs livres. Aussi les Annales de l'Étrurie, écrites, comme Varron nous l'apprend, dans le cours du huitième siècle de cette nation, nous montrent-elles, et combien de siècles d'existence lui sont réservés, et combien il y en a d'écoulés, et par quels prodiges est marqué le terme de chacun d'eux. Ainsi nous y lisons que les quatre premiers siècles ont été de cent cinq années, le cinquième de cent vingt-trois, le sixième de cent dix-neuf, le septième d'autant, que le huitième est en train de s'écouler, et qu'il ne reste plus à s'accomplir que le neuvième et le dixième, après la révolution desquels disparaîtra le nom étrusque.  17, 6},
  key = {Cens832}
}

@Book{Veyne834,
  author = {Veyne, Paul},
  title = {{Die römische Gesellschaft}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Entwicklung Gelesen Geschichte Kaiserzeit},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {München},
  publisher = {Fink},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {1995},
  month = {},
  pages = {332},
  url = {http://www.gbv.de/dms/faz-rez/F19951129NIPP2--100.pdf},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {3-7705-2932-4},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {S 1073/70},
  note = {Freilassung von Sklaven Die Freilassung per Testament waren sehr verbreitet; der Digest und die Grabstein bestätigten es in Fülle. Der Brauch wollte es, daß die Herrschaft bei ihrem Tod eine Anzahl verdienter Sklaven freiließ. Der Wunsch, allseits betrautert zu werden, sicherlich. Auch der damals so lebhafte Drang zur Ostenation und zur conspicuous consumption: die massenhaften Freilassungen waren etwaswie ein Funeral-Potlatch. [...] eine Mehrzahl von Freilassungen gescha sicherlich per Testament was, wie man sehen wird, gravierende Folgen hat.  019},
  note = {Freilassung keine ökomomischen Auswirkungen In Wirklichkeit kostte ihn das nichts: diese neu Freigelassenene blieben bei ihrem Herrn und erfüllten dort die Funktionen, die sie immer ausgeübt hatte; die Befreiung war für sei eine Art Verdienstorden für alte Arbeiter. Santo Mazzorino hat recht: die massiven Sklavenbefreiungen, die im IV. Jahrhundert unter dem Einfluß des Christentums stattfinden werden, haben ethische, aber keine ökomomischen Konsequenzen.  020},
  note = {Aufsteigende Sklaven Was zählte, war nicht der Unterschied zwischen Sklaven und Freigelassenen, sondern der zwischen den Sklaven und der Mehrheit der Freigelassenen, die bei ihrem Herrn blieben, einerseits, und eine Minderheit von Freigelassenen andererseits, die durch günstige Umstände juristisch und ökomomisch unabhängig geworden waren. Es ist diese Minderheit, die im ersten Jahrhundert unserer Zeitrechnung jene lautstarke Schicht von Geschäftemachern bildet, die man zu Recht oder zu Unrecht als aufsteigende Bourgeoisie bezeichnet hat und die dank dem Satiricon legendär geworden ist.  021},
  note = {Aufstieg für Sklaven leichter Daher das Paradox eines Aufstiegs per Kurzschluß. In der Tiefe der Gesellschaft machte der ökomomische Druck praktisch jeden realen Standesunterschied zunichte; Saklven und Freie lebten in derselben Dürftigkeit, und mit Recht spricht eine Inschrift von den ''Kindern der Plebs, ohne Unterschied der Freiheit''. Doch eun Unterschied blieb: für den Sklaven, welcher in der Haushaltung seines Herren der sich möglicherweise um ihn kümmern würde, lebte, waren die Aufstiegschancen insgesamt nicht so gering wie für einen Plebejer oder freien Bauern, den nichts aus seiner Lage befreien konnte.  Quelle: 	CIL X, 5853  023},
  note = {Freigelassen an Adel gebunden Der Adelsgeist ging in diese Richtung; die großen Familien zeigten ihre Macht, indem sie ihre Freigelassenen aushieten und Kreaturen förderten. Wie die Klienten waren die Freigelassenen die Satelliten des Hauses und umgaben es mit einer Aura von Ergebenheit: [...] In den niederen Klassen führte eine fast familiäre Gefühlsbindung oft zum selben Ergebnis; man schuf dem Freigelassenen eine Stellung oder überließ ihm die Mittel, sich eine zu schaffen, so als ob es sich um einen Sohn oder mndestens um einen Bastard gehandelt hätte. [...] So waren die Freigelassenen eine Art Verlängerung, eine bscura propago der Oberklassen. Aus diesem Grund waren sie ein spezifisch italienisches Phänomen; in den westlichen Provinzen, in Afrika zum Beispiel, waren sie selten und nur in den großen Städten anzutreffen, oder ihre Anwesenheit hing mit den nahen Erbgütern einer großen Familie zusammen.  025},
  note = {Wandel bei Freigelassenen zwischen 1. und 2. Jh. Zu ergänzen ist, glaube ich, daß sich die Dinge zwischen dem ersten Jahrhunderte des Imperiums, das noch voll aristokratischer Lässigkeit war, und dem zweiten, das die sozialen Konventionen viel aufmerksamer beachtete und für die Klassenscharenk empfindlich war, offenbar geändert haben. Die allzu individualistische Neigung, seinen Kreaturen eine Stellung zu verschaffen, muß sich abgeschwächt haben. [...] In Ermangelung sicher datierbaren epigraphischen Materials scheint der Abstieg der kaiserliche Freigelassenen während des II. Jahrhunderts ein Zeichen für diese Entwicklung zu sein. Und die Kategorie der unabhängigne Freigelassenen muß sich immer mehr verengt haben, was erhebliche Ökonomishe Fogen nach sich zog.  026},
  note = {Freigelassnen in Italien Mit dieser Kategorie von unabhängigen Freigelassenen, die für einen Moment die Hefe Italiens gewesn ist, macht uns das Satiricon bekannt.  026},
  note = {Handel statt Bauern Kurz, sie sind zumeist Handwerker oder Kaufleute; sie bewirken in einer grundsätzlich agrarischen Gesellschaft eine Veränderung der sozialen Landschaft. Alle sid sie ihre eigenen Herren; von ihrem Patron sprech sie nicht oder nur in der Vergangenheit [Anm: Bezieht sich auf Trimalcho] [...] Denn die Frage der Berufswahl stellt sich in der römischen wie in jeder vorindustriellen Gesellschaft nur in der Oberklasse; überall sonst verstand es sich von selbst, daß man das Handwerk des Vaters betrieb. [...]  Doch für die Bevölkerungsmehrheit hatte die Erblichkeit des Standes, das Kastenregime, de facto immer schon bestanden. Wo hätte denn in einer armen und wenig differenzeirten Ökonomie ein Bauer, ein Handwerker oder ein Ladenbeseitzer vernünftigerweise die Mittel oder auch nur die Idee hernehmen solen, etwas anderes zu unternehmen als sein Vater?  027},
  note = {Primär Ackerbau Andererseits leben unsere Freigelassenen in einer Geselschaft, in der dreiviertel der Bevölkerung Ackerbau treiben. Ihnen jedoch fehlt die Bindung an den Boden. [...] Das gleiche läßt sich auch von den Freigelassenen sagen, nur daß sie niemals eine Bourgeoisie geworden sind; sie bildne zwischen einer umfangreichen freien oder unfreiene Bauernschaft und einem städtischen Alde auf domanualer Grundlage das Element der Differenz, Aus ihne rekrutierten sich bekanntlch vor allem die Angehörigen der nicht ackerbauenden Berufe; hier wiegt ihre Gruppe allein schon die Gesamtheit der Freigeborenen auf.  028},
  note = {Freigelassene in italischen Städten Eine italienische Stadt, also ein Gebilde, das zugleich ein regionaler Markt und das Ergebnis gruppenweiser Siedlungstradition und politischen Lebens ist, ist zunächst von einem Stadtadel bevölkert, der dort die Einkünfte seiner Ländereien verzehrt, von den Freigelassenen dieses Adels und von deren Nachkommen. Zwischen der Aristokratie, die die Stadt regiert, und der Plebs haben die Freigelassenen eine offizielle Vertretung, das Kollegium der seviri oder Augustales, das ihre ökonomische Wichtigkeit sanktioniert. Indem vorwiegend sie für den Nachwuchs in den nichtbäuerlichen Berufen sorgen, spielen sie im Leben der Allgemeinheit eine hochwichtige Rolle, denn der betreffende Nachwuchs stellte sich schwerlich von selbst ein.  028 f},
  note = {Gesellschaft hier eine freie Bauernschaft und eine städtische Plebs, die beide ein sparsames, bescheiden-tugendhaftes Leben, wenn nicht das von Nichtstuern führen; dort der Adel, der von den Einkünften seiner Ländereien lebt, der deren Verwaltung bisweilen streng überwacht, nichtsdestoweniger jedoch seine Ehre in der Regierung der Stadt und in der Ostenation oder einfach im Konsum, kurz in einer ''politische'' Existenz (als cives) sieht. In einer solchen Kultur war die kapitalistische Mentalität der Freigelassenen, die seitdem so banal geworden ist, ein Fremdkörper...  030},
  key = {Veyne834}
}

  note = {Vermutlich Historische Tradition Il discorso e piu complesso per gli altri popoli dell'Italia antica: e difficile dire se genealogie etniche e familiari e tradizioni su fondazioni di citta si siano mai elevate ad una vera e propria narrazione storica (forse qualcosa si potrebbe immaginare per le popolazioni sannite).  46},
  note = {Etruskische Gesellschaft La societe etrusca sara caratterizzata fino alla Guerra Sociale da una sua particolare struttura di tipo 'semifeudale', fondata su larghe proprieta lavorate per lo piu da servi e da schiavi.  52},
  note = {foedus Cassianum Una qualche posizione egemonica di Roma nel Lazio e confermata, fra l'altro, dall stipulazione di un trattato con Cartagine datatao al 509 a. C., primo anno della repubblica. [...] I contrasti di Roma con gli altri popoli latini sfociarono nella battaglia del lago Regillo del 496 a. C.; la vittoria romana non fu risolutiva e comunque si venne nel 493 ad un patto di alleanza, su piede di parita, fra Roma da una parte, e i popoli Latini dall'altra, al quale poi si aggiunsero gli Ernici.  53},
  note = {Vorgehen gehen baccanalien Altra conseguenza fu che i patti di alleanza dovettero conoscere cambiamenti che accentuarono il carattere diseguale dei due contraenti, ampliando le possibilita di intervento del governo negli affari interni alleati. Un esempio caratteristico ci e offerto dalla repressione messa in moto nel 187 a. C. dal governo romano in tutta Italia contro quella che venne considerata una degenerazione del culto bacchico pericolosa per l'ordine politicio e sociale generale.  74},
  note = {Keine Verbündeten auf Augenhöhe mehr I socii Italici e Latini non erano piu gli alleati di una citta che si era battuta per conquistare il primato in Italia. Essi si trovavano ora ad essere gli ausiliari di una potenza a livello mondiale, sia che lo volessero, sie che fossero trascinati in questa nuova direzione.  75},
  note = {Homogenisierung durch Militär L'eguagliamento del sistema di armamento, nei modi di combattimento, nella divisione del bottino e nelle ricompense venne a corrispondere a una profonda assimilazione nelle mentalita e negli ideali.  E nella milizia che le masse romane e italiche trovarono l'omogeneizzazione. [...] La partecipazione in movimento del ceto dirigente romano e delle conquiste nel corso del II secolo negli ambiti provinciali fu sempre piu ampia, anche se naturalmente subordinata rispetto alla presenza romana.  75},
  note = {Entvölkerung latinisher Städte (?) In primo luogo la citta capitale attiro verso di se un forte flusso emigratori dalle comunita latine e alleate, che in parecchi casi risentirono di un vero e proprio spopolamento.  76},
  note = {Wandel in der Landwirtschaft grundlage der sozialen Entwicklung Ma d'altro canto, quell' afflusso di produzioni incentivava in varie aree italiche del centro-sud una 'conversione' delle colture, dia cereali a produzioni specializzate piu redditizie come olio e vino, che trovavano smercio nelle citta (e anche nelle province). [...] Questa tipica struttura italica prese a declinare, anche perche con il nuovo impiego dell' agro pubblici veniva meno il suo tradizionale necessario supporto. Naturalmente non si intende dire che la piccola proprieta contadina andasse sparendo...Catone teorizzava implicitamene la coesistenza della piccola proprieta familiare e della grande azienda con una produzione avviata alla commercializzazione. [...] In ogni caso questa razionalizzazione dell'agricoltura rappresento, in generale, un progresso economico, ma anche segno in larga misura il declino sociale della classe dei piccoli e medi proprietari, che aveva sempre rappresentato il tessuto connettivo della societa romana e italica. Una parte die questa classe si ridusse a proletariato rurale, e a salariati, parte emigro al nord e nelle province occidentali, parte venne ad alimentare la plebe urbana di Roma. Quello che e importante notare e che questa serie di fenomeni interesso, sia pure in modo non omogeneo, tutta l'Italia nel II secolo a. C., e si e potuto quindi avanzare la teoria che sia appunto da questo momento, e sulla base die questo problem, che si possa parlare di una storia unitaria dell'Italia.  76},
  note = {Italische Oberschicht gegen Grachen Una buona parte dell'ager publicus da ricuperare era in mano alle classi alte italiche; era abbastanza ovvio che queste si schierassero in maggioranza contro le proposte graccane, insieme ai gruppi piu conservatori dell'oligarchia romana. [...] D'altro canto le masse italiche, come quelle rurali romane, erano interessate alla riforma agraria; la tradizione storica attesta piu volte un'affluenza di Italici a Roma. Anche se essi non  potevano partecipare alla decisione politica (lo potevano pero i Latini se pur con scarsa efficacia pratica), tuttavia la loro presenza era spesso politicamente efficace, e naturalmente fastidiosa.  77},
  note = {Zerstörung von Fregella und Bürgerrecht für Magistrate Nel 125 a. C. l'antica colonia latina di Fregellae, il corpo civico aveva subito da decenni infiltrazioni di elementi italici, si sollevo contro Roma e venne distrutta. L'episodio suscito grande impressione. Poco dopo fu approvata una norma per la quale i cittadini delle colonie latine che rivestivano le magistrature coloniarie acquisivano senz'altro la cittadinanaza romana.  78},
  note = {Römisches Bürgerrech unaktrativ Le masse italiche, legate alle loro oligarchie, si erano andate integrando nella realta romana attraverso il servizio militare: la cittadinanza romana non doveva offrire ad esse nessuna visibile attrativia.  78},
  note = {Wunsch nach Teilhabe und Bürgerrecht Si sa che Gaio Mario concesse come ricompensa ad intieri reparti la cittadinanza romana in modo piu o meno legale. Si puo arguire che i vantaggi delle cittadinanaza diventavano chiari oramai non piu soltanto ai ceti alti alleati. E ad ogni modo questi ultimi che si deve riferire la felice formula dello storico Appiano: gli Alleati volevano divenire, da sudditi, compartecipi dell'impero.  79},
  note = {Latiner beteiligen sich nicht am Bundesgenossenkrieg ...chiamata la Guerra Socilae, fu un evento epocale nella storia d'Italia; duro nelle sue laterne vicende militari poco piu di due anni (fine 91 - fine 89 a. C.), me ebbe una prosecuzione di fatto nella guerra civile. Furono coinvolti Piceni, Marsi, Peligni, Vestini, Marrucini, Frentani, Irpini, Lucani, Sanniti, Pompeiani ed altre minori popolazioni della Campania meridionale. La partecipazione di Etruschi ed Umbri fu breve; fra gli insorti vi furono anche Galli della Transpadana. Le colonie Latine (dirette da classi ormai romanizzate) rimasero fedeli a Roma, con la sola eccezione di Venusia, non facilmente spiegabile; anzi  proprio contro i baluardi delle colonie latine si infranse o si blocco l'impeto degli insorti.  80 f},
  note = {Bürgerrecht während/nach Bundesgenossenkrieg Alla fine del 90 a. C. fu approvata dai comizi la lex Iulia de civitate, che concedeva la cittadinanza romana ai socii rimasti fedeli e quindi in primo luogo alle colonie latine, o che avessero gia deposto le armi, o le deponessero entro breve tempo. Erano le stesse comunita alleate a dover decidere se accettare o meno questa offerta, e sono note le esitazioni di alcune citta di Magna Grecia, per esempio Neapolis, che avevano con Roma trattaati particolarmente favorevoli.  81},
  note = {Italiker erhalten nun politischen Einfluss Le stesse guerre civili si possono considerare, per il coinvolgimento delle masse, la continuazione della Guerra Sociale e della rivolta spartachiana. E attraverso il servizio militare nelle guerre civili che le masse italiche, spinte da esigenze primarie di ordine economico e sociale, riacquistarono anche un certo ruolo politico nella tarda repubblica agli ordini dei grandi capifazione.  83},
  note = {''Doppelte'' Heimat Quando Cicerone nel de legibus teorizzava la duplicita della patria, quella locale nella quale sie e nati, e quella di diritto, Roma, egli veniva certamente incontro ai sentimenti per nulla spenti di locale patriottismo e cercava di conciliarli con il superiore senso dello stato impersonato da Roma.  => Cic. delle leggi II, 5  83},
  note = {Municipia weitgehend frei Gli statuti municipali stabilivano in modo abbastanza uniforme l'assetto politico della comunita: senato (decuirioni), magistrati, assemblea popolare, e le rispettive competenze. Posizione preminente ebber i senati ai quali furono conferiti anche poteri di giudizio. I magistrati avevano potere giurisdicente. La dove il municipio si impiantava us di una realta urbana e sociale gia sviluppata, anche la via politicia locale si svolse attiva e vivace. Chi preferiva restare in patria e non spostarsi a Roma aveva, specialmente nel I secolo, un ampio spazio di attivita. La larga autonomia e la lontananza da Roma non smorzavano l'interesse per la politica a livello statale, e la partecipazione poteva avvenire in altro modo chenon andando nella capitale a votare nei comizi.  84},
  key = {Gabba840}
}

[..] ..wie Praenete, wo die archöologischen Funde viel weiter entwickelte künsterliche Techniken zeigen, die zweifelsfrei eine Verbindung zur etruskischen Kunst haben,  022},
  note = {Wandel der Wirtschaft in Latium Nach Franks Ansicht hätte sich wegen der Bodenerschöpfung beretis seit dem 5. Jh. ein Anbauwandle vollzogen, bei dem in Latium die Plantagen die Getreidekultur ersetzen. Dieser Prozeß wäre ungefähr um die Mitte des 3. Jhs. abgeschlossen gewesen. Folglich wäre die Einführ sizilichen Weizens nicht der Grund, sondern die Folge der ungenügenden Weizenproduktion in diesen Gebiet gewesen. Wir werden weiter unter auf dieses Problem zurückkommen; im Augenblick genügt es festzustellen, daß er Weizenmangel von den Annalisten nur in Zeiten der Hingersnot erwähnt wird; er scheint in keiner Weise eine für die römische Landwirtschaft charakteristische und ständige Erscheinung gewesen zu sein.  060},
  note = {Wirtschaftliche Entwicklung ..verlassenen Bodens in die Hände reicher römischer Grundbesitzer fiel, die die finanziellen Mittel besaßen, um das Land durch Sklaven bewirtschaften zu lassen: entwerder mit extensivem Getreideanbau oder aber mit Viehzucht. [..] Wie wir noch genauer sehen werden, trat Weideand an die stell von Getreidekulturen und große Flöchen blieben verlassen, während sich die Bevölkerung in wenigen blühneden Städten an der Küste konzentrierte. [..] Sie bestanden in einem Wechsel des Anbaus und in der Entwicklung mittelgroßer landwirtschaftlicher Betriebe (der Umfang war sicher größer als der des kleinen Bauernhofes von eins, der der Ernährung der Familie diente); ferner in der rationelleren Organisation und vor allen in der Ausbreitung einer Form von Landwirtschaft, die sich nicht mehr nur allein auf den Getreideanbeu gründete, sonder auf Plantagen und besonders auf Ölbaumhaine und Weinberge. [...] Diejenigen Gebite, die weniger im Krieg gelitten hatten, wie Latium und Kampanien, befanden sie hierbei im Anbetracht der Zerstörung, die es im Süden und besonders in Apulien gegeben hatte, in einer günstigeren Lage. [...] ..der kleine Bauer wurde verjagt und an siene Stelle trat der reiche Besitzer, der meistens in Rom oder in einer anderen Stadt wohnte und von dort den Betrieb des Hofes, der von anderen verwaltet wurde, nur beaufsichtige.  079},
  note = {Sizilien mehr Getriede Die neuen Verfügungsmöglichkeit über Getreide [Anm. Aus dem im 1. Punischen Krieg eroberten Sizilien] war der erste Schlag gegen den Getreideanabau in Gebieten wie Latium, wo der Ertrag niedrig war und wo die Böden im Vergleich zu anderen, fruchbaren Böden nur zu den mäßigen gezählt werden können.  [S. 91] Nach dem 2. Punischen Krieg veränderte sich die Lage noch drastischer: die Verwüstung Italiens, durch das von Nord nach Süd und Ost nach West die Heere gezogen waren, die Tatsache, daß die Äcker von der dort wohnenden Bevölkrung verlassen wurden, die Menschenverlsute, von denen sich beredte Spuren in dem Rückgang der wzischen 234 und 204 registrierten Cenuszahlen erhalten haben; all dies, zusammen mit der größeren Verfügungsmöglichkeit über Getreide aus denr ersten Rpovinzen, führte zu den Veränderungen in der römischen Landwirtschaft und zur nach und nach zunehmendne Beschäftigung von Sklaven - den Kennzeichen der beiden letzten Jh. der Republik. In diesem Zeitraum entwickelten sich die Bauernhöfe mittlerer Größe mit Anpflanzungen von Öl- und Obstbäumen sowie Weinbergen. [..] Gleichzeitig bildeten sich weit ausgedehnte Großgüter, auf denen man sowohl Getreide anbaute, als auch gleichzeitig große Herden weidete.  090 f},
  note = {Praeneste Metallkunst [Anm. Dat. 4.   LCCN = {ULB 71/3050},
  note = {Hannibal nicht primär Schuld am Bauern untergang This comment seems to me just, but Last should have added that the Hannibalic devastations could not in any event have promoted the decline of the Roman yeomanry, with which Tiberius Gracchus was  at least primarily concerned, because  they hardly touched the lands Roman peasants were tilling at the time.  269},
  note = {Komplexe Gründe für Wirtschaftlichen Untergang The causes of economic decline are apt to be complex. The confiscations of land by which Rome punished the rebels, the importation of hordes of slaves, the profitability of pasturage are surely involved.  277},
  note = {Aufbau der bevölkerung einer Stadt The old Italian town, as I conceive it, was inhabited partly by peasants who went out to till the adjoining fields each day, and partly by craftsmen who supplied them and others living in the country with what they could not make for themselves. This is not to deny that many also lived in large villages specially in the infertile highlands and small isolated valley;  [...] But the decay of towns is some indication of the decay fo a free peasantry. The large owner was more likely to aim at teh self-sufficiency of his estate and to maintain his own slave craftsmen, or to go not to the nearest town for what he needed, but to that which specialized in the product required, often to Rome  345},
  note = {In Hügelgebieten weniger latifundien It is likely that in the hilly country latifundia had not so far displaced small farms as in many other parts of Italy. The coastal plain south of the Liris is fertile and geographically belongs rather with Campania; no one supposes it was 'empty'  346},
  note = {Getreideanbau nicht aufgegeben I believe that cereal cultivation was not extinct in any large part of Italy, though this is not the plcae to give reasons. However, it is beyond question taht Rome depended on imports and not on local supplies of wheat; at beast some other towns in Latium have grown their own grain. Probably Strabo was thing of wine, fruit, vegetrables, poultry, eggs, game and the like.   346},
  note = {Viele Villen Moreover, in many of the hill towns and in parts of the coast there were numerous villas of the rich, for instance in the Alban hills, Tusculum, Tibur, Praeneste, the Ager Laurens, Ardea, Antiun, Tarracina, even close to the Pontine marshes, as well as at Forminae and Anagnia. Here there must have been hordes of servants ministering to the comfort and dignity of the owners. [...] It is most unlikely that villas on rich land in, for instance, Tibur or Tusculum did not make handsome returns, or that a large part of the noble wines of Latium was not produced on the estates of the rich and noble.  [..] The profusion of villas does not entail a dearth of people, though the land was owned by a few.  347},
  note = {Kaum noch große Städte Old Latium had once been thick with towns, villages no doubt in size, that now disappeared. perhaps this was partly due to synoecisms, like that legendary union of Alba and Rome. That process would only have meant that the surviving centres became larger. But there were clearly no large towns left in the neighbourhood of Rome. Tibur and Praeneste were surely the most substantial, yet Horace could call Tibur ''vacuum'', perhaps only meaning 'tranquil' in contrast with 'Roma regia'. Praeneste was notable for the number of commercial and craft collegia recorded in Republican inscriptions, and some Praenestine families seem to have been engaged in business in the East. Yet its territory, after Sulla, is said to have fallen into hands of latifondisti.  347 f},
  note = {Viele Städte verlassen According to Cicero hardly anyone was left in the vicinity of Labicum or Gabii or Bovillae; he contrasts Veii, Fidenae, and Collatia, and even Lanuvium, Aricia, and Tusculum with the relatively large towns of Campania, and the municipes of Tusculum, splendid but few, with the numerous citizens of Atina. For Horace Gabii and Fidenae represent teh acme of desertion. At gabii, according to Dionysius of Halicarnassus, all taht remained were a few inns by the roadside; similarly Lucan describes the old Alban and Laurentum lands as ''rus vacuum'', where you would find none except the night-bound traveller. And yet it is obvious that Gabii with its important quarries was far from deserted. Our witnesses simply disregarded the slaves.   => Wichtig für Heiligtümer  Quellen: 	Cic. de leg agr. II 96 	Cic. Planc 23 und 21 	Horaz Ep. I, II, 7 	Dion. Harl. IV, 53 und VII, 394  348},
  note = {Ansieldungen in Latinischen Städten If there is a substratum of truth in various statements in the Liber Coloniarum, the Graccan commissioners made allotments at Velitrae (238 L), and also at Verulae in the Hernican country (239), Sulla at Aricia (230), Bovillae (231), Castrimoenium (233), Gabii (234), and Tusculum (238), the triumvirs at Formiae (234), Setia and Signia (237), and Ulubrae (239), and Augustsu at Fundi (234). An allusion to the work of quinqueviri at Praeneste (236) might refer to Sulla's well-attested colony there, or to an attempt by the land commissioners appointed under Caesar's law of 59 to break up the latifundia which had grown there since Sulla's times.  349},
  note = {In Latium viele Sklaven, wenig Freie In my view old Latium was not desolate, nor abandoned to pasturage, nor ruined by malaria. But it was mainly a land of estates owned by the few. The population may not have been smaller in the time of Cicero that in that of Cincinnatus, but it was mainly composed of slaves; the free inhabitants were few, and it is this which is relevant to the reliability and interpretation of the census returns.  350},
  note = {Selbst aufgabe des Status durch die municipia We know from a celebrated passage of Cicero that Latin cities (which were formally sovereign in their internal concerns) were bound only by Roman laws wich they adopted ('fundi facti'), and indeed that it was by adopting the Lex Iulia of 90 that the allies acquired the Roman citizenship; that law made teh eligible, but it was only by their own act taht they converted their right into reality. Gellius makes out that even in his own day municipia were in the same position. Some jurist would accept this as correct; more probably Gellius misunderstood Hadrian, who was perhaps distinguishing between the status of municipia and that of colonies in a remote past.  532},
  key = {Brunt846}
}

Un periodo di notevole prosperita, connessa in parte con i traffici in Oriente - testimoniati da iscrizioni di Presnestini al Delo e in Asia Minore - si puo notare negli ultimi decenni del II sec. a giudicare almeno dalle grandiose costruzioni che trasformarono allora l'aspetto urbanistico della citta.   note = {Fortuna Duale Gottheit Il culto si articola dunque in due forme diverse: una divinita matronale, ctonia, alla quale e collegato l'oracolo, e una divinita vergine, guerriera  III},
  note = {Tempel dominiert Stadt Planung La sua posizione, a conclusione e dominio della intera ristrutturazione urbanistica della citta, che probabilmente e stata centrata sul tempio, sottolinea l'enorme importanza che si annetteva a questo culto.  IX},
  note = {Villen in der Stadt - 2. Jh Numerosi sepolcri e ville sono ancora visibile nei dintorni della citta. La piu notevole di queste ultime e quella presso il cimitero, che i bolli laterizi permettono di datare in eta adrianea. La scoperta, qui avvenuta, dell'Antinoo Braschi mostra che si tratta di una villa imperiale certamente appartenuta ad Adriano. Forse qui mori uno dei figli di Marco Aurelio.  IX},
  note = {Griechischer Kunst Einfluss im 2. Jh v. Chr. Quando, alla fine del II sec. a. C., siamo in grado di individuare di nuovo un'intensa attivita artistica, con la ristrutturazione urbanistica della citta e la ricostruzione del santuario, appare chiaro che si tratta dell'opera di architetti e artistis ellenistici: sono scultori greci gli autori delle statue del santuario, e greci d'Egitto realizzano i grandi mosaici del Nilo e dei pesci, che ornano due edifici pubblici vicini al foro.   note = {Kapitols Tempel Tra gli edifici piu importanti del foro e un tempio, che occupava il centro della piazza, e i cui resti sono inglobati nella cattedrale di S. Agapito (muro in opera quadrata di tufo visibile sulla facciata della chiesa). La posizione di questo edificio fa pensare a un tempio equivalente al Capitolium delle colonie e municipi romani. Il soggetto di questo mosaico, unito alla scoperta di due piccoli obelischi di eta claudia di fronte all'edificio, ha reso possibile la sua identificazione con il tempio di Iside..   note = {Topographie Ragioni politiche e amministrative hanno piu volte mutato i confini di questo Lazio: inizialmente esso fu solo la zona piana, limitata dai colli Tiburtini, Prenestini e Albani e comprendeva venticinque chilometri litoranei a sud della foce del Tevere e non piu di sei a nord: in termini attuali, la costa tra l'aeroporto Leonardo da Vinci e Tor Vaianica. Questo era il ''Latium Vetus''. In seguito terre furono tolte alig Equi, agli Ernici, ai Volsci e gali Aurunci e si chiamarono ''Latium Novum''. All'epoca di Augusteo, nel riordinamento generale di tutta l'italia, del Lazio antico e nuovo e della confinante Campania fu fatta una sola regione, la prima: ma colli Tiburtini e anche l'antichissima latina Tibur, furono aggregati alla quarta regione, che prendeva il nome dai Sabini e dai Sanniti.  083},

  note = {Forunta Heiligtum profitiert durch Straße => Umbau der Stadt (?) Alla celebrita del santuario aveva certo giovata anche il fatto di essere posto lungo la via che legava il Lazio etrusco e le zone etrusche della Campania; talche Preneste, gia nel VII secolo a. Veneratissim per tutta l'antichita; l'affluenza di fedeli faceva dire al filosofo Carneade - quello reso celebre piuttosto che dall sua sapienza dalla ignoranz di don Abbondio - che in nessun altro paese piu che a Preneste aveva visto fortunata la Fortuna.  091 f},

La lega albense aveva avuto il suo epicentro sul monte Cavo, presso Albano - il profilo caratteristico si staglia azzurro sull'orizzonte sudorientale di Roma - dove era un santuario di Giove, detto appunto Albano. Pressoche impossibile e rintracciare l'origine di questo culto e di questa federazione di genti che nella venerazione di un dio comune ritrovavano una solidarieta tribale; ma il comune sentimento religioso duro nei Latini sino ai tempi storici e Roma continuo a celebrare quelle ferie latine che, forse dai tempi preistoria, avevano veduto riunite sul monte Cavo le genti dei colli circostanti e della sottostane pianura.  092},

  LCCN = {UD Praneste 17500},
  note = {Ewige Rivalen But while these isolated outburst of jealousy showed teh ill feeling of Rome toward Praeneste, there is yet a stronger evidence of the fact that Praeneste had been in early times more than Rome's equal, for throught the entire subsequent history of the aggrandizement of Rome at the expense of every town in the Latin League, there runs a bitterness which finds expression in the slurs cast upon Praenste, an ever-recurring reminder of the centuries of ancient grudge. Often in Roman literature Praeneste is mentioned as the typical country town. Her inhabitants are laughed at because of their bad pronunciation, despised and pitied because of their characteristic combination of pride and rusticity. Yet despite the dwindling fortunes of teh town she was able to keep a treaty with Rome on nearly equal terms until 90 b. C., the year in which the Julian law was passed.  064},
  note = {Praeneste als Kolonie Sullas As a colony, Praeneste has a different history from that of any other of the colonies founded by Sula. Because of her stubborn defence, and her partisanship for Marius, her walls were razed and her citizens murdered in numbers almost beyond belief. Yet at a later time, Sulla with a revulsion of kindness quite characteristic of him, rebuilt the town, enlarged it, and was most generous in every way. The sentiment which attached to the famous antiquity and renown of Praeneste was too strong to allow it to lie in ruins. Further, in colonies the most characteristic officers were the quattuorviri. Praeneste, again different, shows no trace of such officers.  066},
  key = {Magoffin854}
}

  note = {Romanisierung und Urbanisierung Der Wandel der Städte vom 3. bis 1. Jh. (Cosa, Norba, Alba Fucens) beweist die Vorbildhaftigkeit Roms, die bis zur Erscheinunge der Selbstromanisierung von Städten (Bantia) führt. Auch der Weg für die lokale Aristokratie, über Stiftungen zum Bürgerrecht und damit in die führende Schicht in Rom selbst zu gelangen, läßt sich im Städtebild belegen. Romanisierung und Urbanisierung sind hier fast synonym zu setzen.  337},
  note = {Kaiserkult Verbindendes Element Tempel des Kaiserkults übernehmen zunehmend die Funktion des Kapitols, das einstmals Sysmbol der Verbindung zwischen Rom und der Pflanzstadt war. Nicht ganz klar wird, ob hier historische Veränderungen und fallweise Abweichungen von einem historischen Modell festgehalten oder Gegebeispiele zu einer modernen wissenschaftstheoretischen Idealtypsik gemeint sind. Von Nutzen ist in jedem Fall, daß hier nachdrücklich wiederholt wird, daß bestimmte bauliche Einrichtungen (z. B. capitolia) nicht den Status einer Stadt belegen, sondern als coloniatypische Bauten im Vorgriff oder in der Hoffnung auf eine Statusanhebung errichtet sein können.  338},

  LCCN = {UD Allg 15200},
  note = {socii ''überleben'' als Stadt besser Archaeology has a long way to go in defining these political changes in material terms. The fact of the matter, however, is that they applied to a comparatively restricted number of towns, and the main importance is that, for the time being at least, they ensured the survived of many pre-existing Latin urban communities in the new order of things. Many other centres were not so lucky.  068},
  note = {Frühe Straßen nach Ziel benannt The Via Ostienesis, which led to the maritime colony of Ostia (founded in the fourth century BC), must habve been on such; another was the Via Praenestina, which headed eastwards to the important centre at Praeneste (modern Palestrina). One indication of the early daet of these roads is the fact that they came to be known only by their destinations.  127},
  note = {Römische Religion und Nemi The roots of Roman religion are complex, but it is clear that it devloped very much in parallel with the Latin and Italic parts of the peninsula. [...] It is clear that many sanctuaries initially consisted of no more than an open-air grove, in Latin a lucus or nemus, where the tables were displayed on a tree. One of the most famous was close to modern Nemi (the name is a diret survival of nemus), situated on the side of a lake in the Alban hills, to the south of Rome. [...] The sanctuary began very early and was a religious centre for cities of the Latin Leageu; when the king Servius Tullius founded an altar to Diana on the Aventine Hill in Rome in about 550 BC it was with a clear political motive - to show, in Livy's words, that 'Rome, by common consent, was the capital city'. The sanctuary at Nemi remained popular, however, particularly amongst women, who associated her with childbirth and healing and who paid their honours with great processions.  => Livius 1, 45, 2-3  177},
  note = {Heiligtümer für religiösen Entwicklung wichtig Sanctuaries like Nemi and Lavinium, or Pietrabbondante for the Samnites, doubtless played a major role in formulating early religious traditions, and so, too, did the Etruscans.  179},
  note = {Große Anzahl an Heilkultheiligtümern This much is clear from terracottas depicting parts of the human body, often at life size, that were dedicated by the afflicted at healing sanctuaries. More than one hundred sanctuaries are known, the majority in western-central Italy, and while not all were presided over by Asclepius (for other dieties like Diana at Nemi assumed curative powers), it is nevertheless clear that the inspiration for the idea stemmed ultimately from the temple in Rome itself.  => Heilkulte zeitliches Phemomän  182},
  note = {Ende der Terrakotta Weihungen unklar However, the vogue for dedicating terracottas somewhat mysteriously comes to an end about the time of the collapse of the Republic. Just what happend at the sanctuaries is still largely unclear; but they can nevertheless be seen as part of a much wider process that spread temples and shrines everywhere.  182},
  note = {Heiligtümer in Latium In Italy these are matched by the great temple complexes of Latium, which include a theatre, imposing porticoes and terraces, and fine staircases. A comparatively modest example is to be found at Gabii, built in the second century BC, less than twenty kilometres to the east of Rome. Very much grander is the huge terraced sanctuary fo Fortuna Primigenia at Praeneste (modern Palestrina), where construction work seems to have begun in the second half of the second century BC; or the temple of Hercules Victor at Tivoli, of around 50 BC. These great sanctuaries, to which could be added examples outside Latium, like the temple of Jupiter Anxur, perched high on a hill at Terracina, represent the pinnacle of Republican religious building.  182 f},
  note = {Wiederaufbau von Heiligtümern As Horace wrote in his Odes, published about 23 BC: 'you will pay for the sins of your ancestors, Romans, until you repair the ruined temples of the gods, and the images begrimed in smoke'  185},
  note = {Kaiserkult als Identifikationsmerkmal der neuen ''Schiicht'' For most Italians, it was teh numen or spirit of the emperor that became a focus for worship, rather than Augustus himself, and there was no doubt much cynicism about the quasi-divinity of a living person, particularly amongst the educated rich. It is best summed up by Seneca's biting satire about the emperor Claudius, who arrives in heaven do discover that he has been changed into a pumpkin rather than a god. But a huge number of inscriptions to the Numen Augusti, the divine will auf Augustus, are known, and the imperial cult, largely run by ex-slaves, very rapidly became established during the emperor's lifetime.  186},
  key = {Potter860}
}

  school = {},
  ISBN = {},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {Z 425},
  note = {Bundesgenossenkreig Its subject is the Social War of 91-89 BC, an event whose importance in the history of ancient Italy it would be difficult to overestimate;  203},
  note = {Gründe für Bundesgenossenkrieg In these pages K. argues that the involvement of the Italian allies in the process of Roman imperialism made them increasingly conscious of their inferior status, but at the same time gave them an increased sense of their own worth. This heightened awareness coincided with a marked deterioration in the postion of the allies in the lsat decades of the second century BC; in the Gracchan age the Italians' demand for the Roman citizenship was first articulated at Rome, and became a major political issue. Stated thus, the general thesis is unexceptionable and probably right; [...] ..that the Latins were at the forefornt of Italian agitation in the 120s; and that the revolt of Fegellae had the full support of its Latin ruling class (here K. takes issue with the idea that the Latin rulers of Fregellae remained loyal to Rome in a revolt staged by Oscan-speaking immigrants). On the other hand, I do not think he gives sufficient emphasis to the fact that the allied communities were indirectly taxed by Rome in the form of military contributions which they had to finance themselves, or that the vast increase in military expenditure that would fall on the Romans if the allies were given citizenship must have been a powerful reason for their resistance to allied demands. Moreover, only the Romans gained from provincial tax revenues... [...] The allies got none of this, but they must have seen what was happening.  203},
  note = {Bürgerrecht erst später ''aktiv'' This means that Sulla, so far from giving the Italians what they wanted, effectively disfranchised theme - an d it was not until  the revolution of 70/69 that they obtained full political rights. This is the view of scholars such as Wiseman, whom K. cites with approval and he himself disarmingly admits taht the Italians were unable to exercise the rights they had 'obtained' until 70/69.  204},
  note = {Acker Fragen der Italiker unklar What is not discussed, but remains fundamental, is the question of the rights of Italians in respect of Roman ager publicus. He does not say whether he thinks that the allies who were occupying ager publicus were threatened with wholesale eviction by the land commission, nor does he properly set out the vexed problem of whether the recipients of land allotments under the law were to include non-Roman Italians.  205},
  key = {Cornell861}
}
