  URL = {http://books.google.de/books?id=8qvY8pxVxcwC&lpg=PA209&ots=nPJ7Z71sj1&dq=Cities%20and%20Urbanisation%20in%20Ancient%20Italy&lr&pg=PA212#v=onepage&q&f=true},
  LCCN = {ULB Z 4' 51/124 (21)},
  note = {Topographischer Rahmen This paper deals with city-states in Old Latium (Latium Vetus), the coastal region of Tyrrhenian central Italy bounded to the north-west by the rivers Tiber and Anio and to the east by the Apennines, the Monti Lepini and the Pomptine Marshes. These boundaries, however, are to some extent artifical and even potentially misleading in the present context. Although Old Latium represents a culturally unified region inhabited by people who wer linguistically distinct (i. e. Latin-speaking), and who formed a selfconscious ethnic group (the Latini - ''Latins''), its historical development cannot be studied in isolation, and the institutions and culture of its city-states can only be understood in a wieder Italian context and with reference to neighbouring societies and cultures. [...] ..and in particular into the region to the south-east of Old Latium which writers of the imperial period called ''Greater Latium'' (Latium adiectum).  209},
  note = {Beginn der Stadt werdung ...it is possible to set the beginnings of Rome as a city-state in the second half of the seventh century BC at the latest; and it is probable, though less certain, that the emergence of other city-states in Latium can be dated around the same time. [...] During the sixth and fifth centuries the city-states of Latium maintained their independence but were organised in a league allied to Rome. But during the fourth century they began to be absorbed, one by one, into the evergrowing Roman state. [...] Others followed in 338 BC after the so-called Latin War, when the Latin Legue was dissolved and teh majority of the remaining cities were incorporated as municipia. A handful retained their independence as Latin cities untill the first century BC, bit from 338 BC onwards Latin status meant that the city in question had a distinctive relationship wiht Rome rather than being part of a wider ethnic community.  209},
  note = {Topograhie Latium Vetus is a coastal plain intersected by spurs extending from the Apennines towards the sea. These outcrops provided defensible hilltop sites tath were occupied by the first human settlements. During the early Iron Age many hill villages were established, often forming clusters on adjacent sites.  211 f},
  note = {Staat und Stadt Werdung These changes are important because they mark the formation of a self-conscious community and the operation of a centralised political authority; it is to this period, without doubt, that we can trace back the earliest political, military and religious institutions that are recorded in literary sources. It can be said that, during the later seventh and sixth centuries BC, the communities of Old Latium underwent two simultaneous processes - of urbanisation and state-formation. The result was the city-state.  212},
  note = {Untergang bzw. Fall der Städte in Latium in der Republik Some of these places continued to exist as functioning city-states (municipia) into the imperial period, but many declined. The coastal cities from the mouth of the Tiber to Tarracina (Lavinium, Ardea, Antium and Circeii) all disappeared, in spite of efforts to revive them; Nero's colony as Atntium, for example, was a failure (Tac. Ann, 14, 27). Others, including Gabii, Cora and Norba, were deserted by the time of Augustus, and even those that survived wer reduced in size. The decline of the cities of latium can be explained by a combination of factors, including the effects of warfare (many suffered badly in the civil wars of the 80s BC, especially Praeneste and Norba), and of malaria, which was endemic in the region (though there is no reason to think that it became more pestilential in the late Republic and Principate). In general the most important cause muste have been the centripetal pull of the ever-growing city of Rome, which gradually reduced the surrounding regions to a vast suburbium. Increasingly the territories of the Latin cities were absorbed by large private estates, and the slaves who worked them replaced the free population.  214},
  note = {Geringe Größe von Praeneste und Lavinium Of the other Latin cities only Lavinium, and less certainly Praeneste, are known to have had city walls in the sixth century; at Lavinium the earlier earth-works were replaced by a wall of squared blocks of cappellaccio wich apparently surrounded teh entire inhabited area. The walled circuit of Praeneste, constructed in crude polygonal masonry, is of uncertain date, but may go back to the sixth century or even earlier. Praenste and Lavinium were relatively small places, however, whose urban centres measured between 30 and 50 hectares; they cannot be compared to Rome, which was of a differente order of magnitude (the area enclosed within the Republican [''Servian''] wall is 427 ha)  218},
  note = {Bauboom nach Bundesgenossenkrieg in Samnium und Co In the later Roman Republic, a walled enceinte, complete with towers and formal gateways, was an essential symbol of city status. In Samnium and the central Apennin districts teh process of urbanisation began after the Social War, when all Italy as incorporated into the Roman state, and organised into self-governing municipia. The process was accompanied by rapid urban development and a spate of public building, and in in particular by the construction, often for the first time, of city walls.  218},
  note = {gemeinsame Heiligtümer der Latiner Common sanctuaries were also to be found at Aricia, Tusculum, Ardea, and perhaps Gabii; and at Rome a temple to Diana on the Avetine was founded by Servius Tullius as a common shrine for all the Latins.  219},
  note = {Heiligtümer nicht Zentrum von Bünden More generally we may note that the many common sanctuaries throughout Latium (it is quite conceivable, not to say probable, that every latin city had a common shrine and a festival in which all the Latins took part) cannot all have been the centres of political federations, and the chances are that non of them were.  219},
  note = {Sklavenfreilassung mit Bürgerrechten in allten Latinischen Städten However, in later colonies and municipia, including those with Latin rights, the citizen body included freedmen, and it is not impossible that this was part of an ancient Latin heritage rather than a secondary feature borrowed from Rome. Naturally there can be no certainly about this, but there is one small indication that other aspects of the Roman law of slavery were applied generally throughout Latium Vetus.  221},
  note = {Stadtpolitik in Latium gleich That is to say, the same general principles applied everywhere, although there were differences of detail between one city and another. Every latin city-state, it seems, was governed by a republican system and dominated by an aristocratic oligarchy. The standard features were annual magistracies, elected by a popular assembly, and a senate or council of former office holders. One rather striking fact is that republican governments seem to have existed in latin communities from the earliest times, and there is very little sign of an earlier stage of monarchy, as at Rome.  221},
  note = {rex sacrorum in Tibur On the other hand, in later times a number of Latin cities had a rex sacorum (apart from Rome, they include Lanuvium, Tibur and Tusculum), a priest who carried out religious duties formerly performed by a real king. [...] The likelihood is, then, that the city-states of Latium were once ruled by kings, but that in most cases they were replaced by republican magistrates long before this change occurred at Rome.  => Hätte dann nicht auch der rex nemorensis eine ähnliches Amt als Vorgänger haben müssen?  222},
  note = {Politische Struktur latinischer Städte The most distinctive Latin magistracy is the annually elected dictatorship, which is found at Lanuvium, Aricia, Tusculum, Nomentum and Fidenae. Elsewhere we find colleges of two praetors, as at Praenete, Lavinium, Cora and Velitrae. Aediles and quaestors are found at some of these places, and should probably be seen as subordinate magistrates carrying out particular tasks, as at Rome. Censors are attested at Tibur and Praeneste, whereas elsewhere in Latium the normal chief magistrates carried out censuses every five years and bore the additional title of quinquennales.  Inschriften für Magistrate in den Städten Praeneste:  	CIL XIV, 2890, 2902, 2960, 2994, 2999, 3008 Lanuvium:  	CIL XIV, 2097, 2110, 2121; 	CIL I2 1428, 2121 Aricia:  	CIL XIV, 2169, 2213  222},
  note = {Priesterämter in der hand von wenigen ..namely that the magistracies and priesthoods were largely monopolised by a narrow circle of ruling families. The same is true of the the priesthoods, which were filled by members of the same elite, and frequently by the same individuals; as at Rome, a successful career would consist of a combination of religious and political offices. [...] Finally, it is evident that each Latin city also had its Senate and popular assembly.  => Indiz für das Interesse einzelner, einflussreicher Familien an den Heiligtümern?  222},
  note = {Oskischer Einfluss in Tibur und Praeneste The magisterial title 'censor' seems to be of Oscan origin (Osc. keenzstur), and is attested among the Samnites and hernici; it was adopted only in communities in eastern Latium (Principally Tibur and Praeneste) that were under strong Oscan influence.  224},
  key = {Cornell863}

  note = {Romanisierung Komplex By the end of the first century BC, however, many of these regional differences in levels of urban settlement had disappeared and regionalised urban cultures were being eroded. Undoubtedly the growing political and cultural domination of Rome was an influential factor in this process of homgenisation, but teh relationship between Romnaisation and urban change is a complex one. A simple diagnosis of 'Romanisation' is insufficient, not least because it ignores changes both in indigenous cultures and in the idea of waht it meant to be Roman.  064},
  note = {Selbst Romanisierung in Kampanien nach Bundesgenossenkrieg The cities of Campania, again a region with a strong tradition of urban life which antedated the Roman conquest by several centuries, undergo changes in the decades after teh Social War which are best explained in terms of acculturation and response to Roman policy. In this case, the impetus seems to come from within the cities themselves - from a pro-Roman elite, rather than being imposed by Rome itself.  069},

  note = {Badeanlagen primär in Kampanien gebaut Baths were alos a popular structure during the early Empire. Many structures antedate the crucial period of acculturation after teh Social War, and teh tradition of baths as part of Campanian culture was of long standing.  071},
  note = {Theater aufwendiger bau It is only with the Augustan period that theatres are constructed in any significant number, and, as the figures show, that number was considerably large, given that a theatre was an building which represented a major outlay of resources either by a state or by an individual.  => Gilt das ebenfalls für die Theater in bzw. an den Heiligtümern?  072},
  note = {Nach Bundesgenossenkrieg eigener Wille des Wandels During the third and second centures BC, and in post-Social War Samnium, the transformation in settlement patterns and urban topography is clearly linked with teh exercise of Roman power, but during the first century BC and the first century AD the driving force comes much more from the local communities of Italy.  073},
  note = {Senatoren bauen wenig öffentliche Gebäude The converse is also true, that there is no link between the municipal families which gained senatorial status and those which were prominent municipal benefactors. [...] It is possible that senatorial benefactions of all types were prompted not so much by local contracts and patriotism, but by the formal legal position of Patronus of the community, which carried well defined obligations.  074 f},
  note = {Prunkgebäude in municipien als Ausdrucksform der lokalen Elite Whatever teh motive for large-scale building, on either a public or a private basis, it was not, apparently, social and political mobility in the wider Roman context, and on this basis it is probable that patterns of public building in municipal Italy are reflecting the world view of the municipal elite, not that of the senatorial class or the emperor.  => Gilt dies genauso für Heiligtümer?  075},
  note = {Prunkvolle Gebäude und Kaiserkult als ''kampfmittel der Städte'' A more important motivation for urban change may have been status and competition within local and regional hierarchies of communities. [...] More generally, the imperial cult seems to have been used to express this competitive instinct between cities.  075},
  note = {Selbst Romanisierung der lokalen Eliten Roman forms of urban life seen to have been adopted voluntarily by the municipal elites as an idiom for expressing civic identity, to some extent in the early first century BC, bit overwhelmingly in the aftermath of teh civil wars, when a whole new range of building types, many relating to the imperial cult, were introduced.  076},

Oktober 186, der als Rundschreiben der Consuln an die Bundesgenossen in Italien verschickt wurde. [...] Die Durchführung der Bestimmungen wird in einem entscheidenden Punkt, der Frage der Dispenserteilung von den festgelegten Bestimmungen, direkt römischen Institutionen übertrage, und zwar dem Stadtpraetor, dem die Hinzuziehung des Senasts mit eine mQuorum von 100 Senatoren auferlegt wird.   note = {Politisches Eingreifen ...daß Rom die Gestaltung von Politik nun auch auf einem Gebiet zufiel, das die ursprüngliche militärische Ebene der Zusammenarbeit verließ und innenpolitische Probleme der Bundesgenossen betraf. Diese Aktivitäten als eine reine Demonistration römischer macht gegenüber den italischen Staaten aufzufassen wäre ebenso verfehlt wie eien Betrachtung auf der ebene der politischen Moral oder unter der Alternative einer eher mehr oder eher weniger wohlwollenden Italienpolitik  112},

  note = {Selbstverständnis von Händlern als Römer Während [Anm. Griechisch] Pwmaios [Anm. Romaois] durchweg den einzelnen Italiker kennzeichnet, nennen sich mehrere Italiker als Gruppe nicht [Anm. Pluralform] sondern immer Italikoi [Anm. Griech], seltener Italkoi [Anm. Griech] [...] An dieser Art der Eigenebenennung ist zweierlei bemerkenswer: zum einen, daß sic hdie aus Italien stammenden Personen überhaupt anders denn als Bürger ihrer eigenen Heimatstadt benannt und demnach so etwas wie eine neue gemeinsame identität entwickelt haben, und zum anderen, daß dies über den Römerbegriff und nicht über den Italikerbegriff erfolgt ist. 'Italiker' ist eine Ausweichbegriff, der - im Gegensatz zu den Grabinschriften - an Stätten der Geselligkeit, des Kults und der Repräsentation, auf Weihinschriften, zur Anwendung kam, wohl um durchreisende römische Magistrate oder andere Personen aus der politisch oder ökonomischen Führungsschicht Roms nicht bedenklich zu stimmen.  117},
  note = {Selbstbewußtsein der Bundesgenossen römisch Die Bundesgenpssen entwickelten ein neues, ein römische Selbstverständnis. Es speigelte sich darin der Erfahrungsgehalt von Jahrzehnten wieder, in denen mehr und mehr öffentliche Aufgaben auf Rom übergegangen waren. Dazu parallel verdichteten sich die Beiehungen in Italien auch in den nciht von Staaltichen Aktivitäten geprägten Lebensbereichen, und die Lebensformen näherten sich einandern an. Das Selbstverständnis orientierte sich an einem gemeinsamen Personenverband, der mit dem Römerbegriff gefaßt wurde.  118},
  note = {Blick der Römer unverändert ..daß die Römer die dem System angehörenden Personen unter demselben Blickwinkel betrachteten wie noch ihre Vorfahren im 4. und 3. jahrhundert, nämlich entweder als Bürger ihrer jeweiligen Staaten (Volterraner, Tarentiner usf.) oder unter den Personenstandskategorien Römer, Latiner und Bundesgenossen. Für ihren Herrschaftsraum auf der Apenninenhalbinsel, den sie als geostrategisch, villeicht auch geopolitisch Einheit empfanden, haben sie dne 'Italia'-Begriff in Anwendung gebracht. Anders die Bundesgenossen: Sie haben (wobei freinlich einmal mehr Ausnamhen die Regel bestätigen) ein neus Selbstverständnis entwickelt, das sich dann entsprecehdn im Bundesgenossenkrieg niederschlug.  119},
  note = {Bundesgenossenkrieg 'Italia' wurde jedoch nur für die kurze Zeit des Bundesgenossenkrieges zu einem politischen Begriff: Das 'Italia' der Bundesgenosen - greifbar am behelmten Kopf der Italia auf den bundesgenössischen Münzen, die dem behelmten Kopf der Roma auf den römischen Münzen zum Verwechseln ähnlich sah - war inhaltlich eben auch römisch.  120},
  key = {Hantos884}

Jh Il fatto che una nota cista di Bruxelles rappresenti la preparazione di un pranzo ci sembra una testimonianaza, forse intorno alla meta del III, dell'importanza dei vari collegia che definiscono la plebe prenestina. Non penso infatti che l festino raffigurato sia una qualsiasi festino, ma un pranzo di circostanza, forse di qualche associazione.  139},
  note = {Sklaven ähnliche zu Capua freigelassen La promozione dei liberti a Praeneste e un processo che avviene  sulle orme di quanto e avvenuto a Roma. Flavius, scriba e figlio di libertus del seguito di Ap. Claudius. Legata a Roma, Praeneste non sembra offrire un modello di ''urbs'' molto diverso da quello di Capua con la sua ''multiudo incolarum libertinorumque et istitorum poificumque''.  140},
  note = {Soziale Veränderung in Praeneste Mi chiedo dunque se questa cista, a suo modo, non rifletta per la sua destinataria, i motivi di ''concordia'' e di ''temperatio ordinum'' che, riferiti al mito fondatore della citta, accompagnano, a Praeneste come a Roma, l'evoluzione della societa e il nuovo assetto patrizio-plebeo raggiunto all'inizio del III secolo. Malgrado tutte le difficolta che lo studio della necropoli presenta, questa prospettiva dinamica, dalle piu antiche formule del ''nomen Latinum'' alle piu moderene forme della colonizzazione e dell'imperialismo di Roma, colta attraverso lo studio dei monumenti figurati, sembra in grado di restituirci il senso della evoluzione sociale di Praeneste tra il IV e il III secolo.  145},

  note = {Bevölkerungsgröße und Überlieferungsverhältniss ..si puo calcolare che la popolazione di Praeneste raggiungesse, nel periodo qui considerato, i 15.000 abitanti circa (dei quali forse 5000 residenti nel capoluogo, il resto nei nove pagi del territorio).   note = {Cippi Oberklasse bis zum Aufkommen von Mausoloen Orbene, da un lato bisogna considerare che i Magulnii costituiscono una delle due o tre tre piu importanti famiglie magistratuali di Praenete; dall'altro, che se ci basassimo su argomenti del genere ne dovremmo dedurre la totale assenza di famiglie socialmente e politicamente rilevanti nella Praeneste di eta medio-repubblicana, dal momento che nessuna tomba neppure la piu ricca presentava all'esterno segnacoli diversi da questi ''modesti'' cippi iscritti. In realta, l'uso di amusolei di una certa imponenza - caratterizzati cioe da consistenti strutture esterne - e un fatto relativamente tardi nel corso della repubblica, e comunque non anteriore alla finde del II secolo a. C.: e cioe, non casualmente, contemporaneo alla scomparsa dei cippi iscritti.  256},
  note = {Primäre Phasen mit Cippi in base ai dati paleografici e morfologici possiamo infatti ripartire i coppi in due gruppi, appartenenti rispettivamente al IV-III e al II secolo a. C., con una discriminate sicura, che si puo fissare negli anni immediatamente successivi alla seconda guerra Punica: diciamo intnro al 190-180 a.C., data, come e noto, cruciale per la storia dell'Italie antica, in tutti i suoi aspetti.  257},
  note = {Abnahme in Richtung 2. Jh. Siamo in presenza, dunque, di una progressiva e sensibilissima diminuzione del numero dei cippi man mano che si scende dal III al II secolo.  257},
  note = {Produktions Rückgang? im 2. Jh la produzione di cistes e specchi (ma anche di avori e terracotte) scade qualitativamente e quantitativamente man mano che si scende lungo il III secolo, fino ad esaurirsi in un periodo che non dovrebbe in nessun caso scendere oltre gli inizi del II. Questo fenomeno e noto , e si riscontra in tutte le produzioni artigianali dell'Italia medio-repubblicana  258},
  note = {Rückgang der Oberschicht, Zunahme an Sklaven und Mittelschicht ..anche in alter citta dell'Italia peninsulare, e specialmente nei centri latini: la drastica riduzione, cioe, delle elites dirigenti, parallela al fenomeno di proletarizzazione delle ''classi medie'' costituite dai piccoli e medi proprietari e all'apparizione dell'ager publicus (che, come e noto, riguardo anche gli Italici, oltre ai Romani) e alla diffusione del modo di produzione schiavistico.  258},
  note = {Weniger Bedeutene Soziale Gruppen weniger Präsent i membri meno rappresentativi della societa (anche all'interno di un livello complessivamente molto alto) tendono ad essere meno presenti.  258 f},
  note = {Blüte im 2. Jh. La frenetica e grandiosa attivita edilizia che caratterizza la seconda meta, e in particolare l'ultimo quarto del II secolo (a Praeneste come altrove nella Italia peninsulare) e che si traduce per noi nella straordinara ricostruzione, nelle nuove forme della koine ellenistico-romana, non solo del santuario della fortuna Primigenia, ma in pratica di tutta la citta, si comprende solo all'interno d un tale contesto: economico, beninteso, man anche socio-politico, a sua volta legato a filo doppio al pieno dispiegarsi dell'imperialismo romano.  260},
  note = {Wenige, wichtige Familien Possiamo cosi ricostruire un gruppo di non piu di una dozzina di famiglie magistratuarli, che sembrano aver dominato la vita pubblica della citta a partire dalla seconda meta del II secolo a.C.: Anicii, Fabricii, Feidenatii, Magulnii, Merseii, Orcevii, Saufeii, Tampii, Tondeii, Vatronii (ai quali vanno aggiunit probabilmente Dindii, Geminii, Etrilii). [...] che ci era parso gia di intravvedere attraverso la documentazione della necropoli, ma addirittura il quasi-monopolio di due famiglie, i Saufeii soprattutto e, in misura minore, i Gaulnii, che tra l'altro sono spesso associate tra loro nella gestione e nel controlo dei lavori pubblici, soprattutto per quanto riguarda il tempio della Fortuna.  260},
  note = {Praeneste und Tiovli geographische und historische Sonderstellung La posizione strategica della citta, al confine orientale del Lazio, lungo un'importante via di transumanza e del tutto analoga a quella di Tivoli, e contribuisce a spiegare la storia particolare e ''separata'' dei due centri rispetto al resto del Latium Vetus.  261},
  note = {Viele Sklaven für landwirtschaft ab 2. Jh. Su questa base economica, riconoscibile fin dall'eta arcaica, si innesteranno successivamente, a partire dall'inizio dell II secolo, attivita connesse con lo sviluppo di un'agricoltura intensiva legata al mercato: si e gia visto che Livio ricorda, nel 198 a. C., la presenza a Preneste di numerosi schiavi, che tentarono di partecipare alla rivolta iniziata a Setia e proseguita a Norba e a Circei. [...] Importante senza dubbio e da considerare anche l'attivita artigianale, certamente gia fiorente in eta arcaica. Plinio ricorda la fama degli orefici prenestine, e importante dovette essere anche la produzione della ceramica fine da mensa a vernice nera:  262},
  note = {Fernhandel macht Reich, wollen aber keine Senatoren werden L'intensa attivia economica dei Prenestini nel corso della seconda meta del II secolo a.C. si ricava con sicurezza dalla presenza di numerosi di essi a Delo, dove riappaiono i nomi inconfondibili degli Anicii, Magulnii, Orcevii, Samiarii, Satricanii, Saufei, in contesi che sembrano da collegare con attivita mercantili (tra l'altro, probabilmente, con il commercio degli schiavi) e bancarie. E caratteristico che alcuni Magulnii, magistrati a Praeneste, possono identificarsi con altro presenti a Delo (come sembra di potre dedurre da corrispondenze onomastiche e cronologiche). Non e forse un caso che questa gens non abbia mai tentato, almeno a quanto ci risulta, la scalata al senato di Roma, e abbia limitato le sue attivita urbane alla banca, come sembra di poter dedurre da una tessera nummularia in cui appare un Antiocus Magulni servus.  263},
  note = {Praenestiner in anderen Städten L'esistenza di una vera e propria diaspora si ricava dall presenza di numerosi Prenestini non solo nelle citta del Lazio e della Campania, ma anche in lontani insediamenti coloniali come Aquileia.  263},
  note = {Saufeii im 2. Jh. im Senat (?) Come e noto, questo cognomen e utizzato principalmente dia Fulvii e dai valerii, ed e quindi possibile avanzare l'ipotesi che i Saufeii entrati in senato nel corso della meta del II secolo intrattenessero rapporti di clientela con una di queste due gentes. Un'iscrizione permette di dimostrare la verosimiglianza di tale ipotesi.  265},
  note = {Nach Plünderung durch Sulla keine alten Magistrate mehr Conosciamo bene le cause che travolsero le fortune della famiglia, insieme a quelle di tanti altri prenestini: l'assedio del'82, in conseguenti massacri e la fondazione della colonia sillana. Da allora in poi, non uno solo degli antichi nomi magistratuali apparita nei fasti della colonia: anche quando, a partire dal 49 a.C., i figli die proscritti saranno riammessi agli honores, pochissimi personaggi di origine locale troveranno posto tra i magistrati della citta.  266},
  key = {Coarelli888}
}

  note = {ZuLesen S. 110, 132, 142 => Praeneste Händler  S. 105-111 => Italischen Händler im Osten},
  LCCN = {ULB 66/5114},
  note = {Beginn der Wirtschaftlichen Ostexpansion The new age in the economic relationships of Italy and teh East begins later, withe the new political realtionships of the first half of the second century.  087},
  note = {Änderung der Händerschicht Firstly, trade increased greatly in volume; there are no trade returns, but the great and rapid increase in traders from Italy on Delos is by itself sufficient evidence. [..] That is to say, the Italiotes of the Greek cities in the extrem south were soon overtaken in importance by inhabitants of teh coastal region from the Surrentine peninsula to the Volturnus-Campania in the later sense - mainly Greek or Oscan by extraction, but now increasingly romanized (and with Roman and Latin colonists in their midst)  087},
  note = {Römer haben mehr Kapital für handel The new development of overseas trade sprang, in large measure, from Roman military success in the Mediterranean. Great new wealth came to Italy from war and conquest, and much passed into private hands. This caused a new demand for foreing commodities and provided more captial for foreign trade. Since the individuals enriched in this way will have been more often Romans than Italians, Roman citizens were probably the better placed, so far as capital was concerned, for overseas trade.  088},
  note = {Latiner ''gleiche'' Römern beim Handel But it was Roman and Latin - not Italian traders - who in 187 obtained immunity from port dues under the treaty granted by the Senate to Ambracia, and in 180 the merchants taken by king Genthius of Illyria in the Adriatic are described by Livy as Romans and Latins. [..] Latins, whether from Latium or the Latin colonies, socially assimilated to the Roman citizen body, are hardly to be considered, in this context, as very different from the Romans. They wer almost as well placed as Romans for enterprise overseas; as teh Senate acted, if spasmodically, to protect Roman traders, so it acted for Latins, and they were probably regarded by provincials in much the same light as Romans.  Quelle: 	Liv. 38, 44, 3 f 	Liv. 40, 42, 4 	Polybius, 11, 8, 2  091 f},
  note = {Fehlende Inschriften kein ''argument'' The fact that no epigraphic evidence is forthcoming before or after a certain date, may be due to those circumstances which sometimes destroy or bury beyond recovery the inscriptions of an entire period.  092},
  note = {Bereicherung ab Beginn 2. Jh. But, as has been seem, the enrichment of the Roman upper lcasses had begun with the opening of the second century and had gone far by its third decase, and Strabo is equally mistaken in not allowing fo piracy and slave trading before Diodotus Tryphon;  104},
  note = {Sklavenwirtschaft und Handel mit einander verbunden There can be little doubt thath the supply of captvives greatly increased in the two decades after the defeat of Perseus and the declaration of Delos as a free port; equally little doubt that the Roman upper classes (and some Italians) were already able to buy slaves on a greatly increased scale. [...] But to meet the increasing call for slaves with training, education ,accomplishments, or looks, traders turned to the East. [...] Thus the Delian slave-market was bound to create a body of resident slave-traders, Roman, Latin, Italian, or Italiote, and it is reasonable to connect, not only the mid-century Delain boom, but the prominence if [Anm. griechisch] romani in it, with the simultaneous increase in the demand for slaves and the supply.  105},
  note = {Tibur Familie The Cosinii, apparently native to Tibur, had interests at Puteoli and overseas in Greece and the East; likewise the Cluvii, important at Puteoli and in Campania in Cicero's day and possessing large interests in Asia, may have been established on Delos about 100.  109},
  note = {Handel seit Beginn 2. Jh. Names characteristically Roman/Latin form the largest single class, not surprisingly, since, as has been seen, both Romans and Latins were already active in eastern trade in the early second century.  109},
  note = {Sonderrolle Praenestes The Anicii on Delos, the Magulnii, Samiarii, Saufeii, and Satricanii, stand as a group on their own. These names seem to be identified with Praeneste. This city, with an ancient tradition of industry and long attached to its own Latin dialect, was still, in the second century, a proud and highly individual allied community, despite its proximity to Rome. It is not unlikely thath it had its own commercial life in this period, with families such as these playing a prominent part.  110},
  note = {Familien aus Praneste auch in Milet The Samiarii may have come about this period; a later inscription in the name of Miletus honours a boy of the family for character, success in artistic (or athletic) contest, and affection towards his Greek trainers. Samiarii were important in Pareneste and are found at Delos, and it is not fanciful to trace this young man's forbears from Praeneste to Delos and from Delos to Miletus.  Quellen: 	REG VI; 183 Nr. 26  134},
  note = {Praeneste in Clazomenae In 42 B.C. a rich negotiator fo Calzomenae - named Persius - had an embittered lawsuit in Asia with a proscribed exile, the Praenestine, Rupilius Rex, and, during the hearing before Brutus, outsmarted Rupilius 'pus atque venvenum'.  142},
  note = {Untergang von Delos Strabo says that Mithridates' general Archelaus made havoc of Delos in 87; there was no one on the island when the Romans recovered it, and since those days it hade been in a poor way. But, as epigraphic evidence indicates, Roman and other returned to Delos, and commercial, social, and religoious activities revived at least in some degree. [...] Since new communities have, in favourable circumstances, risen upon the ashes and ruins of the old, it may be that Strabo is exaggeratng the situation after 87, and that some alternative or further explantions should be sought ofr the extinction by 50 B.C. of Delos as a centre of Mediterranean commerce. [...] But it seems safe to believe that failure of the sea-borne supply of slaves, after 67, if it did not ruin a flourishing port, materially contributed to final collapse.  142 f},
  key = {Wilson892}
}

  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Architektur Gelesen Praeneste Republik Römisch Tibur},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},

  address = {Köln},
  publisher = {Böhlau},
  volume = {},

  LCCN = {},
  year = {1994},

  pages = {XII, 247},
  url = {},
  school = {Univ. Köln},
  ISBN = {3-412-09593-1},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {TA Arch 3 Nuenn},
  note = {Säulen in Praeneste Die je rund 5,50m breiten Rampen des Fortunaheiligtums in Palestrain waren mit großen polygonale Kalksteinplatten gepflastert. Die geschlossene Rückwand der Protiken bildete die talwärts gewandte Fassade der Rampen. Infolgedessen war die Säulenfassade nur von der Innenseite der Rampen beim Aufstieg sichtbar. Von der dorischen Portikus haben sich einige  schräg gearbeitet Travertinkapitelle erhalten, die einen lebhafte Vorstellung von der architektonischen Wirkung dieser den Hang hinaufführenden Säulenhallen vermitteln. Wie ungewöhnlich die Form schräg zum Hang liegender Säulen mit ihren schiefen Kapitellen nich auf den heutigen Betrachter wirtk, mag die Äußerung H. Lauters verdeutlichen, der von einer ''barbarischen Gefühllosigkeit'' der Baumeister spricht.  033},
  note = {Halbsäulen Architektur Es sind häufig die stark belasteten, weil das Fundament für die eigentliche Platzanlage dienenden Ebenen, deren tektonisch bedingte Schlichtheit und Geschlossenehit der Fassade durch eine Bogenreihe mit flankierenden Halbsäulen dekorativ aufgewertet und optisch geöffnet wird. [...] In gleicher Weise werden die Bogenreihen bei der Terrassenanlage von Palestrina und Tivoli angewandt. Ach in Palestrina übernahmen sie Verkleidungsfunktion für die in den natürlichen Geländeabfall eingelassenen Gewölbekonstruktionen, die Träger der Protikus Tripex des Heiligtums sind. Im Sinne einer gesteigerten Repräsentativität werden die tragenden Bogenkonstruktionen mit Säulen bzw. Halbsäulen als Blend- und Rahmenarchitektur verbunden. [...] Das eingeschossige Gliederungssystem der Anlagen von Terracina und Palestrina wird am Heiligtum des Herkules Victor in Tivoli auf eine doppelstöckige Anwendung des Arkaden-Halbsäulen-Motivs erweitert. Hier ist es nicht nur die tragende Ebene, die das angesprochene Verkleidungsprinzip aufweist, sondern auch die Portikus sebst verfügung über den Arkaden-Halbsäulen-Prospekt.  067},
  key = {Nünnerich-Asmus895}
}

  note = {Tarragona - Ähnlicher Stadt Komplex The skyline of the old Republican city had been transformed into a sanctuary site declaring the dedication of the people of Tarragon and the province of Tarraconencsis to Eome and its emperors. The format and connection between the spaces of the circus, the 'Provincial Forum' and the temple complex are reminiscent of the sanctuaries of Hercules at Tivoli or Fortuna at Palestrain, but with the important difference that the theatre was replaced with a circus.  103},
  note = {Heiligtümer als Teil der Urbanisierung This suggests that some sacred sites or sanctuaries [Anm. Pietrabbndate], where urbanism appears to have been developing in the second or early first century BC, may not have been able to sustain that urban development over a longer period. In any case, by far the largest sanctuaries with theatre complexes attached to them are found in cities: the famous sanctuary of Fortuna at Palestrina or the sanctuary of Hercules at Tivoli.  233},
  note = {Gabii - Nutzung bis in Spätantike The temple was constructed in the second century BC on a site that was already apparently of great antiquity as a sacred place and probably survived into late antiquity as a stopping-place for travellers.  => Straße  233 f.},
  note = {Gabii - Mythos Theater aufgeführt We may assume that some form of retelling of myths was included within the worship of Juno. This relationship between the ritual performance of a place's myths within a theatre and the worship of gods in temples was a key feature of the Roman city, not just in Italy but also in the Three Gauls and other provinces of the Roman Empire.  234},
  note = {Gabbi - nur heiligtum übrig The sanctuary set up over two centuries earlier continued to be maintained but did not manage to sustain an urban population in its localtiy because it was so close to Rome (nineteen kilometres) and consequently the population had looked to the capital for its urban life. It continued to exist within a suburban context. [...] The example if Gabii provides an important insight into the relationship of sanctuaries and urbanism: the sanctuary helped to sustain urbanism and was itself a focus of activity, but it did not alone constitute Roman urbanism. It is also a telling case of the effect of external factors on the evolution of a city.  236},
  key = {Laurence897}
}

Alföldy sieht durchaus die Schwierigkeiten, ide sch der abstrakten Fixierung eines Modells der römischen Gesellschaft der frühen Kaiserzeit und dessen Kommentierung auf verhältnismäßig engem Raum entgegenstellen.   note = {Oberschicht in Rom und den Städten Alföldy beton wie auch andere Analytiker der römischen Sozialstruktur die Kohaerenz einer ''Oberschicht'', die neben er domus principis, Angehörigen der familia Caesaris und reichen liberti vor allem die drei großen ordinesinsgesamt umfaßt. [...] Senatorenstand und Ritterstand sind genuin römische Gruppen, Senator und Ritter sind stets mit Rom verbunden, sie werden faktisch vom princeps in ihren Rang befördert oder in ihm anerkannt - auch aus ihm eliminiert. Die Priorität des politischen Bezugspunktes Rom ist in jedem Falle evident. Beim ordo decurionum dagegen überwiegen die lokalen Bindungen eindeutig; an der Ergänzng dieses Standes wirkt der princpes nicht mit. [...] Gegen die Überbetonung einer einheitlichen ''Oberschicht'' spricht ferner ein zweites Argument. Es ist bekannt, daß für die Aufnahme in den ordo decurionum in den einzelnen Städten völlig verschiedene Mindestvermögenssätze galten. [S. 216] Unter imperialen Maßstäben ist es einfach paradox, die Angehörigen der Stadträte der Hunderte von Kleinstädten der ''Oberschicht'' des Imperiums zuzuzählen, selbst wenn diese in einzelnen Punkten privilegiert waren.  215 f},
  note = {Mittelstand Die Einschätzung der Mittelschicht ist von fundamentaler Bedeutung für jedes Gesamtbild der römischen Gesellschaft. Es soll dabi nicht bestritten werden, daß es während verschiedener Phasen der römischen Geschichte starke Polarisierungen innerhalb der Gesellschaft gab, insbesonder zwischen Patriziern und Plebejern in der frühen Republik sowie zwischen honestionres und humiliores in der Spätantike.  216},
  note = {Gesellschaftsmodell Das Modell geht somit nur von Schichten aus. Dabei sei keineswegs bestritten, das Augustus Senat und Ritterschaft als Stände systematisch neu konstituiert hat. Dennoch weist die Gesellschaft des Principats so starke ständeübergreifende Tendenzen auf, daß die ordines nicht absolut gesetzt werden können.  218},

  note = {Bewertung It may be that the municipalities of Italy, forced into a notionally defensive alliance with Rome and robbed of their autonomy in foreing affairs, did not chafe under the yoke earlier as they would later, and no doubt their experience as allies were qualitatively different than those of the subject cities of Sicily. This is so regardless of whether we credit service by allied Italians alongside Roman citizens on military campaigns as having contributed in any way to political and cultural integration, and likewise credible even apart from the interested glosses placed n the history of Italian-Roman relations already in the principate.  040},
  note = {Tiefe problem am ende der republik A number of factors converged in the late republic to produce crises on multiple levels, Many were effecs of empire, which is to say, they were created or exacerbated by the rapid distortion of prior understandings of teh appropriate distribution of wealth in society and the role of wealth in politics brought about by the vast conquests undertaken across teh last century of teh republic. relations between Rome and its Italian allies were deeply impacted in theses processes.  042},
  note = {Übergang in die römische Aristokritie schwierig At the same time, no glass of cultural homogeneity or unarticulated convergence of class interests between municipal and Roman elites, such as undoubtedly existed by the late first century BC, coudl overcome the economic and pragmatic difficulties that prevented local Italian elites from entering the world of Roman aristocratic competition in meaningful numbers.  042},
  note = {Italien wird ''provinz'' Another important aspect of imperial social history, one less often discussed, describes the gradual reduction of Italy to the form of a province. How far we credit these indices depends in part, of course, on the role we assign to institutions of government in antiquity in the formation of subjectivity. This is very precisely a problem of social theory.  043},
  note = {Bundesgenossen Krieg wird nicht als solcher bezeichen the matter-of-fact account is symptomatic of the naturalization took place against a background in which violence was understood as a part of politics and not as an expression of a wider, deeper social ill. On another level, some years after what we call teh ''Social War'', it remained possible for the Romans, following their practice, to name that struggle after one of their opponents in it - as teh Bellum Marsicum, the War against the Maris, for example - and in so doing, to avoid naming it after its type, namely, a bellum cum sociis, a war against one's allies. The emergence of the term bellum sociale (social war) to denominate the Allied War of 90-88 BC the required a renaming of the general category from sociale to internum (domestic), to sit alongside gentile, servile, and civile (wars with foreign races, slaves, and civil wars). The refusla to confront the moral and political grievances at the heart of teh Social War - a refusal enabled by teh scapegoating implicit in the act of naming - did ultimately yield to social-historical reflection on the causes of that war, but it was the work of generations.  Quellen: 	Horaz Carm, 3, 14, 14-20 	Strabo 5, 4, 2 	Plin. nat. hist. 3, 70 	Flor. Epit. 2, 6, 1  045},
  note = {Ständige Erneuerung der Poitik und ihre Mittel In other words, according to Cicero, nothing was so in keeping with the ''precedents and practices of our ancestors'' as constant innovation.  Quelle: 	Cic. Manilian (für Pompeius) 60  046},
  note = {Bürgersoldaten und Landesitzt Bruni and Machiavelli thus help is to see beneath the Gracchna analysis three social-theoretical postulates taht widely informed Roman diagnoses of the later republic and its troubles. First, citizens were both soldiers and heads of household. In the latter capacity they were both economic agents and producers of children, and for both those activities it was widely felt taht citizens ideally should be owners of land. The connection between land an citizen identity was both ancient and long-lived, nor was it, in the prevailing economic regime, a merely political fantasy.  047},
  note = {Urbanisierung für zu instabilität The movement of some million or more Italians from the countryside to cities, and many of those to Rome, was itself partly motivated by teh importation to Italy of some two to four million slaves over the last two centuries of teh republic. The destabilization of the political process that  this movement occasioned found expression above all in the demand that the revenues of empire should be used to restore some measure of economic and demographic stability, of whatever form.  048},
  note = {Römische Wähler nur für macht und prestige der Oberschicht da On this understanding the function of Roman voters might be said to have been the granting of honor, power, and opportunity for further self-aggrandizement to successful competitors among the elite, who fought on terms set by themselves in their own self-interest, but which had been successfully universalized and naturalized over generations. The result was a fundamental incapacity of the Roman political imagination, or of Roman political language, to conceive and the to articulate meaningful reform.  049 f},
  note = {Prinzipate monopolisiert den Ruhm beim Kaiser Renaissance and early modern readers of Tacitus - Machiavelli, Bruni, and Lipsius among them - who had different interpretive agendas than Tacitus himself, not least because they did not see thier worlds as continuous with the Roman Republic, but also because unlike Tacitus tehy understood the reality that polities and states could fail, saw in the principate the end of politics, by which they meant the foreclosure for aristocrats of opportunities for teh free exercise of republican virtue. Such virtue at Rome had consisted almost exclusively in the furtherance of its imperial project (however much that project changed), and both de jure and de acto military glory wer under the principate monopolized by teh imperial house.  052},
  note = {Römische durch italisch-provinizielle Aristokraten ersetzt For the disappearance of some of the old Roman aristocracy created space at Rome, rapidly filled by elites first from Italy, then Gaul, and eventually all the provinces, while the diffusion of Roman institutions to the municipalities of the empire provoked the development within provincial societies of something like a multi-tiered governing class. These changes themselves rested upon, and likewise provoked, on-going changes in political culture and local and regional political economies, and to these i shall shortly turn.  053},
  note = {Ende der Republik im Rückblick My principal argument has been that Romans shaped the institutional structures of teh principate, as well as their understandings of its for, in light of complex systems of analysis visible already in the late second century BC and under continuous development thereafter. Indeed, many of teh reforms and innovations in Roman law and politics of the late republic should be understood as designed in light of such percipience as tehy possessed, and naturally constrained by long-standing ideological and motivated commitments to empire, for example, and against monarchy.  060},
  note = {Kaisertreue zentrales bindese Element What is more, in both local life and between localities, a primary object of public aspiration became the voicing, at least, of loyalty to emperor and empire. These cultures of euergetism and loyalism are two sides of a single imperial coin. [...] The principate is, on these terms, an explosion of voices.  061},
  key = {Ando924}

@Book{Veyne927,
  author = {Veyne, Paul},
  title = {{Die griechisch-römische Religion - Kult, Frömmigkeit und Moral}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Gelesen Religion Römisch},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {Stuttgart},
  publisher = {Reclam},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {2008},
  month = {},
  pages = {197},
  url = {http://d-nb.info/986753114/04},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {978-3-15-010621-1},
  edition = {},
  LCCN = {ULB 2008/7977},
  note = {Götter Definition Diese anthropomorphen Götter sind keine das Absolute oder das Unendliche verkörpernde Wesen, sondern, wie gesagt, eine Rasse, eine lebendige Spezies.  015},
  note = {Wirkungsbereich ...sind sie nicht allmächtig und leken auch nicht den Kosmos; sie haben diesen weder geschaffen noch ihm seine Ordnung gegeben. [...] Die göttlichen Interventionen beziehen sich auf diesen kleinen Bereich des Unvorhersebaren, der dem entspricht, was wir gemeinhin als ''Glück'' bezeichnen.  016},
  note = {Beziehung Die Beziehung zur Gottheit ist die eines Käufers zu einem mehr oder weniger verläßlichen Lieferanten.  020},
  note = {Mythos Die Mythologie war der Nährboden für eine echte Frömmigkeit, erfreute gleichzeitig die Phantasie und verlieh jedem Gott einen Charakter, der ihn von den anderen abhob und es den Menschen ermöglichte, eine Wahl zu treffen und sie die Gottheit auszusuchen, die seinen Bedürfnissen oder seiner Vorliebe entsprach. [..] Nicht daß diese mythische Temporalität ursprünglich und ''archetyisch'' gewesen wäre: Sie war nur einfach narrativ, es war die Zeit, in der die Personen der Märchen und Romane leben.  027},
  note = {Religion Das falsche Konzept von Religion bezeichnet in Wirklichkeit ein Konglomerat von sehr unterschiedlichen Überzeugungen und Praktiken, die von einer historischen Religion zur anderen variieren. Es handelt sich um ein Sammelsurium, bei dem man gelegentlich auch auf nationalistische Gedanken und noch vieles andere mehr stoßen kann.  081},
  note = {Kein Trost Halten wir fest, daß der Paganismus, eine Religion, die, wie Mario Vegetti, sagt, wenig Druck ausübte, weitgehend unbrührt war von Proselytentum, von Intoleranz, Verboten, nationalen, messianischen oder sogar politischen Implikationen - und daß er wenig Trost zu bieten hatte.  082},
  note = {Riten für den Menschen wichtig Die Abschaffung des Kultes, der Opfer, der Gesten und all der Huldigungen, die man den Göttern darbringt, würde die Bedürfnisse des sozialen Lebens und den Nutzen der koventionellen Zeichen verkennen. [...] Die Riten sind quasi der Beweis der Frömmigkeit. [S. 100] Wie John Scheid mit Recht betont, bildet die Pflicht, die Götter in festen Formen zu verehren, den ''harten Kern'' des Paganismus.  099f},
  note = {Kultur Eine Kultur besteht nicht nur in der Kenntnis mehrerer Wahrheiten, sondern in dem Besitz einer größeren Zahl von Ideen, wie Leibniz sagen würde, der Möglichkeit, die Realität zu erweitern, etwa durch Kentauren und Chimären.  102},
  note = {Mysterienen Die mysterien waren keine Heilslehre, wie man früher behauptet hat, und erst recht keine hochspirituelle Offenbarung, sondern eine Art Freimaurertum des Jenseits und sonst nichts. Sie garantierten den Initiierten nicht das Heil, sondern ein privilegiertes Dasein im Jenseits, das dank der Protektion durch den Gott, in dessen Kult man eingeweiht war, substantiell glücklicher war als das der anderen.  133},
  note = {Jenseitsvorstellungen nicht definiert Nach der gängisten Vorstellung war der Tod ein ewiger Schlaf, d. h. ein Halbleben. Sie war weiter verbreitet als der Glaube an ein dionysisches oder sonstwie geartetes Jenseits. Daher wäre es unangebracht, von den antiken Jenseitsvorstellungen als von einer ausgefeilten Lehre zu sprechen: Die Menschen waren sich unsicher, und oft überwog die Einsicht, daß man nichts wisse. [...] Im Hinblick auf das Jenseits gab es im Prinzip eine tiefe Kluft zwischen dem Aberglauben des Volkes, das an ein reduziertes Weiterleben der Verstorbenen glaubte, und dem Skeptizismus der gebildeten Kreise.  135},
  key = {Veyne927}
}
