  LCCN = {ULB 2008/7676},
  note = {Selbst ''Hellenisierung'' Above all, identity, is seen as a process. [...] If you hellenizein, you make yourself continouusly into a hellen by behaving like a hellene, in language and culture. The passive form with the prefix [..]/apo- indicates completion of a process: you have made yourself fully hellenic (without ceasing to be Roman or Gallic). The instrument of this process is education, paideia: it is by practising, not just language, but ways of thinking, ways of living, ways of dressing, that you make yourself into a perfect hellene.  006},
  note = {Fusion und Hybridisation Too often in cultural history, recourse is made to one of two metaphors: the metallurgical 'fusion', or the biologicla 'hybridity'. [...] The strata of archaeology may intersect, but they never fuse; and human history suggests that successive cultural influences rarely cancel the traces and memories of the past. The survival of minority languages or religions centuries after conquest suggests that the production of a rapid and homgeneous fusion after conquest is certainly not to be taken for granted, if indeed it ever happens.  007},
  note = {Kulturpropaganda (19. Jh.) Kulturpropaganda [...] ''We find certain types of remains - pots, implements, ornaments, burial rites, house forms - constantly recurring together. Such a complex of regularly associated traits we shall term a 'cultural group' or just a 'culture' ... We assume that such a complex is the material expression of what would today be called a 'people'''  008},
  note = {Materiall Zusammenstellung Willkürlich Third, the assemblage of an archaeologicla culture is not so much a set of unique types as variations on widely shared types, and distinctive associations of those types, which may occur elsewhere but not in that precise association: that can make the identification of a separate 'archaeological culture' more or less arbitrary.  008},
  note = {Ethnische Identität We can express this by saying, with Jonathan Hall, that ethnic identity, and surely identities in general, are 'discursively constructed', created by the discourse of the participants themselves.  009},
  note = {Romansitation und Akkulturation Acculturation cannot be taken as an either/or process whereby individual aspects of 'native' culture either are or are not replaced by elements of Roman culture.  010},
  note = {Nutzung fremder Kultur für eigene Zwecke Millett's rethinking of romanisation in Britain takes distance from any assumption of inherent Roman cultural superiority, and of any model which sees acculturation as a top-down imposition by the conqueror on the conquered. [..] Roman culture is re-contextualised in the structures of power relations, not just between Roman and native, but between native elites and the societies they sought to dominate.  010},
  note = {Romanisation The Roman empire becomes a greate 'middle ground', not simply of the 'Roman' versus the 'other' (in various degrees assimilated to Rome), but an enormous multi-sided exchange across a vast territory, in which 'influences came from everywhere and flowed to everywhere'.  013},
  note = {Kolonisation that in colonialist circumstances, different cultures do not simply blend to form a single new entity (fusion, hybridisation, creolisation, métissage), but that the elements can survive in plurality alongside each other, perhaps as 'discrepant identities', or even simply as parallel and coexistent ones.  013},
  note = {Bilingualität von Kulturen What if the outcome of Roman imperial rule was not to create a new consistent blend at local level, but to enable the coexistence of elements of Roman and native culture, with code-switching as an improvisation? One thesis pursued by this book is that biligualism is at least as interesting a model as fusion or creolisation.  013},
  note = {Kultur als bewuster Ausdruck If social realities are the outcome of our own constructions and not immanent, then the nineteenth-century idea of race, as carrying certain inherent characteristics, potentials and limitations, must be replaced. If the identity of an ethnic group is expressed in its culture, including its material culture, that is only because the group has chose to construct itself in opposition to other groups.  015},
  note = {Materielle Kultur Material-culture must be assumed to be as protean as language or religion. To say that it is not single, fixed, ascribed or bounded is not to say that it is not eloquent, and capable of potent claims to identitiy. It may, in Bourdieu's terms, leave a trace of the praxis by which the habitus embodied in ideology produces and reproduces itself. But it may conflict with ideology, or coexist in tension with it.  017},
  note = {Begriff des Hellenismus  ..neither hellenistic Greek nor hellenistic culture is a convincing product of a fusion or creolisation (there are no Egyptan or Syrian elements), and the fusion model was inappropriate from the start.  [Anm. zu Droyens, Geschichte des Hellenismus (1836)]  021},
  note = {Hellenisierung ist etwas individuelles 'hellenising' is what the foreign Greek-speaker does for himself, not something that he does to others, or that is done to him. The modern transitive usage, whereby a colonial power 'hellenises' (or 'romanises') another people is simply never met.  022},
  note = {Dialog der Kulturen statt ''Fusion'' If we focus on the reciprocity of the process whereby the colonial power not only provides powerful new cultural models to the colonised, but in turn takes to itself culturla models from the colonised (enough to refer to the spread of tea and curry in colonial Britain, and the fashions for oriental art and religion), we can allow that Roman conquest of Greece led not to fusion but reciprocal exchange. The cultures do not fuse (any more than they did in the 'hellenistic east'), but enter into a vigorous and continuous process of dialogue with one another.  023},
  note = {Hellenisierung und Romniserung  'Hellenisation' and 'romanisation' are not sequential, but two closely interrelated aspects of the same phenomenon.  026},
  note = {Blutkreislauf To pursue an anatomic metaphor, it is as if hellenisation and romanisation represented the two phases of the circulation of the blood. If hellenisation is the diastolic phase, by which blood is drawn in to the centre, romanisation is the systolic phase, that pumps the oxygenated blood back to the extremities. It is not enought to have one single, prolonged phase of the one, followed by a similar, single, long phase of the other, because the two need to alternate constantly, to keep the system alive.  027},
  note = {Kultur Definition feeney has argued that one of the most striking characteristics of Roman culture form the earliest stage - that is, the first waves of Greek colonisation in Italy - is the ability to maintain its difference from the Greek while constantly modifying itself in directions assimilable to the Greek. [...] Culture does not merely say who you are. It says who you are in relation to others.  028},
  note = {Sprache nicht entscheidend Language is frequently a critical component of cultural identity; but that does not mean that other components automatically correspond with it, or obey the same rules. You could, as we have seen, learn Latin without turning into a Roman, and indeed could in some cases be a Roman without speaking Latin.  076 f},
  note = {Hellenisierung / Romanisierung the founding of colonies is part of the hellenisation of Italy (Roman power expressed in a hellenic idiom), the creation of a network of independent allies is the true romanisation (Roman power expressed in a Roman way).  080},
  note = {Trennung der Identiäten The Social War destroyed the basis of the dialectic, between Roman and non-Roman, that had characterised Italy for at least two centuries, a dialectic which presupposed, and thereby promoted, a separation of identities.  081},
  note = {Dualität der Identität Found together, they are reminiscent of a bilingual inscription, with tribe and affiliation given in Latin, matronymic in Venetic. What is enormously much harder to assess is whether they expressed two identities, whether in conflict or in harmony, or the absorption of new practices, like loan-words, into a single identity. And if the strigil have the Insubrian a dual identity, did it make him feel specifically Roman, like the colonists of nearby Cremona, or rather associate with a broader Mediterranean cultural koine, already meet centuries before through the Etrucscans?  098},
  note = {Anatomische Votive auf Latiner und Römer beschränkt So Torelli has shown a striking correlation between the distribution of anatomical ex voto offerings and the spread of Roman settlers, either in colonies or viritim, though the original model is developed in the strip from Etruria through Latium to northern Campania. He has also suggestes a significant pattern in the distribution of architectural terracottas of the Etrusco-Italic type: originating in Etruria and Latium, these spread through central Italy, notably Umbria, and are limited in the north and south to actual colonies. But these patterns, though similar, are not the same: especially in Umbria, while architectural terracottas were spread enthusiastically by imitation to allied cities, anatomical ex votos appear to be limited to actual Romans or Latins.  101 f},
  note = {Wenig ''Bauboom'' in Latium the second- and early first-century BCE building boom in opus incertum has suprisingly limited concentration in Latium and Campania, an leaves the colonies looking backward and underdeveloped, while opus reticulatum, the characteristic style of the later first century BCE and first century CE, concentrates around epicentres in Rome and the Bay of Napels, and is exceptional in Samnium, Bruttium and Lucania and Etruria north of Tarquinii.  102},
  note = {Anatomische Votive ''latinisch-römisch'' On the other hand, the anatomic ex voto, with its narrow spread, does indeed seem to be associated with Romans and Latins, but fails to influence the behaviour of their allies.  102},
  note = {Urbanisierung Romanisierung Hellenisierung gehen einher Promotion of the role of urban centres rates as one of the fundamental features of the romanisation of Italy; at the same time, use of the language of hellenistic art and architecture which is an inextricable part of such monumentalisation rates as a fundamental feature of hellenisation.  103},
  note = {Monumentalbauten Ausdruck lokaler Identität But monumental buildings requires such a concerted attempt on the part of a community, is such a commitment of resource, and leaves behind so conspicuous a public symbol, that it is hard not to read it as a significant statement of identity. On the other hand, except possibly when under the Empire buildings are erected through imperial patronage, it is hard to read them as an imposition from outside; even when supported by imperial patronage, major public buildings are likely to represent a communal expression of communal identity.  103 f},
  note = {Praeneste ''hellenisiert'' Praeneste has long and deservedly, enjoyed a reputation as a type-site for Italic helenisation, and is a good place to start in confronting the question of what sort of statements about identity can be extracted from monuments and artefacts.  106},
  note = {Kulturadaption nicht Teil einer Kultur übernahme Here is Praeneste is conspicuous for its ''tombe principesche'', magnificent aristocratic burials with rich, ''orientalising'', grave-goods, largely imported from the east. The Tomba Bernardno of the late eighth century ranks as the finest of these ''princely'' burials in Lazio: [...] What identity might the chiefs of Praenste be signalling with such burials: Greek, Etruscan, or even oriental? The choise makes little sense, because the important point is that burials of this type are widespread phenomen in Italy... [..] They would surely not recognise it as a statement of oriental, or Greek, or Etruscan, identity, but of links to those worlds.  107},
  note = {Praeneste in der Republik  Praeneste's realtions to Rome under the eary republic are unclear; never a memeber of the Latin League, it is possible that the city, like Tbur, fell under the control of the Aequi of the interior in the fifth century. From the confusion of the Latin and Samnite wars of the fourth century, and episodes of alignment with Rome's enemies, Praeneste emerges in firm alliance with Rome, with its large territory diminished, but with complete independence, not Latin status. It is in the fourth and third centuries that the necropolis of la Colombella offers its richest harvest of burials, and the extraordinary series of bronze cists which, along with engraved mirrors, ivory combs, strigils, and bathing equipment, attest the material culture of a large and flourishing elite.  108},
  note = {Griechische Mythen römischen und latinische reflektiert The mythological and generic subject matter shows close engagement with Greek mythology, while offering what is no simply a reflection of a generalised Greco-Italic mythology, but a specific local appropriation. The corpus of cistae, and the closely related series of engraved mirrors, plays a central role in the argument for the existence of a distinctive 'Roman' mythology; depictions of themes like the wolf and twins, evoking the cluster of festivals of Lupercalia, Feralia and Quirinalia, have an evident local relevance to Rome, while many figures like Castor and Pollux, Marsyas, Liber and hairy-suited satyrs reflect Latin versions of such myths.  108},
  note = {Römische und Griesche Einflüsse und dennoch lokale Identität But in any case, we see a Praeneste with an independent elite that is tied by links of marriage and exchange to Rome, familiar with its mythology, and associated in artistic patronage and production. We can describe this elite as romanising, in virtue of such links; and as hellenising in virute of the artistic style of its production. And while 'emblematically' teh style and mythological content do indeed parade the links to the Roman and to the Greek world, it would be hard to argue that the ethnic consciousness expressed is anything other than a local one.  110},
  note = {Lokaler Stil und Familien Kontinuität Restored to the context of the graveyards, with their stone pinecone markers and simplified female heads, a context so compromised by the nineteenth-century excavators, they exemplify a quite recognisable local style that could never be confused with Roman or Etruscan. The graveyards express the self-awareness of a local elite, of a group of families whose names the burials attest as a continuous presence from the fourth to late second centuries. [..S. 111] The identity expressed can be defined as a specific one of citizenschip or membership of the classis of those equipped socially and economically for hoplite warfare.  110 f},
  note = {Lokale Identität ausgedrückt durch fremde Idoime As Torelli pertinently comments, these [Anm. miltary and bathing equipment] are the symbols of the ephebeia, the young citizen trained in the gymnasium, and in combination mark the citizen who has passed through his military and gymnastic training. It is a standard hellenic idiom for expressing citizenship; the wars in which they are training to fight are ones fought in alliance with Rome; the citizenship is that of the independent city of Praeneste. The necropolis of la Colombella may indeed bear witness to the links of Praeneste with the wider world but, as for identitites, it is local social structures and local religiosity which are at stake.  111},
  note = {Wandlung der Fortuna Primigenia The change in style is most immediately visible in the figure of the goddess Foruna herself, who in this period abandons the old Etrusco-Italic image of the mother-goddess, and takes on instead teh features of the hellenisitic Tyche, the Fortune of victory with wings and crown, and is partially assimilated to Isis.  => Isis ist aber eine Muttergottheit schlecht hin  111},
  note = {Charakterisation des Fortuna Heiligtums But it its in the monumental development of the sanctuary of Fortuna Primigenia that the self-confidence of the new style procalims itself. [....] ..urged that it sould be seen as a specifically Italic expression of hellenism. From the awesome axial planing of the layout, with its orchestrated sequence of terraces and ramps, to the architectural language of the colonnades and entablatures, the sanctuary displays deep indebtedness to eastern Mediterranean models. Perhaps the most striking image of hellenisation is not from the sanctuary, but from the late second-century buildings of the Forum: from the Doric frieze of the altar, to the culmination in the decorative details of the mosaics in opus vermiculatum, with its explicity Alexandrian presentation of the Nile and its temples, peoples, flora and fauna, neatly labelled in Greek.  111-113},
  note = {Praeneste Hellenistische Bauten from the Doric frieze of the altar, to the culmination in the decorative details of the mosaics in opus vermiculatum, with its explicitly Alexandrian presentaion of the Nile and its temples, peoples, flora and fauna, neatly labelled in Greek.  113},
  note = {Pranesteinische Familien (Saufeii) reich gewordne  The observation that it was precisely members of the old elite families, like the Anicii, Magulnii, Orcevii, Samiarii, Satricanii and Saufeii, who emerge from the dedications of Delos and other  eastern sites as negotiatores, provides a context both for the economy of the building, and the evident knowledge of and attraction to eastern models. These families are deeply implicated in the processes of Roman imperialism; it is telling that at end of the second century and in the early first century, Saufeii are also found active in Roman politics: a monetalis in 150, a likely Gracchan tribune, a quaestor in 100 who was killed as a partisan of Saturninus, and another tribune in 91 giving his name to a lex agraria. The cohors Praenestina distinguished itself in various campaigns (Livy. 9.16.17-18; 23.19.17-18); and it is on the nexus of direct military involvement and access to booty, and indirect profiteering from the slave and art trades of Delos and elsewhere, that the gigantic financial investment represented by the monumental sanctuary must rest.  113},
  note = {Heiligtum hellenistisch und römisch zugleich Hellenisation, then, is seen in the artistic expression, and romanisation in the collusion with conquest, though neither of these is a new tendency, for Praeneste had been hellenising and romanising for many centuries already. But what is at issue is the expression of identity. Is Praeneste submerging its local character in subscribing to the new helenistic koine? [...] The sanctuary is hellenistic from the point of view of its axial monumentality: [...] The scale and monumentality of the construction is inconceivable without the specific Roman development of concrete construction techniques: here it is more Roman that hellenistic, and Praeneste in one of a well-defined cluster sites in Latium and Campania which pushed opus incertum construction to new limits.  113},
  note = {Römisches und Hellenstisches zum Ausdruck der eigenen Indivitualität verwendet But it is at this point that it becomes most apparent that this new architecture is not merely a reflection of what is happening in the Greek east, nor a replication of the reinterpretation of that by Rome, but a vigorous and [S. 115] innovative movement in which the Italic cities play their own role. In terms of expression of identity, it is highly significant that so many of these sites are sanctuaries: religion has always rated alongside language as one of the most visceral expressions of ethnic identity. [...] since these are all Roman, it might be seen as a response to Roman influence. [...] Such widespread monumentalisation of local cults reflects an enormous investment in local religiosity and local pride which is in no way diminished by the existence of stylistic evocations of the east, or dependence on participation in Roman imperialism and constructional technique. It seems to cut across the distinctions between the urbanised and 'non-cities' areas: sanctuaries were the most potent physical embodiment of local beliefs and values.  114 f},
  note = {Heiligtum viele Erbauern Familien The inscriptional evidence shows clearly that the responsibility for the erection of the sanctuary complex was one shared between many members of the local elite families: [..] the Sullan sack spelled the end of a period of a cluster of families, and their culturla expression in burials and in monuments. The fact that the sanctuary had multiple patron is what makes it so unlike contemporary Rome, where individual temples are erected competitively by individual members of the elite.  115},
  note = {Lokalpatriotismus Samnitisch Praeneste gleich The collaboration of the Praenestine elite has an exact parallel in the collaboration of the Samnite elite at Pietrabbondaten, and is surely elqouent of the awareness of local collaboration as the basis for the assertion of local pride.  115 f.},
  note = {Historische Persönlichkeiten besuchen den Ort What is impressive is not simply that famous people from the eastern Mediterranean visited Praeneste, but that their visits should enter the historical record: we know not because they left casual inscriptions behind, but because Livy and Cicero thought it worthwile mentioning the fact: that is indeed to leave ripples behind. The monumentalisation of the sanctuary expresses an ambition to make ripples at a Mediterranean level, to become one of the great holy places that would attract pilgrims in its own right, to be more than a mere satellite of the great centre of attraction in Rome.   116},
  note = {Heiligtums Charakteristika One is of the specifically Italic combination of theatre and temple in a single major complex... [...] A second is the embelishment of hilltop sanctuaries in general... [...] A third is the monumental enhancement of a series of urban centres (whether or not these were also sanctuaries), which we may exemplify from the string of little hilltop centres that followed the valley of the Sacco river, the main corridor connecting Latium with Campania  Weitere Heiligtümer: Gabii, Tibur, Pietrabbondante, Pietravairano, Tarracina, Sulmona, Macchia di Rossano  116},
  note = {Prusias und Carneades Besuch in Praeneste We know that it wa visited by king Prusias of Bithynia in 167 BCE, and by the philosopher Carneades in 154 while on a mission to Rome: these visits were before the likely date of the major phase of monumentalisation.  Quellen: 	Liv. 45, 44, 8	(Prusias) 	Cicero, de Divination 2, 87 (Carneades)  116},
  note = {Polygonal Mauerwerk als ''archaismus'' The element of local pride is not only implicit in the ambitious scheme of local improvement, but here as elsewher in the apparent ideological choice implicit in hte use of polygonal masonry. [..S. 119] Whereas one might have predicted that the development of new concrete construction techniques would spell the demise of the local craft tradition of masonry, we see it here and elsewhere at its apogee, expressing a visual continuity with the structures that had defined the city for at least two centuries.  Anmerkung: Stadt Aletrium  118 f},
  note = {Hellenisierung Romanisierung As in the other cases considered, we can speak both of hellenisation, in the sence of architectural detail, and romanisation in the sense of the military/economic engine that drives it.  119},
  note = {Familien in Praeneste ähnliche wie in Rom But more confidently we can say that at Aletrium, as at Praeneste, collaboration with Rome allowed the emergence of dominant families which survive for several generations, and which both express and reinforce their dominance through public building schemes, as was the case in Rome. Romanisation expresses itself in social and economic relations, and the reproduction of Roman urban features, while Hernican identity finds its alibi in the reassuring continuity of polygonal masonry.  120},
  note = {Rom ''untersützt'' Ausbau If it must remain speculation, it remains completely plausible to suggest that behind the rebuilding of centres like Signia, Aletrium and Praeneste lay a network of ties, between local dominant families and the leading political figures at Rome, and that the architectural expertise that underpinned these ambitious schems was  of an international level, supported by patronage at Rome, and drawing on the knowledge base of teh hellenistic architectural profession. Again, romanisation and hellenisation seem to converge; but the point at which they meet is a local expression of continuity with a past which they at least imagined stretched back to the regal age.  126},
  note = {Fortuna Heiligtum ''eingefrohren'' ..it is evident taht the conjunction between a flourishing local elite stretching back several centures, and the wealth generated by war-booty, the profits of eastern trade and the richness of the sanctuary itself, was never replicated, and that Fortuna Primigenia froze in its second century form. Aletrium, Ferentinum and Signia equally seem to have passed their moment of glory.  126},
  note = {Bürgerkrieg ändern Italien radikal In Lucan's gloomy vision,what changed the face of Italy was not the longue durée (for aetas edax, we might substitute 'the romanisation of Italy from the fourth to second centuries'), but the traumatic convulsions of teh first century BCE. The archeological evidence strongly supports that vision.  Quellen: 	Lucan. Bellum Civile, 7, 392-399  128},
  note = {Viele ''ausländische'' einflüsse stärken das eigene selbst verständnis The sanctuary of Fortuna at Praeneste, the temple of Juno Moneta at Signia, the temple-theatre complexes at Pompeii and at Pietrabbondante each have numerous features in common. But each of these sites creates a fundamentally different impression, because each draws on teh specific location, history and character of the place. Roman power and Greek culture engender radical transformations of society and economy; but there is no reason to see them as suppressing or substituting local identity. Cultural multilingualism only enhances their power of self-expression.  143},
  note = {''Römische Architktur'' Roman 'ancestral practice', whatever that might be, was too implicated in a myth of rustic simplicity to from a basis for an Augustan architecture.  208},
  note = {Italisch römische griechische Architektur ? Did the Praenestines in construction their great sanctuary at the end of the second century feel less Latin and more Greek for 'hellenising', or more Roman for sharing in the 'concrete revolution'? We can only speculate. What Vitruvius, a century later, allows us to say is that building did indeed raise issues of identity, and that he wants simultaneously to say that the Greek is different and that it can be embraced provided that difference is respected. Over a century of frenetic building work across Italy, in the public and the private sphere, unleashed an extraordinary creativity, but also a debate about identity that was implicit in the debate about citizenship and the distribution of power within the citizen body. Vitruvius, from the viewpoint of the new Augustan order, can resolve that debate, and enfold the Greek and Italic within the Roman.  210},
  note = {Kalender Synchronisation They are willing enough to do it under their own mpulse, and buy into the system by synchronizing Roman time with Praenestine time (and local festivals, especially that of Fortuna Primigenia, are registered on the calendar along with Roman ones, just as are local magistrates) [...] In slipping from the nobility, Roman time becomes the common property of all Romans. It is not only town councils through Italy which enthusiastically inscribe the fasti.  246},
  note = {Diverese unterschiedliche Rechte The Romans remained astonishingly consistent in expecting their Italian allies to fight for their cause, and put up with a variety of subaltern statuses - citizenship without the vote, Latin rights, allies (with 'equal' or 'unequal' treaties). If the Romulean myth of embracing their former enemies had ever had currency before this point, they had forgotten it, and the steady census figures for numbers of citizens confirm the lack of expansion of teh citizen body at a peak period of imperial expansion.  446},
  note = {Bundesgnossenkreig The Social War was a battle over identities for the citizen as well as the member of the elite; and the Augustan census figures, however we interpret them, indicate the outcome of the battle.  447},
  note = {Mehr lokalpatriotismus als Romanisierung The eagerness of the cities and communities of central Italy to transform their urban fabric in the period up to the Social War is better explained, I have argued, in terms of desire to assert local pride in a context of multiple identities than as an aspiration to Roman identity.  447 f},
  note = {Erstes Jahrhundert übergangs gesellschaft The period between 90 BCE and Augustsu is one of transition, in which the full consequences of redefining the citizen body as Italy-wide only gradually percolate. It is striking, for instance, how long it took the 'new men' from the municipalities of Italy to penetrate to power.  449},
  note = {Alte römische Elite verliert an Macht Yet this is exactly the time when the credibility of the traditional authority of the nobility came under attack. Its ability to know and define what it meant to be Roman, follow the ancestral ways, religion, time, law, suffered catastrophic collapse. A rising generation of new Romans did not question their obligation to follow the ancestral ways, mores maiorum; they merely challenged the ability of the old elite to preserver the traditional standards and set the right exempla for the future.  449},
  note = {Luxus statt Politik aus ''Frust'' Just as the failure fo Rome to extend citizenship in the second century may be seen as a factor behind the boom of building in Italien cities, so the frustrations of an Italy-wide elite, trapped in teh bottleneck of the Roman political system and unable to express its distinction in the language of magistracies and public honours at Rome, found in luxury an alternative language for the expression of status. [...] The growth of luxury is not about wealth alone, but about the relationships between wealth and systems of status-recognition.  450},
  note = {Kaiser wichtiger als Wahlen In any case, reliance on imperial patronage rapidly overwhelmed reliance on popular favour, and with a large growth in the number of public offices directly appointed by the emperor, the networks of patronage were necessarily transformed. IF waht teh Italian allies wanted was teh vote, it may seem paradoxical taht their moment of 'triumph' under Augustus should lead to its abandonment.  451},
  note = {Bürgerrecht verliert an Funktion The transformation of citizenship from a reciprocal bundle of rights an obligations to form of social dignity is basic for Roman cultural identity. Citizenship is no longer expressed through actions (voting, fighting) but through symbols: it becomes more urgent to define culturally what 'being Roman' is about when it is reduced to a socio-legal status.  452},
  note = {Bürgerrechte als Kontroll und Herrschaftsmittel von Augustus By reinforcing the value and dignity of citizenship, and presenting himself as its champion and defender, he reaffirmed a social order based on attributable legal status which he himself could control, and use as the material for his patronage network. Not only could he control the elite by an effective distribution of the numerous ranks of senatorial and equestrian status, but he as teh main font of patronage of the citizenship itself, whether distributed to individuals or communities. [...] The symbolic and cultural manifestations of citizen identity grew in importance as the functional link with the operations of the city-state was lost. [...] Augustus' traditionalism,in reaffirming the mores maiorum, in morality, religion, social structures and social practices, was not a veil for an alternative reality; it was rather the language in which the alternative reality was formulated.  453},
  note = {Gesellscahft der kaiserzeit Such figures multiply through small or medium-sized towns like Pompeii and Herculaneum, where we see a society that is hierarchial, by all means, but also remarkably inclusive.  454},
  key = {Wallace-Hadrill930}

  note = {Sklaven heterogen und homogen zu Gleich On account of their particular status, then, slaves were usually excluded from civil society. They formed a group that was homogeneous in its deprivation of rights, but otherwise heterogeneous. Three facts mainly determined teh social situation of slaves: their duties; their nearness (in the sense of their personal relationship) to or distance from the master; and finally, teh latter's social status.  602},
  note = {Freigelassene vs. Freie Teh freedman (libertus) now worked for himself, though his former owner (patronus) participated in the profit through teh post-manumission obligations (operae). However, the possible competition between freedmen and free-born person in the fields of handicrafts or trade might have had a negative effect on the potential income of the lower classes altogether.  602},
  note = {Sklavenhierarchie The public slaves (servi publici) of Rome and other cities were especially privileged. Together with the slaves of the imperial house (servi Caesaris), they formed the top of the 'slave hierarchy'. Both groups could also reckon with manumission, though in the case of the imperial slaves, the subsequent career chances were significantly better. [...] In the private sphere , it is best to divide these persons into tow main groups: the familiae rusticae and urbanae. Slaves in agriculture formed the lowest level, in which the bailiffs of estates had a special status. Slaves in urban household were mostly in a better position; however, in addition to the opportunities, personal risks could certainly also result from proximity to the master. Slaves in trade and  commerce should also be included in this intermediate level. [...] In patent imitation of Roman society otherwise, then, the slave society itself came to be structured hierarchically.  603},
  key = {Schumacher938}
}

Verweigerten sich die Bundegenossen in größere Zahl oder kämpften sie nur halbherzig, war es umdie Herrschaft bald gesehehen. Daß das nicht nur eine theoretische Option war, während die socii in Wirklichkeit an nichts weniger dachten als an eine Rebellion, erweis sich im Bundesgenossenkrieg, dem letzten und größten Kampf der Italiker um ihre Freiheit.   note = {Gründe für die Treue der Bundesgenossen Den naheliegenden Ausweg bot die Annahme, daß anstalle der Rituale andere Bindungen für die Integration Italiens sorgten. Solche waren in der Forschung schon vielfach vorgeschlagen worden: sprachliche und kulturelle Affinitäten, kultische und religiöse Gemeinsamkeiten, der Armeedienst, wirschaftliche Verflechtungen, rechtliche Angleichung, Bürgerrechtsverleihungen, das Patronagesystem. Kommunikation und Verwandtschaft zwischen die Eliten. Daneben war auch öfters darauf hingewiesen wordne, daß die Bindungen nicht nur dank einer friedlichen Durchdringung der Halbinsel zur Geltung kamen, sondern wesenetliche bedingt waren durch gewaltsame Eroberungen, brutale Bestrafung von Aufständischen, durch Deportationen, Massaker und Entrechtun, die natürlich gerade die hartnäckigsten Gegner Roms ausschalteten. [..S. 11] Jedes dieser verbindenden Elemente besitzt seine Bedeutung, und ebensowenig ist das Ergebnis, nämlich daß Italien am Ende in Rom aufging, zu bestreiten  10f},
  note = {Weniger Integration durch fehlende Rituale Rituale sind für eine gesellschaftliche Integration unter vormodernen Bedingungen unserer Ansicht nach nicht nur wesentlich - das heißt, sie könnten zur Not auch durch äquivalente Faktoren resetzt werden - sie sind sogar unverzichtbar. Daraus ergibt sich, daß das Fehlengemeinschaftsstiftender Rituale für Italien nicht ausgegelichen werden konte. Der Herrschaft Roms besaß in Italien demnach eine andere Qualität als in der Stadt, die Integrationsleistung war schwächer.  => Latium hatte gemeinesame Rituale, Sprache, Tradition etc. => Was ist mit Etrurien und Umbrien? Zu Etrurien besteht teilweise noch eine kultische Bindung, aber gemeinschaftliche Rituale dürften fehlen. Für Umbrien ist das Unklar.  => Was ist mit den Städten der magna graecia  11},
  note = {Bevölkerungszahlen Italiens Entgegen der von Julius Beloch und Peter Brunt gepägten commuis opinio scheint es nach den Stiduen von Elio Lo Cascio heute zumindest erwägenswert, ob das Augusteische Italien nicht fünt bis sechs, sondern zehn bis zwölf Millionen Einwohner zählte. Die Zahl der Italiker wäre bislang also unterschätzt worden, und mit ihr natürlich die zu erbringende Integrationsleistung. Neveille Morley hat unlängst gezeigt, daß die Sozialgeschichte gerade des zweiten Jahrhunderts, die Korrektheit dieses Modells der italischen Bevölkerungsentwicklung vorausgesetzt, wenger von Landflucht und Verödung als von Bevölkerungsdruck und intensiver Auseinandersetung um kanpper werden Ressourcen geprägt wäre. Doch nun hat Walter Scheidle scharfsinning wieder für erheblich niedrigere Bevölkerungszahlen plädiert.  11 f},
  note = {Sprache wenig verbreitet Die italischen Völker wahrten bis weit ins erste Jahrhunderte hinein ihre Sprache und ihre nationale Identität. [..] Guy Bradley hat in seiner 2000 erschienenen Studie über das antike Umbrien gezeigt, daß da sLateinische in den Inschriften der Landschaft nur da früh und fast ausschließlich triumphierte, wo latinische Kolonie gegründet worden waren oder römische Siedler Viritanassignationen erhalten hatten. In den Gebieten der socii aber tauchte die lateinische Schrift erst nach 150 auf, um sich bis zum Bundesgenossenkrieg weitgehend durchzusetzen. Die lateinische Sprache kam noch später und vermochte das Umrbische bis zum Bundesgenossenkrieg nicht annähernd zu verdrängen.  13},
  note = {Kein Streben nach Romanisierung Die socii hatten nach Mouritsen an einer Assimilation kein Interesse, ebensowenig am römischen Bürgerrecht. Roma aber war zu einer gewissen Rücksichtnahme gezwungen, weil es auf den alliierten Betirag zur Aremee angewiesen war. Der Bundesgenossenkrieg war in dieser Perspektive keine Kampf um die Aufnahme in die res publica, der gewonnen, sondern einer um die Unabhängigkeit von der Hegemonialmacht, der verloren wurde. An dem Bewußtsein der italischen Gemeinden um ihre nationale Identität und dem Streben nach ihrer Erhaltung hatte die zum Teil über zweihunderjährige Herrschaft Roms nichts geändert.  14},
  key = {Jehne939}

@Book{Torelli955,
  author = {Torelli, Mario},
  title = {{Studies in the Romanization of Italy}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Architektur Gelesen Geschichte Republik},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {Edmonton},
  publisher = {Univ. of Alberta Press},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {1995},
  month = {},
  pages = {XIX, 262},
  url = {http://www.gbv.de/dms/bowker/toc/9780888642417.pdf},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {0-88864-241-5},
  edition = {},
  note = {ZuLesen S. 159-189 => Romanisierung S. 177 => ex voto von anatomischen Dingen},
  LCCN = {Fernleihe bestellt},
  note = {Dressel I Amphora als Beleg für gute Landwirtschaft Although the origin of the ''Graeco-Italic'' amphorae is still controversial and one would like to know more about it in order to understand the earliest phases of teh agricultural development in the peninsula, the distribution all over the Mediterranean area of Dressel I amphorae, exported as containers of Italic produce (mostly from Latium and Campania) is the best evidence of the high level of teh second century B.C. development of agricultural production in the region.  003 f},
  note = {Heiligtümer und Theater in Latium The theaters of Allifae and Sarno and at Teanum, of exceptional size, the sanctuaries of Diana Tifatina, Teanum, Aeclanum, close in conception and construction type to the contemporary scenographic sanctuaries of Latium, such as Praeneste, Tivoli, and Terracina, are equally significant.  005},
  note = {Bei Marsern und Samniten (?) keine großen Villen It is important to underline the radical change which occurred,  with total prevalence in the countryside and an almost complete absence in the city between the third and first centuries B.C. in this territory. The hilltop fortified enclosures, the small family farms scattered in the countryside (the survey in the Biferno Valley by G. Bakrer has identified a number of them), and the series of country sanctuaries perform the  function otherwise and elsewhere performed by the city. As a consequence, the rural villas for agricultural production are completely absent, as indeed is noted by the ancient sources.  010},
  note = {Urbanisierte vs nicht urbanisierte gebiete On one side, a world dominated by cities, as in Oscan Campania, and on the other side, a world dominated by the countryside, as in the Samnitic and Lucanian Apennine region, with a series of intermediate situations characterized by a process of discontinous and still not prevalent urbanization. But it was a complex reality, where toward the end of the period of independence from Rome, the trend toward urbanization manifest itself in a spontaneous manner, under a two-fold pressure: one pressure as economic, represented by the development of agricultural practices, and the other was cultural, fostered by the local aristocracies craving luxuria.  012},
  note = {Kaiserzeitlichen Homogenität The picture of the Augustan period is noticeably different. The great diversity of structures and of cultural levels which manifested itself during the period preceding the Social War turns into an evident uniformity.  012},
  note = {Kolonisten als Mittelschicht It is the late Hellenistic culture, with its peculiar, well known developments, as it spreads out its characteristic areas, which expresses, in a more modest fashion than the original models, the political and social solidarity of the Augustan tota Italia, of large middle classes made up of colonists of Sulla, Caesar, the Triumvirate and Augustus and by the remaining local aristocracies, now ruling established municipal towns.  013},
  note = {Ende der Terrakotta Votive Symptomatic, finally, is the complete disappearance of what had been the figurative culture of the local ''middle'' and ''lower'' classes of the second century B.C. The last votive deposits are dated in the first quarter of teh first century B.C. when those products (terracottas, small bronzes) and those religious customs typical of the ''poor'' culture of the late Hellenistic period also disappear.  014},
  note = {Praeneste - Mischung von Dorische und Ionischer Ordnung Another important predecessor of this type of structure is the podium of the ''apsidal hall'' at the Praeneste sanctuary which scholars date to the Sulan period. Here too the powerful base with Corinthian columns has a characteristic Doric frieze and cornice decorated wiht dentils and ovuli. On the other hand, the same arrangement of a Doric frieze with an Ionic cornice occurs on other monuments in the sanctuary at Praeneste, for example, on the tholos and on the dedicatory base behind the eastern hemicycle on the ''Hemicycle Terrace''. The initial mixing of Doric and Ionic elements is definitely very old.  174 f},
  note = {Unterschiedliche Regionen Differences in Latium, Etruria - especially southern Etruria - and Campania, an area of koine which constitutes the well-known basis of the so-called ''middle Italic'' culture, are barely perceptible. In the less evolved areas, the fourth and third centuries coincide either with a definite urbanization (as in the Umbrian and Picenum region) or with the first monumentalization of central sanctuaries in the paganic territories of teh Samnitic regions.  192},
  note = {Italische Homogenität bis Anfang 2. Jh. v. Chr. An actual break appears in the structures and architectural typologies of this historical block only in the first half of the second century B.C. Until that time, the building typology of Rome, its colonies, the urbanized areas of the socii and, in large measure, the nonurbanized central Italic zones, is essentially teh same. Indeed, the technical and formal solutions of architectural decoration for the entire third century - well illustrated for example by the terracotta temple revetments - are substantially homogeneous within the area.  194},
  note = {Heiligtum in Arezzo mit Theater Temple At Arezzo, the immense extra-urban sanctuary with the theater-temple of S. Cornelio was teh major undertaking. In these two cities, where there are nor unequivocal data on teh eventual process of superseding the old forms of dependency, this building activity is accompanied by a significant upsurge in artisan activity, from alabaster working  to bronze and ceramic production.  197},
  note = {Bauboom in Rom ''imitiert'' ? Thus, the great building renewal in Rome from the beginning of the second century onwards is only partially echoed in central Italy, with the exception of Campania and Latium. [..] The public building activity in the Roman colonies, although emanating from the center, expresses itself in traditional forms that reveal clearly the persistence of a less developed viewpoint and social structure.  198},
  note = {Tradition wichtig für Bauten Where teh local oligarchies are stronger and socially more robust, as at Voterra and Arezzo, teh building activity appears more developed. This is evident in both a freedom of form and in traditional building types, for example, temples and walls in the public sphere and sepulchers in teh private one. [...] In the more developed and socially homogeneous areas (for examples, Perugia, Arezzo, Voltera in Etruria, Ausculum in Picenum, Assis and Gubbio in Umbria, the Pelignian and Pentrian areas of Samnium) there is evidence of a conspicuous construction of monumental buildings oriented entirely along teh traditional lines of urban order and sacred buildings.  199},
  note = {Weniger hellenistische Einflüsse The building activity is concentrated above all on traditional forms, the aggregate expression of a mentality still firmly anchored to the old cultural koine with the rare concession to Hellenistic models (as for example the diffusion - functional with a judical use - of Hellenistic sun clocks) and in the private rather than the public sphere.  200},
  note = {Samniums Heiligtümer zugunsten von Städten aufgegeben Private expenditures in teh villa of otium and production, between the first half of the first century B. C. and the Julio-Claudian epoch spread beyond Latium and Campania and became diffuse throughhout the entire central and northern peninsula. On the local level, the emerging equestrians whole-heartedly carry the banner of the euergetic model, adopting various means according to the local circumstances. In Samnium, with the partial abandonment of the old ''federal'' sanctuaries such as Pietrabbondante, Schiavi, or Vastogirarid, there is an intense urbanization process.  => Die Samnitischen Heiligtümer sind ausdruck des Zusammenwachsens. Ersatz für die Urbanität und werden folglich im Zuge der Urbanisierung aufgegeben, die latinischen Heiligtümern sind hingegen Ausdruck der bereits erfolgten Urbanität und werden, da diese weiter besteht, weiter genutzt, wenn auch im geringen Umfang nur noch  201},
  note = {Trimalchones The road built by the medicus, P. Decimus P. l. Eros Merula, at Assisi or by the Augustales at Falerii are eloquent examples of the emergence in this sector of the new reality of the Trimalchiones and of the crucial function of the euergetism in the dominant ideology, of which the ''parvenu'' freedmen, true heirs of the local aristocracy, are - in a debased form - the vocal interpreters.  203},
  note = {Urabnisierung und Auswirkung The phenomenon [Anm. Urbanisierung] is composed of various aspects - ideological, social, economic. On the ideological plane, teh significance of urbanization and of the new building typology for urbanitas is evident. It was central to the construction of the new political ''consortium'' which emerged from the Social War. [...] Where this is already in existence, the appreciation of a glorious and thus ''civil'' past assumes great ideological importance: this gives rise to an insistence on the traditions of the patria in places with a long history and on famous documents with a great historical significance, which we see flower in the Etruscan cities, or on significant monuments, be they teh ''Ara della Regina'' at Tarquina or the sanctuary of Nortia at Spello. [...] The most ancient phase of teh appearance of the new building types in the early second century B.C., as noted, is characterized by the introduction of opus incertum on a large scale  204},
  note = {Vitruv und Mauertechniken Vitruvius, writing at the beginning of the Augustan age, knew opus incertum as antiquum and attributed to the opus reticulatum - universally used by that time - greater visual appeal but lesser endurance.  215},
  note = {Hellenisierung der Heiligtümer und bautechnik Undoubtedly, the number of public buildings in this technique [Anm. opus reticulatum] is much less than at Rome. Great energy was expended by the local aristocracy in the late second century B.C. and in the first decades of the first century B.C. to give a Hellenistic appearance to the city and suburban sanctuaries. Certainly Praeneste, Tibur, Terracina, and Gabii enter into this category, but also elsewhere, in less macroscopic cases, the situation is identical.  218},
  note = {Bautechnik in Tibur At Tibur the principal public buildings, sacred or profane, of the city are virtually all in opus incertum or quadratum: the temple of Heracles, the buildings on the acropolis and of the forum, the market, and the city walls. The structures for roads with substructures within the city include six in opus incertum (and one in opus quadratum) as opposed to four in opus reticulatum. Two of these pertain to the zone o f expansion of teh city to the southeast which took place after the second half of the first century B.C.  218},
  key = {Torelli955}
}

@Book{Veyne980,
  author = {Veyne, Paul},
  title = {{Brot und Spiele - Gesellschaftliche Macht und politische Herrschaft in der Antike}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Gelesen Geschichte Kaiser Kaiserzeit Religion Republik Sozial Stadt},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {Frankfurt},
  publisher = {Campus-Verl},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {1988},
  month = {},
  pages = {698 S. ;},
  url = {http://www.dandelon.com/isearch/intelligentSEARCH_CLASSICS.nsf/alldocs/C1257680005BA284C12573EE00470780/¤File/000000228909.PDF?OpenElement},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {3-593-33964-1},
  edition = {},
  note = {ZuLesen Kapitel 4 => Zu Klientelwesen},
  LCCN = {ULB 75/11591},
  note = {Religion und Feste Denn solche strategische List beweist nicht, daß die Religion hier insgesamt nur falscher Schein war, sondern lediglich, daß das, was wir als Religion bezeichnen (und dies gilt insbesondere für eine ritualistische Religion), im allgemeinen mehrer Funktionen erfüllt, die qualitiativ verschieden und nicht immer miteindander vereinbar sind. So diente etwa die römische Religion auch dazu, Sicherheit und Feierlichkeit herzustellen.  329},
  note = {Religion ist komplex Worauf es dagegen ankommt ist, daß die Religion insofern etwas Besonderes darstellt, als sie sich für vielfache Verwendungen eignet, so etwa für die bereits erwähnte Sicherheit oder (wie in Rom) für die feierliche Zelebrierung kollektiver Vergnügen für die Menschen. Denn die Spiele waren eine Huldigung an die Götter und zugleich ein Vergnügen für die Menschen. In dieser letzten Hinsicht waren sie anfällig für Manupulation, durch die formme Seelen vielleicht schockiert wurden.  330},
  note = {Religiöse Feste Da es der Glücksfall so wollte, daß die Götter die Feste ebenso sehr und aus denselben Gründen liebten wie die Menschen, wurden hier drei verschiedene Arten von Befriedigungen miteinander vermengt: Frömmigkeit, Festlichkeit und Feierlichkeit. [...] Die Menschen unterhielten sich nicht nur wie die Götter, sonder begingen feierlich ein kolletives Fest; denn alles Kollektive und wenig Organisierte, selbst ein Fest, brauchte ein Zeremoniell. Das Zeremoniell aber war der Religion entlehnt, die folglich fast überall im öffentlichen und privaten Leben präsent war. Ein kolletives Fest verlieh ein Gefühl der Feierlichkeit, die Überzeugung, an einem so umfassenden Unternehmen teilzuhaben, daß dessen letzet Ziele mit Sicherheit das Vergnügen an szenischen Darstellungen übertrafen, welches jeder für sich empfand.  331},
  note = {Spiele verlieren religiöse Bedeutung in der Kaiserzeit Während der beiden letzten Jahrhundert der Republik und um so mehr im Kaiserreich hatten die Spiele ihre religiöse Dimension im Geist ihrer Organsatoren und aller ihre Zuschauer verloren. Man sollte daraus nicht den Schluß ziehen, daß eine Frömmigkeit, die an ihren Ursprüngen intensiv war nach und nach aufgebraucht worden wäre. Wir sollten nicht den ethnologischen Mythos der Inbrunst in illo tempore projiziere, der in keiner historischen Epoche bezeugt ist und das Privileg primitiver Seelen sein soll. Es handelt sich nicht um eine abnehmende Intensität, sondern um mehrere Funktionen, die sich voneinander trennten.  332},
  note = {Persönlichere Religion Denn es [Anm. Säkularisierung] bezeichnet ebenso die Trennung zwischen Religion und Staat sowie den Übergang einer kollektiven Religion, welche ein gesamtes Volk (wenn man so sagen darf) ''als Menu'' erhält, zu einer Religion ''à la carte'', bei der sich jeder den Gott oder die Sekte aussucht, die er will. (Dies findet statt im Übergang von der Religion des klassischen Griechenlands und der der römischen Republik zur hellenistischen Religiosität und zu der des römischen Kaiserreichs oder im Übergang von Brahmanismus zum Hinduismus.) Unter Säkularisierung versteht man schließlich die Herausbildung eeins Glaubens ohne Konformismus, dessen Anhänger weniger zahlreich sind und für ihren Glauben perösnliche Gründe geltend machen.  332 f},
  note = {Euergetimus als Pflicht für Karriere Der Euergetimus wurde zu einem Instrument der politischen Karriere. Seit dem 2. Jh. v. u. Z. konnte, wer nicht die Ädilität durchlaufen hatte, mit der die Ausrichtung der teuersten Spiele verbunden war, sich kaum Chancen ausrechenen, in die Prätur oder das Konsulat gewählt zu werden. Der Euergetismus trug also dazu bei, einen Cursus honorum durchzusetzten, innerhalb dessen die Ädilitätt mit ihren prächtigen Spielen und dann die Prätur, mit der ebenfalls Spiele verbunden waren, dem Konsulat obligatorisch vorausgingen.  333},
  note = {Euergetismus als Machterhalt Wir sollten also die Vorliebe der Senatoren für eine exponierte Stellung in der Öffentlichkeit nicht mit einer allzu menschlichen Eitelkeit erklären.  In dieser autoritären Oligarchie bedeutete ein Gefallen an Popularität ein Interessen an Befehlsgewalt.  335},
  note = {Luxus und Verfall Wenn Luxus die Völker verweichlicht, korrumpiert Reichtum die Oligarchien. Er weckt bei den Armen  das Verlangen, sich über ihre Lebensverhältnisse zu erheben, was für die gesellschaftliche Ordnugn fatale Folgen hat, oder er ruft den Typus des Parvenu auf den Plan, der nicht die Tugenden des alten Aldes besitzt. Plutarch glaubte, daß gesellschaftliche Mobilität zum Fall der römischen Republik beigetragen habe. Vor der Zeit der Bürgerkriege, so schreibt er, ''war es ebenso sehr eine Schmach, sein Vermögen zu vergeuden, wie nicht an der Armut seiner Väter festzuhalten''. [..S. 422.] Vor allem aber korrumpierte der Reichtum den alten Adel, denn er weckte einen Ehrgeiz und eine Rivalität in ihm, die für das friedliche Funktionieren der Gesellschaft fatal waren. Hier wird deutlich, daß die kausale Verknüpfung dieses Arguments psychologische formuliert ist.  421 f},
  note = {Kaiserkult Von Priestern und Magistraten erarbeitet, hatte dieser Kult stets etwas Konventionells und Gewolltes. Seine Urheber, die Intellektuellen und Honorationen, gaben vor, die Massen des Volkes an Unterwürfigkeit gegenüber dem Souverän noch zu übertreffen. Der Herrscherkult hat nie einem Volksglauben entsprochen, sondern immer nur einem Gefühl des Volkes.  470},
  note = {Kaiserkult Die Existenz eines Herrscherkults ist stets ein politisches Symptom.  471},
  note = {Kaiserkult bei den Griechen Der Herrscherkult hatte bei den Griechen eine diplomatische und internationale  Bedeutung, mehr oder weniger wie die Verherrlichkung der Freundschaft zur Sowjetunion in den heutigen Volksdemokratien. Dadurch, daß eine Stadt den Kaiser anbetete, bekannte sie sich dazu, ein Satellit Roms zu sein. Daher mußten juristisch gesehen ihre Beziehungen zu Rom die zwischen zwei gesonderten Staaten sein. [...] Die Einrichtung eines Kaiserkults verstärkte gewiß von Natur aus vorhandene Phänomene und brachte sie nicht nur zum Ausdruck. Denn sobald eine Liebeserklärung mehr ist als ein Gefühlsausbruch und kanomische Form annimmt, wird sie zu einem Versprechen, das zum Gehorsam auch gegen sich selbst und schließlich gegen den anderen zwingt. [...] Oft ist ein Herrscherkult nur ein Zeremoniell. Ein Zeremoniell ist allerdings weniger auf symbolische Gewalt abgestellt, sondern dient vielmehr dazu, den Schwierigkeiten des Alltagslebens mit seinem pittoresken Durcheinander sich gegenseitig überlagernder Interessen zu entfliehen.  472},
  note = {Kaiserkult und Identität Der Kaiserkult war einerseits nur das Symbol einer politischen Treue zum Herrscher, die sehr wenige Christen ablehnten. Er existierte andererseits aus sich selbst heraus und implizierte ein ganzes Religionssystem, das für die Heiden so selbstverständlich war, daß sie sich kein anderes vorstellen konnten. Der Konflikt der Christen mit dem Kaiserkult war der zwischen einer Religion der Dogmen und einer Religion der Riten.  473},
  note = {Kaiserkult und Riten Riten waren im wesentlichen Ausdrucksformen eines höflichens Umgangs mit den Göttern und keine Symbole. [...] Es ist in der Tat symptomatisch, daß im römischen Kaiserreich der Herrscherkult selten extreme Formen (wie etwas blutige Opfer) annahm. Man begnügte sich zumeist dami, etwas Weihrauch zu opfern,  475},
  note = {Funktion des Kaiserkults Neben diesem wichtigsten Aspekkt hatte der Herrscherkult andere Funktionen, von denen hier vor allem der Euergetismus und das Zeremoniell genannt sein wollen. Das Wesen des Heidentums bestand aus Riten und Festen.  475},
  note = {Genien Ein Genius war nicht, wie oft gesagt wird, ein Schutzgeist oder ein unsterbliches ''Double''. Man sah Genien nie zum Schutz von Menschen oder Orten Stellung beziehen oder eingreifen. Sie taten nie etwas und unterschieden sich von Menschen und Orten nur durch ihre Modalität. Sie waren ihre abstrakte und vergöttlichte Individualität. Wenn ein Person einen Menschen oder einen Ort, an dem sie wohnen sollte, oder den Kaiser ehren wollte, so wandte sie sich mit ihren Gebeten an die jeweiligen Genien. Wenn ein Individuum starb, so ''starb'' zwar sein Genius nicht, überlebte es aber auch nicht. Ebensowenig starb sein Schatten - ihm bliebt einfach kein Ort mehr, das war alles. Die Individualität eines Menschen, der nicht mehr da war, gab es nicht mehr.  => ~ Seele  485},
  note = {Göttlichkeit des Kaisers So konnte auch der Kaiser, obwohl er sterblich war, als ein Gott gelten. Das war zwar widersprüchlich, doch dieser Widerspruch in der Sphäre des Fabulierens fiel weniger ins Gewicht, als dies für einen Widerspruch im Bereich der Gefühle gegolten hätte. Man konnte glauben (oder sagen, als glaubte man es), der Kaiser sein ein Gott, weil man das Gefühl der Erhabenheit des Königtums verspürte. Nur Theologen hätten durch Widersprüche zwischen den Fabeln auf pedantische Weise schockiert sein können.  485},
  note = {Hellenistische Religion Doch diese Zurückhaltung verschwand in hellenistischer Zeit, als in religiösen Dingen zum Triumph gelangte, was Hegel als Gesetz des Herzens und als Wahnsinn des Dünkels bezeichnete.  486},
  note = {Kaiserkult Alle Schwierigkeiten haben sie hier aus der Tatsache ergeben, daß die Religion, die ja nur ein historisches Phänomen, eine Grenzerfahrung oder ein vulgäres Konglomerat ist, verwechselt wurde mit der Erfahrung des Göttlichen, das umfassender, ja unbegrenzt ist und auscheint in der Ahnung seines Wesens. Man darf den Kaiser nicht mit den Göttern konfrontieren, sondern muß nach den Beziehungen suchen, die beide zur ursprünglichen Erfahrung des Göttlichen, zum ''Numinosen'' unterhalten.  486},
  note = {Kaiserkult Das war nicht weiter schwer, denn der Vergöttlichung des Kaiser entsprach, wie wir gesehen haben, einerseits die Unterwürfigkeit des Volkes vor seinem Herrn und andererseits in organisierter, institutionalisierter, offizieller Kult. Doch der Vergöttlichung entsprach kein Glaube. Man liebte den König unterwürfig und bot ihm Opfer dar, doch niemand sagte sich. ''Jupiter ist ein Gott, Mark Aurel auch.''  488},
  note = {Euergetimus in Italien Selbstverständlich waren außerhalb Roms in den Munizipien Italiens und in dne ausländischen Städten Spiele und Bauwerke den Euergeten freigestellt. SChließlich blieben großzügige Spenden aller Art, die außerhalb Roms zulässig waren, in der Hauptstadt dem Kaiser vorbehalten.  588},
  key = {Veyne980}
}

  author = {Margueron, Jean-Claude},
  title = {{Conclusions - Auhourd'hui et demain}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Architektur Gelesen NurVergleich Votive},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {''Maquettes architecturales'' de l'antiquité. Actes du Colloque de Strasbourg, 3-5 Dezember 1998},
  editor = {Muller, Béatrice},
  address = {Paris},

  edition = {},
  LCCN = {KB Straßburg 1998},
  note = {Modelle geben nicht die Realität wieder La maquette reflet de l'architecture antique Il nous faut bien constater que dans l'ensemble et sauf cas d'espèce - je pense en particulier à la maquette d'Archanès qui n'a pas fini de nous étonner - l'information architecturale venant des maquettes est faible, et ce n'est pas l'une des moindres conclusions de ce colloque. On ne peut espérer avoir des informations sur la proportion des étages à partir d'une maquette, ni sur le mode d'organisation de l'escpace interne, ni sur la structure des couvertures; les relations verticales sont, sauf justement à Archanès et Égypte, toujours inexistantes et nous connaissons le fonctionnement des portes par la fouille, sans avoir besoin de faire appel aux maquettes. Sauf cas rarissimes, on ne doit pas espérer restaurer les parties disparues des constructions antiques à partir des connaissances tirées des colloque, même s'il nous faut le regretter vivement, surtout quand on pense que ma première démarche vers le maquettes - et je n'ai pas été le seul - a été motivée par l'espoir d'y trouver les références manquantes sur le terrain.  542 f},
  key = {Margueron992}
}

  note = {Inschriften Verteilung In Italien ist eine relativ gleichmäßige Verteilung der Zeugnisse während des gesamten hier behandelten Zeitrausm festzustellen. Ein scheinbares Übergewicht während des 2. Jh.s ist wesentlich durch die besonders günstige Überlieferungssituation bedingt.  311},
  note = {Tibur Sonderfall Auffällig ist einmal die relativ hohe Zahl von Senatoren, die in Tibur sowohl magistratische als auch priesterliche Funktionen übernahmen. Sie stammten, zumindest im 2. Jh., nicht aus der Stadt selbst, sondern hatten Verbindung mit den Gemeinwesen erhalten, weil sie auf dem Territorium Landbesitz, vo allem für den Sommeraufenthalt, erworben hatten. Tibur war von Rom aus jederzeit leicht erreichbar, so daß sogar magistratische Aufgaben unter Umständen persönlich erfüllt werden konnten, wie es etwa auch die Tätigkeit des M. Antius Crescens Calpurnius als pontifex Volkani et aedium sacrarum in Ostia beweist. Sodann finden sich gerade unter diesen Amtsinhabern in italischen Städten nicht wenige, die patrizischen Standes waren, die sich überlicherweise nur kurzfristig in offizieller Mission in den Provinen aufhielten.  312},
  note = {Nähe Roms  Die relative Nähe zu Rom war wohl insgesamt von erheblichem Gewicht bei der Entscheidung von Mitgliedern des Senatorenstandes, in einzelnen Städten Italiens munizipale Verpflichtungen zu übernehmen;  312},
  note = {Lange Bindung an Stadt Zahlreicher sind jedoch die Fälle einer Bindung auch in der zweiten Generation oder sogar noch später, wie etwa bei P. Plautius Pulcher gegenüber Tibur (Ia Nr. 11)...  313},
  note = {Keine Loslösung Der Übergang munizipaler Familien in den Reichssenatorenstand hat keineswegs überall und sofort eine allgemeine Herauslösung aus der bisherigen Umwelt mit sich gebracht; diese Familien bildeten vielmehr auch weiterhein in vielen Selbstverwaltungseinheiten einen wesentlichen und auch aktiv-engagierten  Tiel der kleinräumigen städtischen Gesellschaften.  318},
  key = {Eck999}
}

@Book{Fejfer1001,
  author = {Fejfer, Jane},
  title = {{Roman Portraits in Context}},
  shorttitle = {},
  keywords = {Gelesen Kaiserzeit Nemi Praeneste Priorität Skulptur},
  journal = {},
  booktitle = {},
  editor = {},
  address = {Berlin},
  publisher = {Walter de Gruyter},
  volume = {},
  number = {},
  series = {},
  LCCN = {},
  year = {2008},
  month = {},
  pages = {Online-Ressource (ix, 592 p)},
  url = {http://site.ebrary.com/lib/academiccompletetitles/home.action},
  school = {},
  ISBN = {978-3-11-018664-2},
  edition = {},
  note = {ZuLesen S. 285 ff => Aufstellungskontext der Nemi Statuen},
  LCCN = {TB 348/350 Iko},
  note = {Ehren Statuen Qd Edwar  033},
  note = {Bedeutung von privaten Stiftungen If a citizen showed generosity towards the city, the assumption was that in return a statue of him would be set up in public place. This transformation fo real capital into symbolic capital played an essential part in teh social and economic life of a city. It only worked because it was predicated on shared values, amongst which the importance of public honour was supreme. Provincial cities were highly dependent on gifts from benefactors.  049},
  note = {Ehrung für Bürger in Praeneste For example, Gnaeus Voesius Aper is honoured with a statue by the community of Praeneste not only for his services as curator annonae and curator muneris publici gladiatori but also because he provided the land and oversaw the construction of a gladiatorial school and a spoliarium (an area set aside for stripping teh equipment of dead gladiators)  049},
  note = {Fundilius keine Senator o.ä. The ancient viewer would immediately have noticed that Fundilius wears simple soft boots and that there was (probably) neither a clavus on the tunica nor a purple border on the toga.  285},
  note = {Fundilius Benennung The styling of the Fundilius statue equals the best works found in Rome during this period. In his energetic pose and proud facial expression he might well have been an important senator or orator about to deliver a speech recorded in the scroll, which he had just untied. [...] The lack of a patronymic indicates that Gaius Fundilius is a freedman and Apollo's parasite or guest, meaning an actor. He is also doctus, an educated man. The nominative of the inscription suggests that he erected the statues himself perhaps a votive offering to the goddes of the sanctuary.  286},
  note = {Fundilia und Funilius zusammen konzipiert Dressed in a chiton, a large mantle and stola (the latter characterizing her as an honourable, upper-class married matrona), she is obviously the former owner of Fundilius, who possibly set up the statue in her honour, as teh use of the dative suggests. [...] The size of the two statues and the carving of the drapery (for example over the right thign) suggest that the statues of Fundilius and Fundila were made as a pair. Strong gender differences prevail in their body language, however. While the pose and the drapery arrangement of Fundilius' statue expresses openness, energy and dominance, teh concealed, wrapped-up body of Fundilia expresses her chaste and honourable lifestyle.  286},
  note = {Fundilia altmodisch-republikanisch wiedergegeben Behind the flat nodus, above her forehead, there is a flat cutting and a depression, originally menat for holding an additional high feather-like hair piece. [...] Fundilia may therefore wear the legendary Republican tutulus hairstyle, described by Varo as obligatory for the matres familias. The tutulus was a high construction made form twisted locks of hair intertwined with purple woolen threads and worn on the top of the head. It is rarely found in sculptural representation and must have been perceived as extremely old-fashioned. In accord with this, Fundilia has the serious, bony face of an old woman, marked by a deep furrow across the forehead, and wrinkles below the eyes and around the nose. The hairstyle and the ideal of aristocratic femininity presented here refer to late Republican female portrait styles. [...] Fundilia, Fundilius' former owner, is portrayed in a very old-fashioned style which indicates that she is being presented as his ancestor. In that role Fundilia follows a series of important Republican women, including Cornelia, the mother of teh Gracchi, whose public role it was to be ancestor.ð  300},
  note = {Kranzträger ebenfalls Künstler The final actor in the Nemi group may be identified with the male portrait wearing a wreath of flowers. This characterizes him as a victor in some competition, perhaps connected with the performing arts.  301},
  note = {Hostius Capitio Hostius Capito is a free citizen and a rhetor, a much more dignified profession than that of actor. [...] Hostius Capito's portrait also fits stylistically with the Claudian period. The quaestor of Aricia whose portrait relates closely to that of Fundilius was probably a relative of Fundilia Rufa, as his cognomen 'Rufus' suggests.  301},
  note = {Frauen auch Schauspieler (?) Rhetores and oratores learned a lot about the art of performance from actors. But an excessively close relationship was damaging for the rhetor, who might no longer be believed to speak the truth. The Parasites of Apollo were an association of scenic performers, whose members included pantomimes, mimes and actors. Fundilius, however, had a special role in being doctus ('learned'). [...] Rather he was a serious actor perhaps even one who performed in tragedy. The rhetor is perhaps a grafteful pupil or even a distant colleague.. [...] The inscriptions do not tell us anything to suggest why the freed women were present among the group but female mimes are known for example form an association which owned a communal burial space in Rome. It is therefore possible that the freedwomen from the Nemi group were performers, too.  302},
  note = {Einheitliche Gruppe -> Claudisch (?) There can be no doubt that the sculptures described above formed part of an ensemble, in which Fundilius was the central feature. The herm format, the type of marble, the quality of the carving and the style of the portraits demonstrate that they were set up as a group sometime during the Claudian period. The group may have been housed in the so-called Fundilia room or in another part of the sanctuary. [...] They bear witness to the multiple choice and variation that prevailed in the styling of portraits produced within the same period, made for the same social or associated group and by the same workshop.  302},
  note = {Verbindung zwischen Funidlius und Rufus (?) The presence in this room of images both of manumitted slaves who held one of the most dishonourable professions and of local notabilities, seems like an unequal partnership. [...] Perhaps the quaestor Lucius Aninius Rufus was involved in a similar business arragement with Fundilia and her freedman Fundilius and the other performers in the group. Secondly, Roman society enabled social mobility, although by law an actor like Fundilius was excluded from entering the nobility. However, his popularity, his influence as a performer as well as his own desire for public honours may have been factors that resulted in his assuming a substantial public role.  => fraglich  303},
  note = {Religiöser, lokaler Schauspieler Verein und Glanz des Kaisers The presence of three and possibly four actors, all of whom were freedmen, suggests an organization of parasiti with Fundilius as theri leader; it is he who is doctus and is represented in a full-figure statue. The organization may have had a significant role in performing religious plays such as the legendary succession of the high priest of Nemi, the Rex Nemorenses, in the small theatre situated nearby also within the sanctuary. Perhaps Sorex was invited for a particular event as guest performer. [...] He [Anm. Fundilius] may have set up the statue in her honour out of gratitude for his manumission, which she probably granted him after years of good income. [...] None of the statues or herms carries any indication of official approval. Fundilius may have been allowed to furnish this small room as a votive offering to Dina because of his services to the religious and artistic life of the sanctuary. [...] No doubt the nearby imperial statues lent a welcome prestige to Fundilius association of actors; but in terms of their own self-representation, the styling of the imperial image left only limited impact.  304},
  note = {Kaiserkult The imperial cult provided a platform for definig the outstanding role and position of the emperor in relationship to those whom he ruled, but this was modeled on the cult of the traditional gods and it inevitably smacked the god-like aspect of teh ruler. The invention of the centrally defined, multiple replicated and widely disseminated portrait image of the emperor, which made his personal features well known and recognizable, was far more all-embracing in its implications. It replaced the emperor in person and made him omni-present.  433},
  note = {Ehrenstatuen Teil der städtischen Identität With time the portrait came to represent the history, the memory and the identity of teh city and of the Empire. In the highly competitive Roman society with intense intercity rivalry, famous and generous citizens helped to define a city's identity. Together with statues of gods and of teh local personifications wich surrounded an honorific statue, the figure portrayed gradually became one of the city's mythical ancestors. A city was proud of its honorific statues because they were an integral element in its identity, shaping its history and sustaining its collective memory.  435},
  key = {Fejfer1001}
}
